Spanish Translation: Abnormal morphology of collagen fibers in cartilage. In cartilage, collagen II, actually a collagen II:IX:XI heterofibril, is by far the most important type of collagen. column5: Invasión vascular anormal de la metáfisis

Spanish Translation: Any abnormal process of ossification of the metatarsal bones, which normally are each ossified from two centers: one for the body, and one for the head (metatarsal II,III,IV, and V) and one for the body and one for the base (metatarsal I). The ossification process begins in the center of the body about the ninth week, and extends toward either extremity. The center for the base of the first metatarsal appears about the third year, and the centers for the heads of the other bones between the fifth and eighth years. They join the bodies between the eighteenth and twentieth years.

Spanish Translation: This term applies to all changes in bone mineral density which (depending on severity) can be seen on x-rays as a change in density and or structure of the bone. Changes may affect all bones of the organism, just certain bones or only parts of bones and include decreased mineralisation as may be seen in osteoporosis or increased mineralisation and or ossification as in osteopetrosis, exostoses or any kind of atopic calicfications of different origin and distribution. The overall amount of mineralization of the bone-organ can be measured as the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones, usually measured by densitometry of the lumbar spine or hip. The measurements are usually reported as g/cm3 or as a Z-score (the number of standard deviations above or below the mean for the patient's age and sex). Note that measurement with this method does not reflect local changes in other bones, and as such might not be correct with regard the hole bone-organ.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of dorsoventral patterning of the limbs
Spanish Translation: An abnormality resulting from a defect or disruption of dorsoventral patterning that normally happens during early development of the limbs. A disruption of the normal development of the dorsoventral axis may lead to a variable spectrum of different phenotypic abnormalities that may affect the nails and or palmar and dorsal side of the hands and/or feet, ultimately changing the normal dorsoventral appearance of the affected limbs.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
Spanish Translation: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand. Note that this includes the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
Spanish Translation: In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits). The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end (as seen in the proximal phalanges of the other digits), whereas the epiphyses of the other metacarpal bones are located at the distal end. This term applies if the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal is in any way abnormal, referring to age and gender depending norms, as seen on x-rays.
column5: Anomalía de la epífisis del primer metacarpiano

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 1st metatarsal
Spanish Translation: In contrast to the metatarsals 2-5, the first metatarsal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, whereas the proximal phalanx of the big toe is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits. This term applies to abnormalities of the epiphysis of the first metatarsal bone.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the hallux
Spanish Translation: In contrast to the metatarsals 2-5, the first metatarsal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, whereas the proximal phalanx of the big toe is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits. This term applies to abnormalities affecting the proximal phalanx of the hallux.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: This term applies if the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, which is located at the proximal end of the phalanx, does not appear in concordance with gender and age dependant norms as seen on x-rays. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

Abnormally long and slender fingers ("spider fingers").
Pathological deposition of calcium salts in one or more arteries.
Joint pain.
Joint pain affecting the hip.
Inflammation of a joint.
A non-progressive finding characterized by multiple joint contractures found throughout the body at birth.
A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply.
The congenital absence of the sternum.

column5: Autoamputación de dígitos de la mano

Term textual definition: Avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis
Spanish Translation: Avascular necrosis of the `proximal epiphysis of the femur` (FMA:32841) occurring in growing children and caused by an interruption of the blood supply to the head of the femur close to the hip joint. The necrosis is characteristically associated with flattening of the femoral head, for which reason the term coxa plana has been used to refer to this feature in the medical literature.
column5: Necrosis avascular de la epífisis capital femoral

Spanish Translation: The presence of a row of beadlike prominences at the junction of a rib and its cartilag.
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies.
column5: Cuerpos vertebrales con lengüetas o picos
Cuerpos vertebrales T12-L3 con lengüetas o picos

Spanish Translation: The rib cage has the shape of a wide mouthed bell. That is, the superior portion of the rib cage is constricted, follwed by a convex region, and the inferior portion of the rib cage expands again to have a large diameter.
Absence of the biceps muscle.
Exaggerated concavity of the anterior or posterior surface of the vertebral body, i.e., the upper and lower vertebral endplates are hollowed inward.
Presence of abnormal convexity of the upper and lower end plates of the vertebrae, i.e., an exaggerated bulging out of the upper and lower vertebral end plates.

Term textual definition: Bifid distal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones.

column5: Falange distal bífida del dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the `femur` (FMA:9611) as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side.
Partial duplication of the `first metacarpal bone` (FMA:23899).
Clefting affecting the humerus.

Term textual definition: Bifid proximal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is partially duplicated. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
A bifid rib refers to cleavage of the sternal end of a rib, usually unilateral. Bifid ribs are usually asymptomatic, and are often discovered incidentally by chest x-ray.
Presence of a `bifid` (PATO:0001572) `sacral bone` (FMA:16202).
The sternal cleft is a rare congenital anomaly resulting from a fusion failure of the sternum.
Cleft (split into two parts) `distal phalanx of thumb` (FMA:23945).
column5: Pulgar bífido en la falange distal

Spanish Translation: A cleft of the `xiphoid process` (FMA:7488) of the sternum.
The presence of bilateral `coxa_valga` (HP:0002673).
Missing radius bone on both sides associated with congenital failure of development.
The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease on both hands.
Bilateral clubfoot deformity (see HP:0001762).
A bilateral form of `triphalangeal thumb` (HP:0001199).
Underdevelopment of the ulna on both sides.
A chronic loss of wrist joint motion on the right and left sides.
column5: Contractura en flexión bilateral de la muñeca

Spanish Translation: A two-part `calcaneus`(FMA:24496), a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification.
A developmental defect that occurs if the two halves of the patella fail to fuse in early childhood.
Congenital synostosis between two or more adjacent vertebrae.
A fluid filled cavity that develops with a bone.

column5: Apariencia de hueso en hueso en el antebrazo

Spanish Translation: Digits that appear disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot. The word brachydactyly is used to describe a series of Mendelian diseases characterized by distinct patterns of shortened digits (brachydactyly types A-E). This is the sense used here, however, it is preferable to described the observed phenotypic abnormalities precisely.

Spanish Translation: In the orthopedic and radiological literature, sagittally cleft vertebra is generally known as a butterfly vertebra.
Butterfly vertebrae have a cleft through the body of the vertebrae and a funnel shape at the ends.
A `partial dislocation` (PATO:0002157) of the `atlantoaxial joints` (FMA:72336).
Any abnormality of the `atlas` (FMA:12519) and the `axis` (FMA:12520).
A `partial dislocation` (PATO:0002157) of the `intervertebral joint between the second and third cervical vertebrae` (FMA:25057).
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the `calcaneus` (FMA:24496).
column5: Punteado de la epífisis del calcáneo

Spanish Translation: Synostosis of the `calcaneus` (FMA:24496) with the `navicular bone` (FMA:24499).

This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus).
Abnormal narrowing of the orifice of the mitral valve because of calcification of the mitral valve leaflets.
An abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) pattern of calcifications in soft tissues within or surrounding bones (as observed on radiographs).

Term textual definition: Calcific stippling of infantile cartilaginous skeleton
column5: Calcificación punteada del esqueleto cartilaginoso infantil

Spanish Translation: Deposition of calcium salts in muscle tissue.
`Calcification` (PATO:0001447), that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the `aorta` (FMA:3734).
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the calf muscles.
column5: Hipertrofia del músculo de la pantorrilla

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the muscuklature of the calf.
column5: Hipoplasia del músculo de la pantorrilla

Spanish Translation: Enlargement of the muscles of the calf due to their replacement by connective tissue or fat.
An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull).

An abnormal forward-flexed posture e.g. forward flexion of the spine, which is noticeable when standing or walking but disappears when lying down. It is becoming an increasingly recognized feature of Parkinson's disease and dystonic disorders.
The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the second to fifth fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
column5: Camptodactilia de segundo a quinto dedos de la mano

Spanish Translation: The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
column5: Camptodactilia del dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: Camptodactyly is a painless flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint that is usually gradually progressive. This term refers to camptodactyly of one or more toes.
Abnormal calcification of a `cardiac valve` (FMA:7110).
Abnormal calcification in the `cardiovascular system` (FMA:7161).
Congenital absence of a carpal bone.
Underdevelopment of one or more `carpal bones`  (FMA:23889).
Osteolysis affecting carpal bones.
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform).
Fusion involving carpal and metacarpal bones.
The presence of a tail-like skin appendage located adjacent to the sacrum.

Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column. Note that normally, the interpedicular distances get progressively wider as one proceeds down the spine.
column5: Estrechamiento de las distancias interpediculares caudales

Spanish Translation: Congenital protrusion of the abdominal or thoracic viscera, usually with a defect of the sternum and ribs as well as of the abdominal walls.

A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal.
column5: Metacarpiano central en forma de Y

Spanish Translation: Exaggerated convexity of the cervical vertebral column, causing the cervical spine to bow outwards and take on a rounded appearance.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates affecting the cervical spine.
A supernumerary rib developing from an abnormal enlargement of the costal element of the C7 vertebra.
An abnormal narrowing of the cervical spinal canal.
An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine.
The presence of `arthrosis` (MPATH:27), i.e., of degenerative joint disease, affecting the `cervical vertebral column` (FMA:24138).
A `partial dislocation` (PATO:0002157) of one or more intervertebral joints in the `cervical vertebral column` (FMA:24138).
Fusion of the C5 and C6 cervical vertebrae.
`Agenesis` (MPATH:57) of one or more vertebrae of the `cervical vertebral column` (FMA:24138).

Term textual definition: Cervical vertebral bodies with decreased anteroposterior diameter
column5: Cuerpos vertebrales cervicales con diámetro anteroposterior disminuido

Spanish Translation: `Dysplasia` (MPATH:589) of the `cervical vertebral column` (FMA:24138).

Fusion of cervical vertebrae at C2 and C3, caused by a failure in the normal segmentation or division of the cervical vertebrae during the early weeks of fetal development, leading to a short neck with a low hairline at the back of the head, and restricted mobility of the upper spine.
A morphological abnormality of distal phalanges such that they have the appearance of chess pawns.
column5: Falanges distales en forma de peón de ajedrez
Epífisis radial en forma de cono o Chevron-like
Radio en forma de cono o Chevron-like

Spanish Translation: Chilblains are acral ulcers.
A type of `disproportionate short stature` (HP:0003498) characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in childhood.
column5: Talla baja con tronco corto de inicio infantil

Spanish Translation: Inflammation of cartilage.

Radiographic evidence of articular calcification that represent calcium pyrophosphate depositions in soft tissue surrounding joints and at the insertions of tendons near joints (Entheses/Sharpey fibers) .
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells.

A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the `notochord` (FMA:85521) along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis.
An increase in bone density within the clavicle.
A discontinuity of the vertebral arch (FMA:11946), i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
Clinodactyly refers to a bending or curvature of the `fifth finger` (FMA:24949) in the radial direction (i.e., towards the 4th finger).
column5: Clinodactilia del quinto dedo de la mano
Fémur distal en forma de palo de golf
Fémur proximal en forma de palo de golf

Spanish Translation: Broadening of the soft tissues (non-edematous swelling of soft tissues) of the digital tips in all dimensions associated with an increased longitudinal and lateral curvature of the nails.
Terminal broadening of the fingers (distal phalanges of the fingers).
Terminal broadening of the toes (distal phalanges of the toes).

column5: Coalescencia de los huesos del tarso

Spanish Translation: An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger).

column5: Huesos del carpo en forma de comas

Spanish Translation: A scoliosis which is the results of a difference in leg length (which might be due to hemihypertrophy or hemihypotrophy of a leg) and the resulting tilting of the pelvis. If untreated this will lead to the development of scoliosis over time.

Term textual definition: Complete duplication of distal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side.
column5: Duplicación completa de la falange distal del pulgar

Spanish Translation: Complete duplication of one or more `phalanx of big toe` (FMA:32884).
column5: Duplicación completa de la falange del dedo gordo del pie

Term textual definition: Complete duplication of phalanx of hand
Spanish Translation: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also refered to as Hyperphalangism.
column5: Duplicación completa de las falanges de la mano

Term textual definition: Complete duplication of proximal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
column5: Duplicación completa de la falange proximal del pulgar

Spanish Translation: A developmental defect consisting in the complete duplication of the first metatarsal bone.

Term textual definition: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd finger
Spanish Translation: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also refered to as Hyperphalangism.
column5: Duplicación completa de las falanges del segundo dedo de la mano

Term textual definition: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the thumb of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

Spanish Translation: The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a  bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle.

Term textual definition: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
Spanish Translation: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. That is, the PIP joint of a fourth finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
column5: Contractura de la articulación interfalángica proximal del cuarto dedo de la mano

Term textual definition: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe
Spanish Translation: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
column5: Contractura de la articulación interfalángica proximal del cuarto dedo del pie

Term textual definition: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger
Spanish Translation: Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion deformity of the little finger. That is, the PIP joint of a little finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
column5: Contractura de la articulación interfalángica proximal del quinto dedo de la mano

Term textual definition: Contracture of the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux
Spanish Translation: Chronic loss of joint motion in the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The tarsometatarsal joints of the feet are also called Lisfranc's joints.
column5: Contractura de la articulación tarsometatarsiana del dedo gordo del pie

Term textual definition: Contractures involving the joints of the feet
column5: Contracturas que afectan las articulaciones de los pies

Term textual definition: Contractures of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb
Spanish Translation: Chronic loss of joint motion of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is formed by the first metacarpal and the trapezial bone and is also called Articulatio carpometacarpalis pollicis, carpometacarpal articulation of thumb, carpometacarpal joint of thumb or first carpometacarpal articulation. Seldom referred to as thumb saddle joint.
column5: Contracturas de la articulación carpometacarpiana del pulgar

Spanish Translation: The distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.

Term textual definition: Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
Spanish Translation: A less than normal number of sternal ossification centers. The sternum is initially formed from bilateral sternal plates that chondrify and begin to fuse with ribs at 10 weeks gestational age. Ossification starts in the manubrium and upper part of the sternal body at the 6th month, in the middle of the sternal body at the 7th month, in the lower part of the body during the 1st postnatal year and in the xiphoid process between years 5 and 18. The number of ossification centers vary up to six, and it is the ossification centers that are visualized by prenatal ultrasound. This term describes a reduction in the number of ossification centers compared with age-related norms.
column5: Disminución del número de centros de osificación esternal

column5: Duplicación de la falange proximal del dedo gordo del pie

Term textual definition: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Spanish Translation: Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
column5: Duplicación de la falange proximal del pulgar

Spanish Translation: Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
An abnormality of the hand resulting from contracture of the palmar fascia with a fixed flexion deformity of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is an acceleration in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.
column5: Edad ósea acelerada disarmónica (no coincidente entre huesos)

Spanish Translation: Different levels of maturation of different bones.
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is a delay in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.

Term textual definition: Dysharmonic maturation of the hand bones
Spanish Translation: Pattern of hand-wrist development does not fit the normal sequence of ossification of the individual bones of the hand.
column5: Maduración de los huesos de la mano disarmónica

Spanish Translation: The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `femoral head` (FMA:32851).

Term textual definition: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole
column5: Falanges distales del pulgar displásicas con un orificio central

column5: Enfermedad valvular cardíaca progresiva con calcificación temprana

Spanish Translation: In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes refered to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200).
column5: Apéndice accesorio con forma de dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the fibular side of the foot, next top the little toe), preaxial (on the tibial side of the foot, next to the big toe) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between big and little toe), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes refered to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200).
column5: Apéndice accesorio con forma de dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: Deposition of calcium salts in a tissue or location in which calcification does not normally occur.
Formation of abnormal, extraskeletal bony tissue, i.e., the presence of bone in soft tissue where bone normally does not exist.

Formation of abnormal bony tissue within `muscle` (FMA:30316) tissue.

The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe/fingers over absent 2nd or 3rd toes/fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands and/or feet.
Dislocation of the distal humerus out of the elbow joint, where the radius, ulna, and humerus meet.
A chronic loss of elbow joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the elbow.
Increased length of the `radius` (FMA:23463).
Increased size of epiphyses.
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger with respect to age-dependent norms.

The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphyses of phalanges of the fingers.

Spanish Translation: Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees.

Term textual definition: Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the femurs
Spanish Translation: Flaring of distal  `femur` (FMA:9611).
column5: Deformidad de los fémures en matraz de Erlenmeyer

Spanish Translation: An increased degree of  femoral version, which is defined as the angular difference between axis of femoral neck and transcondylar axis of the knee. Thus, femoral anteversion is an inward twisting of the femur that causes the knees and feet to turn inward.
An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is cappped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Abnormal formation of new bone on the surface of a bone of the hand.
column5: Exostosis de huesos de la mano
Exostosis de los huesos del antebrazo

column5: Metacarpianos agrandados con cavidades medulares ensanchadas

column5: Metatarsianos agrandados con cavidades medulares ensanchadas

column5: Falanges agrandadas con cavidades medulares ensanchadas

Spanish Translation: Failure of the femur to develop.
Bowing (abnormal curvature) of the `femur` (FMA:9611).

Term textual definition: Femoral bowing present at birth, straightening with time
Spanish Translation: Congenital onset bending or abnormal curvature of the `femur` (FMA:9611) that normalizes with age.
column5: Incurvación del fémur al nacer que mejora con el tiempo

Spanish Translation: Tumor-like growths that consist of replacement of the medullary bone with fibrous tissue, causing the expansion and weakening of the areas of bone involved. Especially when involving the skull or facial bones, the lesions can cause externally visible deformities. The skull is often, but not necessarily, affected, and any other bone or bones may be involved. Fibrous dysplasia can either effect isolated bones (Monostotic fibrous dysplasia) or also generalized all bones of the body (Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia).
Absence of the fibula.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the `fibula` (FMA:24479).

column5: Desviación externa o fibular del segundo dedo del pie
Desviación externa o fibular del tercer dedo del pie
Desviación externa o fibular del cuarto dedo del pie
Desviación externa o fibular del quinto dedo del pie
Desviación externa o fibular de los dedos del pie

Spanish Translation: Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition.
Underdevelopment of the fibula.
Relatively increased growth of the fibula compared to that of the tibia.
Bending or curvature of the `distal phalanx of little finger` (FMA:23949) in the radial direction (i.e., towards the 4th finger).
column5: Clinodactilia de la falange distal del quinto dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: Presence of an angular or V -shaped indentation on the ulnar side of the fifth metacarpal bone (i.e., on the sides towards the fifth finger).
Bending or curvature of a `fifth toe` (FMA:25053) in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
column5: Clinodactilia del quinto dedo del pie
Hiperextensibilidad de la articulación de dedo de la mano
Hiperlaxitud articular de dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are revered to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as "Symphalangism".
column5: Sindactilia de dedo de la mano
Metáfisis femoral en forma de campana

Spanish Translation: Flaring (increase of width with a splayed appearance) of the `humeral metaphysis` (FMA:32830).
column5: Metáfisis humeral en forma de campana

Spanish Translation: Widening of the `ilium ala` (FMA:42826), that is of the wing of the ilium, combined with external rotation, leading to a flared appearance of the iliac wing.
column5: Alas ilíacas en forma de campana
Metáfisis irregulares en forma de campana

Spanish Translation: The presence of splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segments of the long bones.

column5: Metáfisis del codo en forma de campana

Term textual definition: Flared metaphyses of the upper limbs
column5: Metáfisis ensanchadas de los miembros superiores
Metáfisis radial en forma de campana
Extremos de las costillas irregulares en forma de campana
Tórax inferior en forma de campana

Spanish Translation: The presence of wide, concave anterior rib ends.

Flattening of the superior part of the acetabulum, which is a cup-shaped cavity at the base of the hipbone into which the ball-shaped head of the femur fits. The acetabular roof thereby appears horizontal rather than arched, as it normally does.
An abnormal flattening of the `proximal epiphysis of the femur` (FMA:32841).
column5: Epífisis de la cabeza femoral achatada

Spanish Translation: An abnormal flattening of the 'Distal epiphysis of femur` (FMA:32822).
Abnormally flat configuration of the `glenoid fossa` (FMA:23275), also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Abnormal flatness (decreased height) of epiphyses.
An abnormally flattened `femoral head` (FMA:32851).
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metacarpal bones.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones.
An abnormally flat form of the proximal epiphysis of the radius.

Term textual definition: Flattened, squared-off epiphyses of tubular bones
column5: Epífisis aplanadas de los huesos tubulares

Spanish Translation: A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints.
One or more bent (flexed) joints of the third toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
column5: Contractura en flexión del tercer dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: Chronic loss of joint motion in a finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
column5: Contractura en flexión de los dedos de la mano

Spanish Translation: Chronic loss of joint motion in the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 2nd finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
column5: Contractura en flexión del segundo dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the second toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
column5: Contractura en flexión del segundo dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the fourth toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
column5: Contractura en flexión del cuarto dedo del pie

A sensation of stiffness in the joints that occurs following waking up in the morning.

Generalized weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs.
column5: Debilidad generalizada de los músculos de las extremidades

column5: Tumor de células gigantes del hueso

`Gout` (HP:0001997) affecting the `Metatarsophalangeal joint of big toe`.

Spanish Translation: Lateral deviation of the great toe (i.e., in the direction of the little toe).
Medial deviation of the great toe owing to a deformity of the great toe joint causing the hallux to deviate medially.
Hyperextension of the metatarsal-phalangeal joint with hyperflexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint.
An abnormal hand posture in which the hands are clenched to fists. All digits held completely flexed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.
Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the hand.
A kind of `polydactyly` (HP:0010442) characterized by the presence of a supernumerary finger or fingers.
Bony swelling of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage thzat are visible radiographically.
Undergrowth of the limbs that affects only one side.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of a leg.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of an arm.
Overgrowth of only one side of the body.
Overgrowth of only one leg.
Overgrowth of only one arm.
Shortening of a leg affecting only one side.
A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body.
The presence of abnormal `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) in the `liver` (FMA:7197).
The presence of one or more `herniated` (PATO:0000643) `nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disk` (FMA:13550).
Increased height of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
Permanent fixation of the hip in primary positions, with limited passive or active motion at the hip joint.
Displacement of the femur from its normal location in the hip joint.
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `hip` (FMA:24964).
With the hand relaxed and the thumb in the plane of the palm, the axis of the thumb forms an angle of at least 90 degrees with the long axis of the hand.
A horizontal (flat) conformation of the ribs, the long curved bones that form the rib cage and normally  progressively oblique (slanted) from ribs 1 through 9, then less slanted through rib 12.
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the radius and the humerus.
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the ulna and the humerus.

column5: Contracturas en las articulaciones de la mano

Spanish Translation: Displacement or malalignment of joints.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring within a `joint` (FMA:7490).
The ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
Lack of stability of a joint.
Joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in a joint or joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity. Joint stiffness typically subsides over time.

column5: Inflamación articular inicio en la infancia tardía

Spanish Translation: Juvenile aseptic necrosis comprises a group of orthopedic diseases characterized by interruption of the blood supply of a bone, followed by localized bony necrosis most often of the epiphyses of bones of children or teenagers.
A bent (flexed) knee joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
column5: Contractura en flexión de la rodilla

Spanish Translation: An abnormal curvature of the spine in both a coronal (lateral) and sagittal (back-to-front) plane.
Exaggerated anterior convexity of the thoracic vertebral column.
`Calcification` (PATO:0001447), that is, pathological  deposition of calcium salts, of the large, conduit arteries (aorta, subclavian, carotid, iliac, renal, axillary, femoral, brachial).
Increased size of carpal bones.
Increased size of the `ilium ala` (FMA:42826).
The presence of an abnormally large pelvis.
Calcification (abnormal deposits of calcium) in the laryngeal tissues.

column5: Desplazamiento lateral de la cabeza femoral

column5: Aplasia del cóndilo lateral del húmero

column5: Talla baja con tronco corto letal

Spanish Translation: A contrqacture (chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin) that prevent normal movement of one or more joints of the limbs.
Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology.
Limb shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the extremities.
A reduction in the freedom of movement of one or more joints.

column5: Limitación de la movilidad de la rodilla

column5: Limitación en la extensión del codo
Limitación en la extensión  y supinación del codo
Limitación en la flexión del codo
Limitación en el movimiento del codo

column5: Limitación en la extensión de la cadera

column5: Limitación del movimiento de la cadera
Limitación del movimiento de articulación interfalángica

column5: Limitación en el movimiento del hombro

column5: Limitación en el movimiento de la muñeca

Spanish Translation: Increased length of the clavicles.
Increased length of the `distal phalanx of finger` (FMA:75818).
column5: Falange distal alargada de dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: Disproportionately long fibulae.

The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand.
Increased back to front length of the foot.
Increased length of the `big toe` (FMA:25047).
column5: Dedos gordos de los pies largos

Increased length of the `middle phalanx of finger` (FMA:75817).
column5: Falange media del dedo de la mano largo

Spanish Translation: For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length.
Increased length of multiple or a single `phalanx of finger` (FMA:23914).
column5: Falange del dedo de la mano largo

Spanish Translation: Increased length of the `proximal phalanx of finger` (FMA:75816).
column5: Falange proximal del dedo  de la mano largo

Spanish Translation: Increased inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
Digits that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot.
Increased length of the ulna.
A difference in length or diameter between the left and right leg.
Pain in the leg with no clear focal etiology.
`Peromelia` (HP:0009828) affecting only the lower limbs.  That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation.
`Phocomelia` (HP:0009829) affecting only the lower limbs.
Leg shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the lower extremity.
A reduction of the distance between the lower thoracic vertebral pedicles.
column5: Estrechamiento de la distancia interpedicular de vértebras torácicas bajas

Spanish Translation: Over curvature of the lower thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the lumbar spine.
An abnormal accentuation of the inward curvature of the spine in the lumbar region.
Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between lumbar vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column.
column5: Estrechamiento de la distancia interpedicular lumbar

Spanish Translation: Over curvature of the lumbar region.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine.
An abnormal narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal.

column5: Defecto lítico en metáfisis de los miembros superiores

The increased girth is accompanied by an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension AND the lateral dimension of the digit.
A type of `Macrodactyly` (HP:0004099) affecting one or several fingers.

Trastornos del desarrollo de la articulación radio-cubital
Marcado retraso en la edad ósea

column5: Masivo engrosamiento de las corticales de huesos largos

Spanish Translation: The presence of a supernumerary toe (not a hallux) involving the third or fourth metatarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly.
The presence of a supernumerary finger or toe (not a thumb or hallux) involving the third or fourth metacarpal/tarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
Shortening of the middle parts of the limbs (forearm and lower leg) in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Shortening of the middle parts of the arm in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Shortening of the middle parts of the leg in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Increase in bone denisty in the diaphyseal (shaft) region of a metacarpal bone.

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx).
A chronic loss of joint motion in metacarpophalangeal joints due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
Increased mobility of one ore more `metacarpophalangeal joint` (FMA:35246).
Fusion of a metacarpal bone with the proximal phalanx of the finger distal to it across the corresponding `metacarpophalangeal joint` (FMA:35246).

Term textual definition: Metaphyseal abnormalities of distal and proximal femurs
column5: Anomalías metafisaria de fémur distal y proximal

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae.
Metaphyseal cupping refers to an inward bulging of the metaphyseal profile giving the metaphysis a cup-like appearance.
Metaphyseal cupping affecting the metacarpal bones.
column5: Metáfisis de los metacarpianos en forma de copa

Spanish Translation: Metaphyseal cupping affecting the proximal phalanges.
column5: Metáfisis de las falanges proximales en forma de copa

Spanish Translation: The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
The presence of dysplastic regions in metaphyseal bones.
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphyses.
Reduction in density of metaphyseal bony tissue.
Abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Bony outgrowths that extend laterally from the margin of the metaphysis.
Abnormal widening of the metaphyseal regions of long bones.
Osteosclerosis of the endosteal surface of the diaphyses (shafts) of the metatarsal bones.
column5: Esclerosis endosteal de la diáfisis del metatarso

Spanish Translation: Osteolysis involving metatarsal bones.
The metatarsals are deviated medially (tibially), that is, the bones in the front half of the foot bend or turn in toward the body.
A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight.
The presence of abnormally small extremities.
Developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the middle portion of the clavicle.
Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle.
`Mirror image duplication of digits` (HP:0010689) affecting the feet.
column5: Polidactilia de pie imagen en espejo

Spanish Translation: `Mirror image duplication of digits` (HP:0010689) affecting the hands only.
column5: Polidactilia en mano imagen en espejo

Spanish Translation: A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes.
A developmental anomaly with absence of one or more ribs.
Abnormal calcification of the `mitral valve` (FMA:7235).
Fusion of the hands and feet by a thin membrane of skin (scarring) seen in forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa and leading to a "mitten" hand deformity.

column5: Esclerosis mixta de la metáfisis humeral

Spanish Translation: Moderate osteoporosis.
`Fibrous dysplasia of the bones` (HP:0010734) were lesions are localized in only one bone.
Morbus Kienboeck is a `Juvenile aseptic necrosis` (HP:0100323) affecting the Os lunatum.
Morbus Koehler is a `Juvenile aseptic necrosis` (HP:0100323) affecting the Os naviculare pedis.
Morbus Osgood-Schlatter is a `Juvenile aseptic necrosis` (HP:0100323) affecting the Tuberositas tibiae.

A developmental growth retardation of the vertebral end plates that may lead to secondary destruction of the vertebral end plates and protrusion of the nucleus pulposus into the vertebral body (so called Schmorl's nodes as seen on x-rays).
There is normally one ossification center in the head of the femur. This term applies if there are multiple such centers.
column5: Osificación multicéntrica de la cabeza femoral

Term textual definition: Multicentric ossification of proximal femoral epiphyses
column5: Osificación multicéntrica de las epífisis femorales proximales

Term textual definition: Multicentric ossification of proximal humeral epiphyses
column5: Osificación multicéntrica de las epífisis proximales del húmero

Spanish Translation: Presence of multiple cystic changes in multiple ares or multiple bones.
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the `epiphysis` (FMA:24012) of one or more long bones.
column5: Múltiples centros de osificación del carpo

Spanish Translation: Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes.
column5: Exostosis múltiples de dedos de la mano

Spanish Translation: Presence of more than one exostosis. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is cappped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Dislocation of many joints.
Multiple exostoses originating in long bones.
The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease).
The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before.
More than one fracture of the ribs.
`Calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) in the `myocardium` (FMA:9462).
An abnormal reduction of the anterioposterior diameter of the `vertebral body` (FMA:11945).
Reduced width of the chest from side to side, associated with a reduced distance from the sternal notch to the tip of the shoulder.
An abnormally reduced diameter of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
A foot for which the measured width is below the 5th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
Decreased width of the `foramen obturatorium` (FMA:16999). The foramen obturatorium (also known as the obturator foramen) is a hole located between the ischium and pubis bones of the pelvis.
A narrowing of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium.
column5: Estrechamiento de las hendiduras sacrociáticas mayores

Spanish Translation: Decreased width of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).

column5: Espacios articulares de la muñeca estrechos

column5: Muescas sacroilíacas estrechas en la infancia

column5: Estrechamiento de las pequeñas articulaciones de la mano

A form of triphalangeal thumb that can be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.
Separation of the odontoid process from the body of the axis.

Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual finger bones. Bony fusions are revered to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as "Symphalangism".

Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual bones of the toes. Bony fusions are revered to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a tibial-fibular axis. Fusions of bones of the toes in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".

Spanish Translation: A benign, painful, tumor of bone characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue, primitive bone and calcified tissue.

A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage.
Osteolysis refers to the destruction of bone through bone resorption with removal or loss of calcium.

Spanish Translation: Osteomas are bony growths found most commonly on the skull and mandible; however, they may occur in any bone of the body. Osteomas do not usually cause clinical problems and do not become malignant.

Osteomalacia is a general term for bone weakness owing to a defect in mineralization of the protein framework known as osteoid. This defective mineralization is mainly caused by lack in vitamin D. Osteomalacia in children is known as rickets.
An infection of bone.

A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance.

Osteopenia refers to a reduction in bone mineral density (BMD) below normal peak BMD but not low enough to be classified as osteoporosis. According to the WHO, osteopenia is characterized by a value of BMD more than 1 standard deviation below the young adult mean, but less than 2 standard deviations below this value.
Abnormally increased formation of dense trabecular bone tissue. Despite the increased density of bone tissue, osteopetrotic bones tend to be more fracture-prone than normal.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake.

Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone density and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue with a consequent increase in bone fragility. According to the WHO, osteoporosis is characterized by a value of BMD 2.5 standard deviations or more below the young adult mean.
Osteoporosis affecting predominantly the vertebrae.

column5: Osteoporosis en los huesos del antebrazo

Spanish Translation: Decrease in mass and density of the metatarsal bones.
Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the `tarsal bones` (FMA:71339), seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.

A malignant bone tumor that usually develops during adolescence and usually affects the long bones including the tibia, femur, and humerus. The typical symptoms of osteosarcoma comprise bone pain, fracture, limitation of motion, and tenderness or swelling at the site of the tumor.
Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass).

Term textual definition: Osteosclerosis of the base of the skull
Spanish Translation: An increase in bone density affecting the basicranium (base of the skull).
column5: Osteosclerosis de la base del cráneo

Spanish Translation: Osteosclerosis (increased density related to increased bone mass) of the ulna.
A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest.
column5: Superposición de los dedo de la manos

Spanish Translation: Describes a foot digit resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the foot is at rest.
column5: Superposición de los dedos del pie

Spanish Translation: Overconstriction, or narrowness of the diaphysis and metaphysis of long bones.

column5: Fracturas indoloras debido a una lesión

Term textual definition: Patchy changes of bone mineral density
Spanish Translation: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density. These changes can either be patchy reduction or increase of mineral density as seen on x-rays. Depending on the pathomechanism and the underlying disease, these changes can either appear solely as reduction or increase or as a combination of both (patches of bone showing an increased density while others are affected by reduction of mineral density).
column5: Cambios irregulares de la densidad mineral ósea

Spanish Translation: Patchy (irregular) increase in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.

Term textual definition: Patchy reduction of bone mineral density
Spanish Translation: Patchy (irregular) reduction in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.
column5: Disminución de la densidad mineral ósea en parches

Term textual definition: Patchy variation in bone mineral density
Spanish Translation: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density with patches of bone showing an increased density side to side with patches that are affected by reduction of mineral density. This is sometimes referred to as a moth-eaten appearance on x-rays.
column5: Variación irregular en la densidad mineral ósea

Spanish Translation: Absence of the patella.
The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar dislocation occurs if the patella fully dislocates out of the groove.
Underdevelopment of the patella.

The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella.

A pathologic fracture occurs when a bone breaks in an area that is weakened secondary to another disease process such as tumor, infection, and certain inherited bone disorders. A pathologic fracture can occur without a degree of trauma required to cause fracture in healthy bone.
Bulbous appearance of the anterior vertebral bodies, such that the vertebral bodies have the greatest vertical height anteriorly as well as bulbous anterior superior-inferior contours.
Underdevelopment of the pectoral muscle.
A deformity of the chest caused by overgrowth of the ribs and characterized by protrusion of the sternum.
A defect of the chest wall characterized by a depression of the sternum, giving the chest ("pectus") a caved-in ("excavatum") appearance.
Pectus excavatum (defect of the chest wall characterized by depression of the sternum) affecting primarily the inferior region of the sternum.
column5: Pectus excavatum región inferior del esternón

Term textual definition: Peg-like central prominence of distal tibial metaphyses
column5: Prominencia central de las metáfisis tibiales distales (con forma de ganchos)

Spanish Translation: Pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology.
A benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface of the pelvis. Exostoses are cappped by cartilage, and arise from a bone that develops from cartilage.

Term textual definition: Periosteal thickening of long tubular bones
Spanish Translation: Thickening of the `periosteum of long bone` (FMA:32677).
column5: Engrosamiento del periostio de los huesos tubulares largos

Spanish Translation: The distal parts of the limbs are missing leading to a stump formation.

Atrophy of the peroneous muscles, `peroneus longus (also known as Fibularis longus)' (FMA:22539), `Peroneus brevis (also known as fibularis brevis` (FMA:22540), and `Peroneus tertius (also known as fibularis tertius` (FMA:22538).
The presence of an unusually high `plantar arch` (FMA:43942). Also called high instep, pes cavus refers to a distinctly hollow form of the sole of the foot when it is bearing weight.

A foot where the `plantar arch` (FMA:43942) is in contact with the ground or floor when the individual is standing; or, in a patient lying supine, a foot where the arch is in contact with the surface of a flat board pressed against the sole of the foot by the examiner with a pressure similar to that expected from weight bearing; or, the height of the arch is reduced.

Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region.
A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates.

column5: Huesos de la mano en punta

Term textual definition: Pointed proximal second through fifth metacarpals
Spanish Translation: All of the metacarpal bones of the hand have a pointed proximal appearance.
column5: Segundo a quinto metacarpianos proximales en punta

Spanish Translation: A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes.

column5: Polidactilia que afecta el segundo dedo de la mano
Polidactilia que afecta el segundo dedo del pie
Polidactilia que afecta el tercer dedo de la mano
Polidactilia que afecta el tercer dedo del pie
Polidactilia que afecta el cuarto dedo de la mano
Polidactilia que afecta el cuarto dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: `Fibrous dysplasia of the bones` (HP:0010734) were lesions are localized in many bones throughout of the body. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is a cardinal feature of McCune-Albright syndrome.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the great toe.
column5: Polisindactilia de dedo gordo del pie

Spanish Translation: Decreased `ossification` ( GO:0001503) of the cervical vertebral bodies, i.e., of the `Cervical vertebrae set` (FMA:72063).
Decreased `ossification` ( GO:0001503) of the `vertebral bodies` (FMA:11945).
A pterygium (or pterygia) occuring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee).
A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the muscle and soft tissue. In contrast if the bones of the foot are affected the term structural foot deformity applies.

Polydactyly of the foot most commonly refers to the presence of six toes on one foot. Postaxial polydactyly affects the lateral ray and the duplication may range from a well-formed articulated digit to a rudimentary digit.
Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand (that is, on the side with the fifth finger).
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the fifth finger or fifth toe.
Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand with a complete extra finger and extra metacarpal.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the foot on the lateral side (i.e., on the side of the little toe).

column5: Fusión posterior de las vértebras lumbosacras

Spanish Translation: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an posterior direction.
column5: Luxación posterior de la cabeza radial

Spanish Translation: Wide, concave posterior rib end.
Complete or partial merging of the posterior part of adjacent ribs.
An excessive concavity of the posterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies.
column5: Festoneado posterior de los cuerpos vertebrales

Spanish Translation: Partial dislocation of the head of the radius in the posterior direction.
column5: Subluxación posterior de la cabeza radial

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the shape of  vertebrae, such that they are wedge-shaped (narrow towards the back).
column5: Acuñamiento posterior de los cuerpos vertebrales

Spanish Translation: Duplication of all or part of the first ray.

Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the thumb or great toe.
Early ossification of the `costochondral junction` (FMA:7956), which is the joint between the ribs and costal cartilage in the front of the rib cage.

Mitral annular calcification (MAC) results from progressive calcium deposition along and beneath the mitral valve annulus . MAC is a common degenerative process involving the fibrous annulus of the mitral valve, and is generally an incidental finding associated with aging. This term applies if MAC occurs at a substantially younger age than usual.

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at each end of a long bone, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the fibula, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
column5: Fusión epimetafisiaria prematura en el peroné

Spanish Translation: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the foot, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
column5: Fusión epimetafisiaria prematura en el pie

Spanish Translation: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the hand, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
column5: Fusión epimetafisiaria prematura en la mano

Spanish Translation: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the radius, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the tibia, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
column5: Fusión epimetafisiaria prematura en la tibia

Spanish Translation: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the ulna, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
column5: Fusión epimetafisiaria prematura en el cúbito

Spanish Translation: Fusion of the epiphysis and metaphysis of one or more phalanges prior to the normal age or stage of growth.
column5: Fusión prematura de la epífisis de las falanges

Term textual definition: Premature fusion of the radial epiphyseal plates
Spanish Translation: A premature fusion of the epiphyseal plates of the radius. Epiphyseal plates are located at the distal and proximal ends of the long bones, in this case of the radius and premature fusion will have an effect on the growh of the radial bone, inhibiting or at least disturbing the normal growth and development of the bone.
column5: Fusión prematura de las placas epifisarias radiales

Spanish Translation: Prematurely closed sternal sutures.
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of a `long bone` (FMA:7474).
column5: Encurvamiento progresivo de los huesos largos
Fusión espinal progresiva de las vértebras cervicales

Spanish Translation: Progressive bone resorption in the distal part of the clavicle.
A progressive form of `scoliosis` (HP:0002650) with congenital onset.
Progressively worsening joint contractures.
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the `forearm skeleton` (FMA:71199).

column5: Fusión progresiva de articulaciones interfalángicas proximales segunda-quinta

Spanish Translation: A `progressive` (PATO:0001818) form of `decreased height` (PATO:0000569) of the `intervertebral disk` (FMA:10446).
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the leg.
The development of `Pes cavus` (HP:0001761) that is progressive with age.
Protruding heel bone, or `calcaneus`(FMA:24496).

A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips. The term "persistent fetal fingertip pads" is often used as a synonym, but should better not be used because it implies knowledge of history of the patient which often does not exist.
column5: Almohadillas de la yema del dedo prominentes

Spanish Translation: Increased prominence of the `xiphoid process` (FMA:7488) of the sternum.

column5: Acortamiento proporcional de todos los dedos de la mano

Spanish Translation: Intrapelvic bulging of the medial acetabular wall.

Spanish Translation: The presence of multiple protuberances (bulges, or knobs) at the ends of the `long bones` (FMA:7474).
column5: Protuberancias en los extremos de los huesos largos

Spanish Translation: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is defined as a posterior and inferior slippage of the `proximal epiphysis of the femur` (FMA:32841) onto the metaphysis (femoral neck), occurring through the physeal plate during the early adolescent growth spurt.
Overgrowth of the proximal part of the fibula.

column5: Hiperextensibilidad articular proximal de dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the legs, i.e., of the thigh.

column5: Engrosamiento perióstico de la falange proximal

Spanish Translation: `Proximal mislocalization` (PATO:0002179) of the `big toe` (FMA:25047) from its normal position.
column5: Desplazamiento proximal del dedo gordo del pie

Spanish Translation: `Proximal mislocalization` (PATO:0002179) of the `thumb` (FMA:24938).
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an proximal direction.
column5: Luxación proximal de la cabeza radial

Spanish Translation: An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the proximal portions of the radius and the ulna.

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases.
Some or all of the metacarpal bones (i.e., metacarpal II to V) have a pointed proximal appearance.
Bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the 2nd toe.

Spanish Translation: A band of bone material of decreased density forming alongside the surface of the cortical bone with thickening of the periosteum. Callus formation in the affected area is common and gives the appearance of a false fracture.

A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or "false joint").

Accessory epiphyses (which are also known as pseudoepiphyses) can also occasionally be observed at the proximal ends of the metacarpals, usually involving the 2nd metacarpal bone.

The normal epiphysis of the second metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.

The normal epiphysis of the third metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.

The normal epiphysis of the fourth metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.

The normal epiphysis of the fifth metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.

Spanish Translation: A displacement or misalignment of the humerus with respect to the other bones of the should joint. Note that a subluxation is a partial dislocation.
Chronic reduction in active and passive mobility of the shoulder joint due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.

The shoulder, or pectoral, girdle is composed of the clavicles and the scapulae. Shoulder-girdle weakness refers to lack of strength of the muscles attaching to these bones, that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders.

column5: Queratosis espinosas de palmas y plantas

Spanish Translation: Flaring (widening) of the epiphysis.
Divergence of digits along the anteroposterior axis (in the plane of the sole).

A condition in which middle parts of the foot (toes and metatarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe over absent 2nd or 3rd toes as far as oligo- or monodactyl feet.

A condition in which middle parts of the hand (fingers and metacarpals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic middle fingers over absent middel fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands.
A disorder of bone growth affecting the vertebrae and the ends of the long bones (epiphyses).
Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the vertebra.
Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the fifth lumbar vertebral body (L5) onto the sacrum (level S1).
Spondylolysis is an osseous defect of the pars interarticularis, thought to be a developmental or acquired stress fracture secondary to chronic low-grade trauma.
A congenital skeletal deformity characterized by the elevation of one scapula (thus, one scapula is located superior to the other).

Term textual definition: Spurred metaphyses of the upper limbs
column5: Espuelas en las metáfisis de los miembros superiores

Spanish Translation: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

Three ossification sites are present in typical vertebral bodies (C3-L5): a single ossification center in the vertebral body, and one each in the two neural arches. This term applies if there are additional vertebral ossification centers present during the development and maturation of the spine.

Term textual definition: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
Spanish Translation: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke.

Webbing or fusion of the fingers or toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are revered to as "bony" syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers or toes in a proximo-distal axis are refered to as "symphalangism".

Term textual definition: Synostosis involving bones of the fingers
Spanish Translation: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term "symphalangism of the hand" may be translated as fusions of bones of varying digree, that involve at least one phalangeal bone of the hand. If bony fusions are revered to as "Symphalangism" the fusion occurs in a proximo-distal axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a radio-ulnar axis are refered to as "bony" Syndactyly.
