An abnormality of fear/anxiety-related behavior, which may relate to either abnormally reduced fear/anxiety-related response or increased fear/anxiety-related response.
Any structural anomaly of the `hypothalamus` (FMA:62008).
An abnormal `functionality` (PATO:0001509) of the `hypothalamus` (FMA:62008).
An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs) in the leg.
column5: Alteración en potenciales evocados de miembros inferiores

Term textual definition: Abnormal metabolic brain imaging by MRS
Spanish Translation: An anomaly of metabolism in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
column5: Alteración metabólica en imagen cerebral por espectrometría de resonancia magnética nuclear

Spanish Translation: An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs). MEPs are measured following single-pulse or repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation and can be used for the assessment of the excitability of the motor cortex and the integrity of conduction along the central and peripheral motor pathways.
Any anomaly in the process by which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons.
An abnormality of the function of the electrical signals with which nerve cells communicate with each other or with muscles.
A structural anomaly of a neuron.
An abnormality of the myelination of peripheral neuronal axons and dendrites.
Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs.

Abnormality of REM sleep. Phases of REM sleep are characterized by desynchronized EEG patterns, increases in heart rate and blood pressure, sympathetic activation, and a profound loss of muscle tonus except for the eye and middle-ear muscles. There are then phases of rapid eye movements.
column5: Trastorno del sueño rem ("rapid eye movements" o movimientos oculares rápidos)

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of  actions or reactions of a person taking place during interactions with others.
An abnormal regulation of the sweat glands by the sympathetic nervous system associated with abnormal perspiration.

An anomaly in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse. This is a four step process, comprising (i) synthesis and storage of neurotransmitters; (ii) neurotransmitter release; (iii) activation of postsynaptic receptors by the neurotransmitter; and (iv) inactivation of the neurotransmitter. Thus, this term is defined as an anomaly of `neurotransmitter metabolic process` (GO:0042133).
A deviation from normal signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus.
column5: Alteración en la intensidad de la señal del tálamo en la resonancia magnética nuclear

Spanish Translation: Deviation from the normal range of size of the `thalamus` (FMA:62007).
An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs) in the arm.
column5: Alteración en potenciales evocados motores de miembros superiores

Spanish Translation: A structural abnormality of the `brain` (FMA:50801), which has as its parts the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain.
An anomaly of the `brainstem` (FMA:79876).
column5: Alteración de la morfología del tallo cerebral

Spanish Translation: Any anomaly of the conduction of motor nerve impulses in the central nervous system.
column5: Alteración en la conducción motora central

Spanish Translation: An anomaly of the control or production of movement in the central nervous system.
column5: Alteración de la función motora central

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of cortical sensation. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function usually indicates a lesion of a parietal cortex or of the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex.
column5: Alteración en la función sensorial central

Term textual definition: Abnormality of central somatosensory evoked potentials
column5: Alteración en potenciales evocados somatosensoriales centrales

Spanish Translation: An anomaly of a cerebral artery. The cerebral arteries comprise three main pairs of arteries and their branches, which supply the cerebrum of the brain. These are the `anterior cerebral artery` (FMA:50028), the `middle cerebral artery` (FMA:50079), and the `posterior cerebral artery` (FMA:50583).
An anomaly of `cerebral veins` (FMA:70861).
An anomaly of the `circle of Willis` (FMA:50454), also known as the cerebral arterial circle.

A neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia (inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily), muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement), chorea (widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible, rapid, jerky, and restless nature), athetosis (inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, or other group of muscles in a fixed position), and akathisia (inability to remain motionless).
column5: Alteración en la función motora extrapiramidal

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `forebrain` (FMA:61992), which has as its parts the telencephalon, diencephalon, lateral ventricles and third ventricle.
column5: Alteración en la morfología del cerebro anterior o proencéfalo

Spanish Translation: Cognitive, psychiatric or memory anomaly.
column5: Alteración en las funciones mentales superiores

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `hindbrain` (FMA:67687), also known as the rhombencephalon.
column5: Alteración en la morfología del cerebro posterior o romboencéfalo

Spanish Translation: A deviation from the norm of the intracranial pressure.
An abnormality of the `midbrain` (FMA:61993), which has as its parts the tectum, cerebral peduncle, midbrain tegmentum and cerebral aqueduct.
column5: Alteración en la morfología del cerebro medio o mesencéfalo

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements.
A structural anomaly of the `nervous system` (FMA:7157).
column5: Alteración en la morfología del sistema nervioso

Spanish Translation: A functional anomaly of the `nervous system` (FMA:7157).
column5: Alteración en la fisiología del sistema nervioso

Spanish Translation: An abnormality resulting from an anomaly of neuronal migration, i.e., of the process by which neurons travel from their origin to their final position in the brain.

Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain.
column5: Alteración en la sensación de dolor

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the conduction of electrical impulses by peripheral (motor or sensory) nerves. This finding is elicited by a nerve conduction study (NCS).
column5: Alteración en la conducción nerviosa periférica

Term textual definition: Abnormality of peripheral somatosensory evoked potentials
column5: Alteración en potenciales evocados somatosensoriales periféricos

Spanish Translation: Functional neurological abnormalities related to dysfunction of the `pyramidal tract` (FMA:72634).
column5: Alteración en la función motora piramidal

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP), i.e., of the electrical signals of sensation going from the body to the brain in response to a defined stimulus. Recording electrodes are placed over the scalp, spine, and peripheral nerves proximal to the stimulation site. Clinical studies generally use electrical stimulation of peripheral nerves to elicit potentials. SSEP testing determines whether peripheral sensory nerves are able to transmit sensory information like pain, temperature, and touch to the brain. Abnormal SSEPs can result from dysfunction at the level of the peripheral nerve, plexus, spinal root, spinal cord, brain stem, thalamocortical projections, or primary somatosensory cortex.
An abnormality of the `thalamus` (FMA:62007).
column5: Alteración en la morfología del tálamo

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the anterior horn cell
Spanish Translation: Any anomaly of the `anterior horn cell` (CL:0000100).
column5: Alteración de las células del cuerno anterior de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `Arachnoid mater` (FMA:9591).
An abnormality of `astrocytes` (CL:0000127).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `autonomic nervous system` (FMA:9905).
Abnormality of the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the brainstem white matter
Spanish Translation: An anomaly of the `white matter of brainstem` (FMA:282112).
column5: Anomalía de la sustancia blanca del tallo cerebral

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `caudate nucleus` (FMA:61833).

An anomaly of the `cerebellar peduncles` (FMA:77791). The superior, middle, and inferior cerebellar peduncles emerge from the cerebellum. The superior cerebellar penduncles connect the cerebellum to the midbrain, the middle cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the pons, and the inferior cerebellar peduncle connects the medulla spinalis and medulla oblongata with the cerebellum.
An anomaly of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).
An abnormality of the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944).
An abnormality of the `cerebral cortex` (FMA:61830).
An abnormality of the `cerebral subcortex` (FMA:242188).
Abnormality of the `cerebral ventricles` (FMA:275917).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the cerebral white matter
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `cerebral white matter` (FMA:241998).
column5: Anomalía de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)` (FMA:20935).
An abnormality of the `telencephalon` (FMA:62000), which is also known as the cerebrum.
An abnormality of the `choroid plexus` (FMA:61934), which is the area in the cerebral ventricles in which cerebrospinal fluid is produced by modified ependymal cells.
Abnormality of the `corpus callosum` (FMA:86464).
Abnormality of the corticospinal tract, which is the chief element of the pyramidal system (the principle motor tract) and is the only direct connection between the cerebrum and the spinal cord.
Abnormality affecting one or more of the `cranial nerves` (FMA:5865), which emerge directly from the brain stem.
An abnormality of the `dentate nucleus` (FMA:72260).
An abnormality of the `Diencephalon` (FMA:62001), which together with the cerebrum (telencephalon) makes up the forebrain.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the dorsal columns, i.e., of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. The dorsal column consists of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus and itself is part of the dorsal funiculus.
column5: Anomalía de la columna dorsal de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `Dura mater` (FMA:9592).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the `eleventh cranial nerve` (FMA:6720).

An abnormality of the enteric nervous system, which comprises two types of ganglia, the myenteric (Auerbach's) and submucosal (Meissner's) plexuses. The enteric nervous system functions to control gut movement, fluid exchange between the gut and its lumen, and local blood flow.
An abnormality of the `Falx cerebri` (FMA:83967).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the fifth cranial nerve
Spanish Translation: An abormality of the `fifth cranial nerve` (FMA:50866).
column5: Anomalía del v par craneal o trigémino

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `fourth ventricle` (FMA:78469).
An abnormality of the `glia cell` (CL:0000125).
An abnormality of the `globus pallidus` (FMA:61835).
An anomaly of the `internal capsule` (FMA:61950), which is an area of white matter in the brain that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the lower motor neuron
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `lower motor neuron` (FMA:84632).
An abnormality of the `medulla oblongata` (FMA:62004), the lower half of the brainstem.
column5: Anomalía de la médula oblongada o bulbo raquídeo

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `Meninges` (FMA:231572), including any abnormality of the `Dura mater` (FMA:9592), the `Arachnoid mater` (FMA:9591), and the `Pia mater` (FMA:9590).
An abnormality of the `metencephalon` (FMA:62003). The metencephalon is the part of the hindbrain that consists of the pons and the cerebellum.
An abnormality of the `microglial cells` (CL:0000129). They are also known as brain-resident macrophages or hortega cells.
An abnormality of the `nervous system` (FMA:7157).
Any abnormality of the neuromuscular junction, which is the synapse between the motor end plate of a motor neuron and the skeletal muscle fibers.

One of the three types of glia cells that, with the nerve cells, compose the central nervous system and are characterized by sheetlike processes that wrap around individual axons to form the myelin sheath of nerve fibers.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the peripheral nervous system
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `peripheral nervous system` (FMA:9903), which is composed of the nerves that lead to or branch off from the central nervous system.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the periventricular white matter
column5: Anomalía de la sustancia blanca periventricular

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `Pia mater` (FMA:9590).
An abnormality of the `pons` (FMA:67943).
column5: Anomalía del de la protuberancia o puente cerebral

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `septum pellucidum` (FMA:61844), which is a thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the lateral ventricles of the brain.
column5: Anomalía del septum pellucidum o septo pelúcido

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve
Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the `seventh cranial nerve` (FMA:50868) sometimes also referred to as the facial nerve.
column5: Anomalía del VII par craneal o nervio facial

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `abducens nerve` (FMA:50867).
column5: Anomalía del VI par craneal o abducente

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `spinal cord` (FMA:7647) (myelon).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the spinal dura mater
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the spinal dura mater, which is the outermost of the three layers of the meninges surrounding the spinal cord.
column5: Anomalía de la duramadre de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: Any abnormality of the spinal meninges, the system of membranes (dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater) which envelops the spinal cord.
column5: Anomalía de las meninges de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the spinocerebellar tracts, a set of axonal fibers originating in the spinal cord and terminating in the ipsilateral cerebellum. The spinocerebellar tract convey information to the cerebellum about limb and joint position (proprioception). They comprise the ventral spinocerebellar tract (FMA:72642), the anterior spinocerebellar tract (FMA:72642), and the posterior spinocerebellar tract (FMA:72641).
Abnormality of the striatum (FMA:77618).
Abnormality in the space in the meninges beneath the arachnoid membrane and above the pia mater that contains the cerebrospinal fluid.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the superior cerebellar peduncle
Spanish Translation: An anomaly of the `superior cerebellar peduncle` (FMA:72495).
An abnormality of the `third ventricle` (FMA:78454 ).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the `twelfth cranial nerve` (FMA:50871).
column5: Anomalía del xii par craneal o nervio hipogloso

Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the `vestibulocochlear nerve` (FMA:50869), the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain.
column5: Anomalía del viii par craneal o nervio vestíbulococlear

Spanish Translation: A complete loss of the ability to perceive vibration.
column5: Abolición de la sensación de vibración

Term textual definition: Absence of the third cerebral ventricle
Spanish Translation: A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the `Third ventricle` (FMA:78454).
Recurrent absence seizures are `generalized seizures` (HP:0002197) and are characterized by a loss of consciousness, thus, are a form of `dialeptic seizures` (HP:0011146).
Absence seizures that are additionally characterized by eyelid myoclonia.
column5: Crisis de ausencia con mioclonías del párpado

Spanish Translation: Absence seizures that are characterized by additional motor phenomena such as eyelid myoclonias or myoclonic seizure of the upper limbs.
column5: Crisis de ausencia con otras características especiales

Spanish Translation: Absence of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can normally be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.
Lack of measurable response to stimulation of auditory evoked potentials.
column5: Ausencia de respuesta en los potenciales auditivos del tallo cerebral

Spanish Translation: Agenesis of the midbrain.
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella.
Absence of the `septum pellucidum` (FMA:61844).
column5: Ausencia del septum pelucidum o septo pelúcido

Spanish Translation: Complete lack of development of speech and language abilities.
Poverty of behavior and speech output, lack of initiative, loss of emotional responses, psychomotor slowing, and prolonged speech latency.
A tremor present when the limbs are active, either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement.
Acute progressive areflexic weakness and mild sensory changes resulting from myelin breakdown and axonal degeneration.
Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla.
Affective auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
An abnormality resulting from a lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) that results in bowel obstruction with enlargement of the colon.
A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the small intestine.
Congenital absence of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).

Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.
Aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression, physical aggression against objects, physical aggression against people, and may also include aggression towards oneself.

Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions.
A type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places, especially where crowds gather.
Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination).
Presence of abundant argyrophilic grains and coiled bodies on microscopic examination of brain tissue.
column5: Cuerpos de inclusión argirófilos o de pick

Spanish Translation: Inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily.
Akinetic mutism is essentially characterized by a total absence of spontaneous behavior and speech occurring in the presence of preserved visual tracking.
An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read.
Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain.
A type of holoprosencephaly characterized by the presence of a single ventricle and no separation of the cerebral hemisphere. The single midline ventricle is often greatly enlarged.
EEG dominated by diffuse alpha-waves (8-13Hz).
column5: EEG con predominancia de ondas alfa

Spanish Translation: A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads.
Congenital absence of the spinal cord.
The presence of `amyloid deposition` (MPATH:34) in the nerves of the `peripheral nervous system` (FMA:9903).
A defect in the motor ability that enables speech.
Inability to experience pleasure  activities usually found enjoyable.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward.
Cerebral hemorrhage that occurs before birth.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the `anterior cerebral artery` (FMA:50028).
column5: Estenosis de la arteria cerebral anterior

Spanish Translation: Feeling or dread, apprehension, and impending disaster.
Lack of emotion or emotional expression; a disorder of motivation that persists over time.
A developmental defect characterized by `aplasia` (MPATH:58) of the `Falx cerebri` (FMA:83967).

Term textual definition: Aplasia of the inferior half of the cerebellar vermis
column5: Aplasia de la mitad inferior del vermis cerebeloso

Term textual definition: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the central nervous system
Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of tissue in the central nervous system.
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia que afecta el sistema nervioso central
Aplasia / hipoplasia de los tractos corticoespinales

Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).

Term textual definition: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cerebral white matter
Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of the `cerebral white matter` (FMA:241998).
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of the `corpus callosum` (FMA:86464).
A defect in the understanding of complex motor commands and in the execution of certain learned movements, i.e., deficits in the cognitive components of learned movements.

Stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct (also known as the mesencephalic duct, aqueductus mesencephali, or aqueduct of Sylvius), which connects the third cerebral ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle, which is between the pons and cerebellum.
An extra-parenchymal and intra-arachnoidal collection of fluid with a composition similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid.
Absence of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the lower limbs.
Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the upper limbs.

Arnold-Chiari malformation consists of a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum, sometimes causing hydrocephalus as a result of obstruction of CSF outflow.

Arnold-Chiari type I malformation refers to a relatively mild degree of herniation of the posteroinferior region of the cerebellum (the cerebellar tonsils) into the cervical canal with little or no displacement of the fourth ventricle.
Arteriosclerosis (increased thickness, increased stiffness, loss of elasticity) of the small arteries of the brain.

Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on based on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit.
A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints.
Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of `glioma` (HP:0009733).
Proliferation of `astrocytes` (CL:0000127) in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system.
A type of `dyssynergy` (HP:0010867) characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed.

Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- oder overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).
A type of cerebral palsy characterized by slow, involuntary muscle movement and mixed muscle tone.

Athetosis (from the Greek word for 'changeable' or 'unfixed') refers to an inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, tongue, or any other group of muscles in a fixed position. Instead, posture is interrupted by slow, purposeless involuntary movements.
Seizures characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone, which may be fragmentary, confined to a segment (limb, jaw, head), or massive, leading to a slumping to the ground .

Term textual definition: Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system
column5: Atrofia / degeneración del sistema nervioso central

Spanish Translation: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the `cerebrum` (FMA:62000), also known as the telencephalon, the largest and most highly developed part of the human brain.

column5: Atrofia / degeneración de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) manifests at age 2-3 years or by first grade at the latest. The main symptoms are distractibility, impulsivity, hyperactivity, and often trouble organizing tasks and projects, difficulty going to sleep, and social problems from being aggressive, loud, or impatient.
column5: Trastorno de hiperactividad y déficit de atención

Spanish Translation: Absence seizures characterized by insidious begin and end and often prolonged duration, accompanied by slow spike-wave discharges on EEG.
Auras with sensations of buzzing, drumming sounds or single tones.
Subjective ictal phenomena that, in a given patient, may precede observable seizures; if alone, constitute a if alone, constitute a simple partial seizure.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV).

A disorder beginning in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV).
Abnormal bladder function (increased urge or frequency of urination or urge incontinence) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
An abnormality of the regulation of the `autonomic nervous system` (FMA:9905).
Impotence (inability to develop or maintain an erection) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
A type of dystonia that affects the midline muscles, i.e., the chest, abdominal, and back muscles.
A pattern of simultaneous degeneration and regeneration of axons (see comment).
A reduction in the number of axons in the peripheral nervous system.
The presence of axonal regeneration following a previous axonal lesion.

Upturning of the big toe (and sometimes fanning of the other toes) in response to stimulation of the sole of the foot. If the Babinski sign is present it can indicate damage to the corticospinal tract.
The presence of `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) affecting one or more structures of the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).
The presence of `gliosis` (MPATH:182) in the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).
Death of cells in the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).
A type of `onion bulb formation` (HP:0003383) prominently affecting the area of the basal lamina.
column5: Formación de la lámina basal en forma de "bulbos de cebolla"

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of mental functioning including various affective, behavioural, cognitive and perceptual abnormalities.

Term textual definition: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
column5: Tumor benigno del sistema nervioso central

Spanish Translation: EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz).

column5: Lesiones bilaterales de los ganglios basales

Spanish Translation: Bilateral convulsive seizures are focal seizure with secondary bilateral motor phenomena, not primary generalized seizures.
Deposition of calcium salts on both sides of the brain.
Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in both hemispheres.
A bilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
Mirror hand movements.

A personality disorder characterized by impulsive behavior and unpredictable and capricious mood. Affected individuals show a liability to outbursts of emotion and an incapacity to control the behavioural explosions.

Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement).
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of brain tissue that was once present.

A developmental structural anomaly of the stalk-like part of the brain that comprises the midbrain (aka mesencephalon), the pons (aka pons Varolii), and the medulla oblongata, and connects the cerebral hemispheres with the cervical spinal cord.
A `glioma` (HP:0009733) affecting the `brainstem` (FMA:79876).
An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia.
column5: Marcha con polígono de sustentación amplio

Spanish Translation: Bruxism is characterized by the grinding of the teeth including the clenching of the jaw and typically occur during sleep.

Bulbar weakness (or bulbar palsy) refers to bilateral impairment of function of the lower cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII, which occurs due to lower motor neuron lesion either at nuclear or fascicular level in the medulla or from bilateral lesions of the lower cranial nerves outside the brain-stem. Bulbar weakness is often associated with difficulty in chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.

A form of anomalous eating behavior characterized by binge eating is followed by self-induced vomiting or other compensatory behavior intended to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting or exercising or a combination of these).
A loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
Increased amount of myelin in the central nervous system.
Reduced amount of myelin in the central nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis.
An increased lymphocyte count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
An increased white blood cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
An increased polymorphonuclear cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
column5: Pleocitosis a expensas de polimorfonucleares en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Spanish Translation: The presence of `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) in the `falx cerebri` (FMA:83967).

Term textual definition: Calcification of the small brain vessels
Spanish Translation: Deposition of calcium salts within small blood vessels of the brain.
A paraganglioma (a  neuroendocrine neoplasm) originating in a carotid artery.
A sudden and transient episode of bilateral loss of muscle tone, often triggered by emotions.
The formation of small cavities in the tissue of the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).

If the two laminae of the septum pellucidum are not fused then a fluid-filled space or cavum is present. The cavum septum pellucidum is present at birth but usually obliterates by the age of 3 to 6 months. It is up to 1cm in width and the walls are parallel. It is an enclosed space and is not part of the ventricular system or connected with the subarachnoid space.
Reduced muscle tone secondary to an abnormality of the central nervous system.
Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles.
Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the Purkinje cell layer.
column5: Atrofia de la lámina de Purkinje del cerebelo

Spanish Translation: Lack of development of the cerebellum.

Term textual definition: Cerebellar ataxia associated with quadrupedal gait
Spanish Translation: The presence of cerebellar signs and symptoms such as lack of balance associated with quadrupedal gait (locomotion on all four extremities with a 'bear-like' gait with the legs held straight).
column5: Ataxia cerebelosa asociada a marcha cuadrúpeda

Spanish Translation: Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellum`(FMA:67944).
Atrophy (wasting) of the `cerebellar cortex` (FMA:72248).
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944).
A `glioma` (HP:0009733) affecting the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944).
The presence of `gliosis` (MPATH:182) in the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944).
Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the granular cell layer.
column5: Atrofia de la capa granular del cerebelo

Spanish Translation: A 'hemangioblastoma` (HP:0010797) of the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944).

column5: Hipoplasia de un hemisferio del cerebelo

Spanish Translation: `Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.
Underdevelopment of the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944).
Wasting (atrophy) of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).
Underdevelopment of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).
An arachnoid cyst located at the margin of the cerebellum and pons.
The presence of a localized dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
Atherosclerosis (HP:0002621) of a cerebral artery.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of a cerebral artery.
Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the cerebrum.
A sac-like aneurysm (outpouching) of a cerebral blood vessel.
column5: Aneurisma cerebral sacular o en forma de baya

Spanish Translation: The presence of `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) within brain structures.
Atrophy of the cortex of the cerebrum.

Atrophy of one side of the brain, characterized by findings including   thinning of the cerebral cortex, reduced volume of the cerebral white matter with r abnormal myelination, and enlargement of the ispilateral fourth ventricle.
Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths of the white matter of the brain.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the brain.

Cerebral inflammation involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells.
The presence of a `hamartoma` (HP:0010566) of the `cerebrum` (FMA:62000).
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) into the parenchyma of the `brain` (FMA:50801).
Cerebral eosinophilic, discrete, intracytoplasmatic inclusions of unknown significance.
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the white matter of the central nervous system.
Underdevelopment of the cerebrum.
Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates of stainable substances within cells of the brain.

Cerebral palsy describes a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitation, that are attributed to nonprogressive disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain. The motor disorders of cerebral palsy are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition, communication, and behaviour, by epilepsy, and by secondary musculoskeletal problems.
Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.

A congenital malformation of veins which drain normal brain characterized by a caput medusae or an umbrellalike convergence of multiple venules on a single, or occasionally multiple, enlarged parenchymal or medullary vein, like the trunk of a tree or the shank of an umbrella. This dilated terminal vein penetrates the cortex to drain either (a) superficially to cortical veins or sinuses, (b) deeply to subependymal veins of the lateral ventricle and then into the galenic system, (c) to the fourth ventricle and then to the pontomesencephalic vein, or (d) to the precentral cerebellar vein and into the galenic system.
Congenital defect with failure of the development of the `cerebral white matter` (FMA:241998).
column5: Agenesia de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the cerebral white matter.
column5: Atrofia de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the `cerebral white matter` (FMA:241998).
column5: Hipoplasia de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: Compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region, generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness, weakness, difficulty walking, abnormalities of coordination, and neck pain or stiffness.
column5: Compresión de la médula espinal a nivel cervical

Spanish Translation: Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord.
column5: Atrofia de la médula espinal a nivel cervical

Spanish Translation: A diagnostic reflex elicited by stimulation of the skin over the surface of the lateral malleolus of the foot. The Chaddock refelx is present if there is extension of one or more or all of the toes with or without fanning of them when the external inframalleolar skin is stimulated. The Chaddock sign, similar to the Babinski sign, is taken to be an indication of disease of the spinocortical (pyramidal) tract.
Involuntary and irregular twitches of the chin.
Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion.
Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).
The presence of `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) in the `choroid plexus` (FMA:61934).
A cyst occurring within the `choroid plexus` (FMA:61934) within a cerebral ventricle.
`Choroid plexus papilloma` (MPATH:246) is a histologically benign `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) located in the ventricular system of the `choroid plexus` (FMA:61934).
Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter.
An abnormality characterized by chronic impairment of  the normal functioning of the axons.
Subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation that persists for six months or longer.
Persistent pain, usually defined as pain that has laster longer than 3 to 6 months.
A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch.
Lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects.
A type of headache characterized by repeated attacks of unilateral pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes and associated with local autonomic signs.
Abnormality in the process of thought including the ability to process information.

column5: Rigidez o espasticidad en rueda dentada

Spanish Translation: Complete absence of wakefulness and content of conscience, which manifests itself as a lack of response to any kind of external stimuli.
A form of `hydrocephalus` (HP:0000238) in which there is no visible obstruction to the flow of the cerebrospinal fluid between the ventricles and subarachnoid space.
Febrile seizures with focal semiology, duration of more than 15 minutes, or occurring in a cluster of 2 or more convulsions within 24 hours.
Lack of clarity and coherence of thought, perception, understanding, or action.
The presence of `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) within brain structures that is present already at the time of birth.
An unusually happy aspect over time which can also may be observed during inappropriate situations that should be causing for example distress, fear or anger.

Injury to the median nerve caused by its entrapment at the wrist as it traverses through the carpal tunnel. Clinically, constrictive median neuropathy is characterized by pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the median nerve distribution of the hand.
column5: Neuropatía del nervio mediano por compresión

Spanish Translation: An anomalous build up of copper (Cu) in the `brain` (FMA:50801).
column5: Acumulación de cobre en el cerebro

Spanish Translation: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the corpus callosum.
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `cerebral cortex` (FMA:61830).
An abnormal reduction of the number and complexity of the pattern of gyrations of the cerebral cortex.

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients.

Term textual definition: Corticospinal tract disease in lower limbs
column5: Enfermedad del tracto corticoespinal que afecta miembros inferiores

Spanish Translation: A functional deficit of the tract that conveys nervous impulses from the motor cortex of the brain to the spinal cord. The corticospinal tract mediates discrete voluntary skilled movements.

column5: Parálisis del vi par craneal o abducente
Pérdida de la función motora de un par craneal

Spanish Translation: A form of focal dystonia affecting the face, head or neck muscles.
An increase in size of the `third ventricle` (FMA:78454).
A type of `seizure` (HP:0001250) characterized by crying or an outburst of crying as a major feature.
A type of rigidity in which the arms are in flexion and adduction and the legs are extended. This signifies a lesion in the cerebral white matter, internal capsules, or thalamus.
Decreased intensity of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.
Decreased concentration of homovanillic acid (HVA) in the cerebrospinal fluid. HVA is a metabolite of dopamine.
column5: Disminución de ácido homovanílico (hva) en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Term textual definition: Decreased amplitude of sensory action potentials
Spanish Translation: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies.
column5: Disminución en la amplitud de los potenciales de acción sensitivos

Term textual definition: Decreased distal sensory nerve action potential
Spanish Translation: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential in distal nerve segments. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies.
column5: Disminución en el potencial de acción sensitivo del nervio a nivel distal

Spanish Translation: A reduction of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid.
An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction.
column5: Disminución en los potenciales de acción de la placa terminal pequeña

Spanish Translation: A type of decreased nerve conduction velocity that affects the `motor neuron` (FMA:83617).
column5: Disminución en la velocidad de conducción motora nerviosa

Spanish Translation: A reduction in the speed at which electrical signals propagate along the axon of a `neuron` (FMA:54527).
column5: Disminución en la velocidad de conducción nerviosa

Term textual definition: Decreased number of large peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
Spanish Translation: A reduced number of large myelinated nerve fibers.
column5: Disminución en el número de fibras nerviosas mielinizadas periféricas grandes

Term textual definition: Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
Spanish Translation: A loss of myelinated nerve fibers in the peripheral nervous system (in general, this finding can be observed on nerve biopsy).
column5: Disminución en el número de fibras nerviosas mielinizadas periféricas

Term textual definition: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
column5: Disminución en el número de fibras nerviosas mielinizadas periféricas pequeñas

Spanish Translation: Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).
Reduced speed of conduction of the action potential along a sensory nerve.
column5: Disminución de la velocidad de conducción sensitiva nerviosa

Spanish Translation: A reduction in the size of nerve terminals.
column5: Disminución en el tamaño de las terminales nerviosas

Spanish Translation: A reduction in the quantity of space occupied by the `thalamus` (FMA:62007).

column5: Disminución / ausencia de los reflejos del tobillo

Spanish Translation: Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the deep cerebral white matter.
column5: Hipodensidades de la sustancia blanca profunda

Spanish Translation: Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. Nonword repetition (NWR) is a measure of short-term phonological memory.

column5: Déficit en la memoria fonológica de corto plazo
Degeneración de las células del asta anterior

Term textual definition: Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts
Spanish Translation: Deterioration of the tissues of the `lateral corticospinal tracts` (FMA:72635).
column5: Degeneración de los tractos corticoespinales laterales

Spanish Translation: A subjective feeling that an experience which is occurring for the first time has been experienced before.
column5: Deja vu o fenómeno de lo "ya visto"

Spanish Translation: `Delayed` (PATO:0000502) `myelination` (GO:0042552) in the central nervous system.
column5: Retraso en la mielinización del sistema nervioso central

Spanish Translation: A type of `motor delay` (HP:0001270) characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands.
column5: Retraso en el desarrollo de la motricidad fina

Spanish Translation: A type of `motor delay` (HP:0001270) characterized by an delay in acquiring the ability to control the large muscles of the body for walking, running, sitting, and crawling.
column5: Retraso en el desarrollo de la motricidad gruesa

Spanish Translation: `Delayed` (PATO:0000502) `myelination` (GO:0042552).
`Delayed` (PATO:0000502) `myelination` (GO:0042552) in the peripheral nervous system.
A failure to meet one or more age-related milestones of social behavior.
A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age.
column5: Retraso del lenguaje y la comunicación

Spanish Translation: A belief that is pathological and is held despite evidence to the contrary.

A loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function. Dementia represents a loss of previously present cognitive abilities, generally in adults, and can affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior.
Demyelination of peripheral motor nerves.
Demyelinating neuropathy is characterized by slow nerve conduction velocities with reduced amplitudes of sensory/motor nerve conduction and prolonged distal latencies.
Demyelination of peripheral sensory nerves.

Term textual definition: Dense calcifications in the cerebellar dentate nucleus
column5: Calcificaciones densas en el núcleo dentado del cerebelo

Spanish Translation: A condition characterized by pervasive dysphoric mood, loss of interests, and inability to experience pleasure.
Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.
A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills.

Term textual definition: Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures
Spanish Translation: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills, following the onset of epilepsy.
column5: Estancamiento del desarrollo al inicio de cuadro convulsivo

Spanish Translation: Seizures characterized by impaired consciousness.
Coexistence of two hemicords, at variable levels, causing splaying of the posterior vertebral elements. Results in neurological deficits in lower limb or perineum.
Reduced ability to walk (ambulate).
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebellum.
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebrum.
Generalized deposition of calcium salts within the brain.

Term textual definition: Diffuse demyelination of the cerebral white matter
Spanish Translation: A diffuse loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
column5: Desmielinización difusa de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: A diffuse loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.

Term textual definition: Diffuse swelling of cerebral white matter
column5: Edema difuso de la sustancia blanca cerebral
Anomalías difusas de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: An abnormal dilatation of the `fourth cerebral ventricle` (FMA:78469).
A reduction in goal-directed behavior, that is, motivation, the determinant of behavior and adaptation that allows individuals to get started, be energized to perform a sustained and directed action.
Duplication of the spinal cord.
A lack of restraint manifested in several ways, including disregard for social conventions, impulsivity, and poor risk assessment.

Term textual definition: Disorganization of the anterior cerebellar vermis

Spanish Translation: A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa.
Peripheral sensory neuropathy affecting primarily distal sensation.
An abnormal reduction in sensation in the distal portions of the extremities.

Term textual definition: Distal sensory impairment of all modalities
column5: Discapacidad sensitiva distal que incluye todas las modalidades

Term textual definition: Distal sensory loss of all modalities
column5: Pérdida sensitiva distal que incluye todas las modalidades

Spanish Translation: Excessive daytime sleepiness.
A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the duodenum.
A widening or ballooning of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord usually at the lumbosacral level.

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed.
`Dysfunction` (PATO:0001641) of the `autonomic nervous system` (FMA:9905).
A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic.

A type of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as rhythmically tapping the fingers on the knee, generally related to a cerebellar lesion.
Abnormal sensations with no apparent physical cause that are painful or unpleasant.
Defective development of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).

A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment.
A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.

A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent).

A type of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements.
A structural anomaly of the inferior portion of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).
Difficulty in swallowing.
An impairment in the ability to produce voice sounds.

Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium.

A type of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts.
An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.
Abnormality observed by electroencephalogram (EEG), which is used to record of the brain's spontaneous electrical activity from multiple electrodes placed on the scalp.
EEG background activity at 4-5/second.
column5: EEG con actividad de fondo de 4-5/ segundos

Spanish Translation: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies.

The burst suppression pattern in electroencephalography refers to a characteristic periodic pattern of low voltage (<10 microvolts) suppressed background and a relatively shorter pattern of higher amplitude slow, sharp, and spiking complexes.
column5: EEG con trazado de supresión de actividad

Term textual definition: EEG with central focal spike waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the central region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas pico focales centrales

Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the central region.

Term textual definition: EEG with central sharp slow waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp slow waves in the central region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas lentas afiladas centrales

Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp waves in the central region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

Term textual definition: EEG with centrotemporal focal spike waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the centrotemporal region of the brain (also known as the central sulcus), i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas pico focales centrotemporales

Spanish Translation: EEG with abnormal amplitude.
column5: EEG con cambios en el voltaje

Spanish Translation: An EEG with constitutional variants contains waves that are rare or unusual but not generally pathologic.
EEG showing diffuse slowing without interruption.
EEG frequency is abnormally increased.
EEG discharges recorded in particular areas of the A localized (focal) abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

Term textual definition: EEG with focal sharp slow waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas lentas afiladas focales

Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
Focal (localized) slow activity reflects focal dysfunction, not diffuse dysfunction (i.e., encephalopathy).
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.

Term textual definition: EEG with frontal focal spike waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the frontal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas pico focales frontales

Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the frontal region.

Term textual definition: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp slow waves in the frontal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas lentas afiladas frontales

Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp waves in the frontal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
EEG discharges recorded on the entire scalp typically seen in persons with epilepsy.

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized low amplitude activity
Spanish Translation: An abnormal generalized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
column5: EEG con actividad generalizada de baja amplitud

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized polymorphic epileptiform discharges
Spanish Translation: Generalized epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies.
column5: EEG con descargas epileptiformes polimórficas generalizadas

Spanish Translation: EEG with repetitive generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas lentas afiladas generalizadas

Spanish Translation: Diffuse slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 1
Spanish Translation: Slowing at frequencies between 7.5 and 8.5 Hz.
column5: EEG con actividad lenta generalizada grado 1

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 2
Spanish Translation: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 4-7 Hz.
column5: EEG con actividad lenta generalizada grado 2

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 3
Spanish Translation: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 0.5-3 Hz.
column5: EEG con actividad lenta generalizada grado 3

Term textual definition: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 4
Spanish Translation: EEG without electrical activity.
column5: EEG con actividad lenta generalizada grado 4

Spanish Translation: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.
Epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
column5: EEG con descargas epileptiformes inducidas por hiperventilación

Spanish Translation: Focal epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
column5: EEG con descargas epileptiformes focales inducidas por hiperventilación

Term textual definition: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalized epileptiform discharges
Spanish Translation: Generalized epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
column5: EEG con descargas epileptiformes generalizadas inducidas por hiperventilación

Spanish Translation: Non-continuous diffuse slowing of electroencephalographic patterns.

column5: EEG con espigas generalizadas irregulares y complejos de ondas

column5: EEG con actividad localizada de baja amplitud

Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the occipital region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas pico focales occipitales

Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the occipital region.

Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp slow waves in the occipital region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

column5: EEG con enlentecimiento de la actividad a nivel occipital

Term textual definition: EEG with parietal focal spike waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the parietal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.

Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp slow waves in the parietal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.

column5: EEG con actividad rítmica anormal persistente

column5: EEG con respuesta fotoparoxística grado ii

column5: EEG con respuesta fotoparoxística grado iii

column5: EEG con respuesta fotoparoxística grado iv

Spanish Translation: The presence of complexes of repetitive spikes and waves in EEG.
column5: EEG con complejos de onda poliespiga

Term textual definition: EEG with series of focal spikes
Spanish Translation: Focal spikes occurring for several seconds.
column5: EEG con series de espigas focales

Spanish Translation: The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (2.5-3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).
column5: EEG con complejos punta-onda (2.5 a 3.5 hz)

Spanish Translation: The presence of complexes of slow spikes and slow waves (<2.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).
The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (>3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).

Complexes of spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms), which are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy, in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

Term textual definition: EEG with temporal focal spike waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the parietal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas pico focales temporales

Spanish Translation: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the temporal region.

Term textual definition: EEG with temporal sharp slow waves
Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp slow waves in the temporal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
column5: EEG con ondas afiladas lentas temporales

Spanish Translation: EEG with sharp waves in the temporal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
The presence of spontaneous bursts of rapidly firing potentials that recur at regular intervals of 2-10 per second and are unaffected by voluntary effort. This is an electromyographic (EMG) finding.
Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years.
column5: Crisis de ausencia de aparición temprana

Spanish Translation: Increased susceptibility to fatigue.
The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person.
Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an  exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint.
Increased concentration of `dopamine` (CHEBI:18243) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
column5: Niveles elevados de dopamina en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Term textual definition: Elevated brain choline level by MRS
Spanish Translation: An increase in the level of choline-containing compounds in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
column5: Nivel de colina elevado en cerebro por resonancia magnética nuclear por espectrometría

Term textual definition: Elevated brain lactate level by MRS

column5: Nivel de lactato elevado en cerebro por resonancia magnética nuclear por espectrometría

Spanish Translation: Increased length of the `superior cerebellar peduncle` (FMA:72495).
Encephalopathy is a term that means brain disease, damage, or malfunction. In general, encephalopathy is manifested by an altered mental state.
Increase in amplitude of a long-loop response upon somatosensory evoked potential testing, representing an electrically evoked myoclonic response.
Abnormal increase in size of the brainstem.
column5: Aumento en el tamaño del tallo cerebral

Spanish Translation: An abnormally increased size of the cerebellum compared to other brain structures.
column5: Aumento en el tamaño del cerebelo

Spanish Translation: Increase in size of the cisterna magna, one of three principal openings in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, located between the cerebellum and the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata.
column5: Aumento en el tamaño de la cisterna magna
Aumento en el tamaño de la fosa interpeduncular

Spanish Translation: Increase in size of the `hippocampus` (FMA:62493).
column5: Aumento en el tamaño del hipocampo
Aumento en el tamaño de la fisura interhemisférica

Spanish Translation: Increase in size of a peripheral nerve. This finding can be appreciated by palpation along the axis of the nerve.
column5: Aumento en el tamaño de nervios periféricos

Spanish Translation: An increase in size of the subarachnoid space associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure).
column5: Aumento en el tamaño de la cisterna de Silvio

Spanish Translation: An increase in the quantity of space occupied by the `thalamus` (FMA:62007).
Malfunction of a peripheral nerve resulting from mechanical compression of the nerve roots from internal or external causes and leading to a conduction block or axonal loss.

An entrapment neuropathy of the suprascapular nerve, presenting with shoulder weakness confined to the supraspinatus muscle (this muscle initiates shoulder abduction) or to the infraspinatus (this muscle externally rotates the arm), as well as with pain in the posterior part of the shoulder and upper periscapular region.
column5: Neuropatía por atrapamiento del nervio supraescapular

Term textual definition: Entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve at elbow
Spanish Translation: An entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel (in the elbow) characterized by numbness in the ring and little fingers and weakness of the intrinsic muscles in the hand.
column5: Neuropatía por atrapamiento del nervio cubital a nivel del codo

Spanish Translation: The presence of an `ependymoma` (MPATH:247) of the `central nervous system` (FMA:55675).
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring between the `dura mater` (FMA:9592) and the `skull` (FMA:46565).

Auras with abdominal discomfort including nausea, emptiness, tightness, churning, butterflies, malaise, pain, and hunger; sensation may rise to chest or throat. Some phenomena may reflect ictal autonomic dysfunction.

A form of partial status epilepticus with simple motor manifestations that are maintained for over one hour, with clonic activity restricted to one body part and recurring at fairly regular intervals.
A sudden flexion, extension or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles which is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure.
Electroencephalographic patterns that resemble epileptogenic abnormalities.
Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance.
Intermittent and recurrent bouts of a subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
Transient episodes of weakness of the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.
Intermittent episodes of paralysis of all four limbs.
An exaggerated startle reaction in response to a sudden unexpected visual or acoustic stimulus, or a quick movement near the face.
Affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
An increased amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the subarachnoid space.
Pheochromocytoma not originating from the adrenal medulla but from another source such as from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia.
Muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement).

Term textual definition: Eye of the tiger anomaly of globus pallidus
Spanish Translation: The presence, on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, of markedly low signal intensity if the `globus pallidus` (FMA:61835) that surrounds a central region of high signal intensity in the anteromedial globus pallidus, producing an eye-of-the-tiger appearance.
column5: Anomalía en ojo de tigre del globo pálido

Spanish Translation: Repetitive pressing, poking, and/or rubbing in the eyes.
Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures.
Fasciculations affecting the tongue muscle and the musculature of the face.

Fasciculations are observed as small, local, involuntary muscle contractions (twitching) visible under the skin. Fasciculations result from increased irritability of an axon (which in turn is often a manifestation of disease of a motor neuron). This leads to sporadic discharges of all the muscle fibers controlled by the axon in isolation from other motor units.
A type of weakness that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.

Febrile seizures are convulsions induced by a fever in infants or small children and are generally characterized by loss of consciousness and tonic-clonic movements. Most febrile seizures last a minute or two.
An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others.

Term textual definition: Focal EEG discharges with propagation to ipsilateral hemisphere
Spanish Translation: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to the hemisphere on the same side of the brain.
column5: Descargas focales en el eeg con propagación sobre el hemisferio ipsilateral

Term textual definition: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
Spanish Translation: Focal EEG discharges that secondarily spread to both hemispheres and can then be recorded over the entire scalp.
column5: Descargas generalizadas en el eeg con propagación en ambos hemisferios

Term textual definition: Focal T2 hyperintense basal ganglia lesion
Spanish Translation: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the basal ganglia.
column5: Lesión focal hiperintensa en t2 de los ganglios basales

Spanish Translation: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MIR) of the brainstem. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the brainstem.
column5: Lesión focal hiperintensa en t2 del tallo cerebral

Spanish Translation: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the thalamus.
column5: Lesión focal hiperintensa en t2 del tálamo

Term textual definition: Focal T2 hypointense basal ganglia lesion
Spanish Translation: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a localized hypointensity affecting a particular region of the basal ganglia.
column5: Lesión focal hipointensa en t2 de los ganglios basales

Spanish Translation: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MIR) of the brainstem. This term refers to a localized hypointensity affecting a particular region of the brainstem.
column5: Lesión focal hipointensa en t2 del tallo cerebral

Spanish Translation: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a localized hypointensity affecting a particular region of the thalamus.
column5: Lesión focal hipointensa en t2 del tálamo

Spanish Translation: Focal seizures with an objectively documented and distinct alteration of autonomic nervous system function involving cardiovascular, pupillary, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregularity functions.

Term textual definition: Focal autonomic seizures with altered responsiveness
Spanish Translation: An autonomic seizure with altered responsiveness.
column5: Convulsiones autonómicas focales con respuesta alterada

Term textual definition: Focal autonomic seizures without altered responsiveness
Spanish Translation: An autonomic seizure without altered responsiveness.
column5: Convulsiones autonómicas focales sin respuesta alterada

Spanish Translation: A type of `dystonia` (HP:0001332) that is localized to a specific part of the body.

Term textual definition: Focal epileptiform discharges with limited propagation to contralateral hemisphere
Spanish Translation: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to contralateral hemisphere but without secondary generalization.
column5: Descargas epileptiformes focales con propagación limitada al hemisferio contralateral

Spanish Translation: A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure that affects a particular part of the cortex.
Focal seizures involving musculature in any form.
Seizures of which initial semiology indicates, or is consistent with, initial activation of only part of one cerebral hemisphere.

Term textual definition: Focal seizures with impairment of consciousness or awareness
Spanish Translation: A `partial seizure` (HP:0007359) characterized by impairment or loss of consciousness.
column5: Convulsiones focales con deterioro de la conciencia o el estado de alerta

Term textual definition: Focal seizures without impairment of consciousness or awareness
Spanish Translation: A `partial seizure` (HP:0007359) in which consciousness is maintained.
column5: Convulsiones focales sin deterioro de la conciencia o el estado de alerta

Spanish Translation: Seizures with sustained increase in muscle contraction in parts of the body lasting a few seconds to minutes.

column5: Lesiones focales de la sustancia blanca

Spanish Translation: Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly.
column5: Parálisis del iv par craneal o nervio troclear

Spanish Translation: Atrophy of the `frontal cortex` (FMA:61824).
Primitive reflexes traditionally held to be a sign of disorders that affect the frontal lobes.
A venous angioma of the frontal lobe of the brain.
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `cortex of frontal lobe` (FMA:242199) and the `cortex of parietal lobe` (FMA:242203).
An excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of the brain in the frontoparietal region.
Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the frontotemporal cerebrum.
A dementia associated with degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe and clinically associated with personality and behavioral changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and lack of insight.

Term textual definition: Fusion of the left and right thalami
Spanish Translation: A developmental defect characterized by fusion of the left and right halves of the `thalamus` (FMA:62007).
column5: Fusión de los tálamos izquierdo y derecho

Spanish Translation: Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs.
A type of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) characterized by the impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal walking.

The term gait disturbance can refer to any disruption of the ability to walk. In general, this can refer to neurological diseases but also fractures or other sources of pain that is triggered upon walking. However, in the current context gait disturbance refers to difficulty walking on the basis of a neurological or muscular disease.

Term textual definition: Gait instability, worse in the dark
column5: Inestabilidad en la marcha, empeora en la oscuridad

Spanish Translation: A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum, representing a tumor of the sympathetic nerve fibers arising from neural crest cells.
A type of `seizure` (HP:0001250) characterized by laughing or an outburst of laughing as a major feature.
Generalized atrophy or hypoplasia of the cerebrum.
Seizures with regularly repetitive myoclonus, involving the same muscle groups, at a frequency of about 2-3 c/sec.
A type of `dystonia` (HP:0001332) that affects all or most of the body.

Term textual definition: Generalized hypotonia due to defect at the neuromuscular junction
column5: Hipotonía global debido a un defecto de la unión neuromuscular

Spanish Translation: Seizures with sudden, brief (< 100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal).
Seizures of with initial involvement of both cerebral hemispheres.
Generalized seizures with sustained increase in muscle contraction lasting a few seconds to minutes.

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures are `generalized seizures` (HP:0002197) with bilateral symmetrical tonic contraction then bilateral clonic contractions of somatic muscles usually associated with autonomic phenomena.
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures on awakening are a form of `Generalized tonic-clonic seizures` (HP:0002069) that occur upon awaking.
An abnormal enlargement (i.e. increase in measured voltage) of somatosensory evoked potentials.
