A tumor arising from glia in the central nervous system with macroscopic regions of necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopically, glioblastoma multiforme is characterized by regions of pseudopalisading necrosis, pleomorphic nuclei and cells, and microvascular proliferation.
The presence of a `glioma` (MPATH:249), which is a `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the `central nervous system` (FMA:55675) originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes).
The presence of `gliosis` (MPATH:182) in the `central nervous system` (FMA:55675).
Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size.

A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age.

column5: Trastorno específico del lenguaje con problemas en la gramática

Spanish Translation: Gray matter heterotopia is a neurological disorder caused by clumps of grey matter being located in the wrong part of the brain. It is characterized as a type of cortical malformation. The neurons in heterotopia may appear to be normal, except for their mislocation; nuclear studies have shown glucose metabolism equal to that of normally positioned gray matter. The condition causes a variety of symptoms, but usually includes some degree of epilepsy or recurring seizures, and often affects the brain's ability to function on higher levels. Symptoms range from nonexistent to profound, in which case heterotopia can result in severe seizure disorder, loss of motor skills, and mental retardation.
Auras with taste sensations including acidic, bitter, salty , sweet or metallic tastes.
A phenomenon in which persons repetitively pull out their own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss.
Perceptions in a conscious and awake state in the absence of external stimuli which have qualities of real perception, in that they are vivid, substantial, and located in external objective space.
Auras with creation of composite perceptions without corresponding external stimuli involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory and/or gustatory phenomena.
A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting head movement.
Habitual striking of one's own head against a surface such as a mattress or wall of a crib.
Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.

A `hemangioblastoma` (MPATH:238) is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter.

Hemiballismus is a rare movement disorder that is caused primarily by damage to various areas in the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013). Hemiballismus is usually characterized by involuntary flinging motions of the extremities. The movements are often violent and have wide amplitudes of motion. They are continuous and random and can involve proximal and/or distal muscles on one side of the body, while some cases even include the facial muscles. The more a patient is active, the more the movements increase. With relaxation comes a decrease in movements.
Focal clonic seizures affecting one side of the face.
A segmental myoclonus of muscles innervated by the facial nerve.
Hypsarrhythmia occurring in one hemisphere.
Enlargement of all or parts of one cerebral hemisphere.
Relatively mild weakness in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.

Loss of strength in the arm, leg, and sometimes face on one side of the body. Hemiplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas hemiparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength.

Central nervous system dysfunction in association with liver failure and characterized clinically (depending on degree of severity) by lethargy, confusion, nystagmus, decorticate posturing, spasticity, and bilateral Babinski reflexes.
Intracellular aggregates of actin and actin-associated proteins within nerve cells.

A personality disorder characterized by shallow and labile affectivity, self-dramatization, theatricality, exaggerated expression of emotions, suggestibility, egocentricity, self-indulgence, lack of consideration for others, easily hurt feelings, and continuous seeking for appreciation, excitement and attention.
Holoprosencephaly is a structural anomaly of the brain in which the developing forebrain fails to divide into two separate hemispheres and ventricles.
A defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and glial tissue.

Hydrocephalus is an active distension of the ventricular system of the brain resulting from inadequate passage of CSF from its point of production within the cerebral ventricles to its point of absorption into the systemic circulation.
Dilation of central canal from incomplete fusion of the posterior columns or persistence of the primitive large canal of the embryo.
Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.

Seizures with increase in rate of ongoing movements or inappropriately rapid performance of a movement involving predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrashing, rocking movements.
A tendency or compulsion to examine objects by mouth.
The presence of overactive or overresponsive reflexes.
A headache disorder that occurs exclusively at night, waking the affected individual from sleep.
Hyperexcitability of the neuromuscular system related to abnormally low level of calcium in the blood, resulting in carpopedal or generalized spasms.

Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage.
Abnormally low glucose concentration content in the cerebrospinal fluid.

Term textual definition: Hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
Spanish Translation: A darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter.
column5: Hipointensidad de la sustancia blanca cerebral en la resonancia magnética nuclear

Spanish Translation: Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency.
Seizures with a decrease in amplitude and/or rate or arrest of ongoing motor activity.
Underdevelopment of the `brainstem` (FMA:79876).
Underdevelopment of the corpus callosum.
Underdevelopment of the `frontal lobe` (FMA:61824) of the cerebrum.
Underdevelopment of the `pons` (FMA:67943).
Underdevelopment of the ventral portion of the `pons` (FMA:67943).
Underdeveloped `posterior communicating artery` (FMA:50084).
Reduction of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the upper limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.

column5: Deficiencia de la hormona liberadora de gonadotropina de origen hipotalámico (gnrh)

Spanish Translation: The presence of a `hamartoma` of the `hypothalamus` (FMA:62008).
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose  (FDG) in the hypothalamus as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
column5: Hipometabolismo en hipotálamo por tomografía de emisión de positrones con fdg

Spanish Translation: A type of `hypothyroidism` (HP:0000821) that results from a defect in `thyrotropin-releasing hormone activity` (GO:0008437).
Decreased secretion of luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone by the hypothalamus.
column5: Secreción disminuida de la hormona hipotalámica liberadora de hormona luteinizante

Spanish Translation: Hypsarrhythmia is abnormal interictal high amplitude waves and a background of irregular spikes. There is continuous (during wakefulness), high-amplitude (>200 Hz), generalized polymorphic slowing with no organized background and multifocal spikes demonstrated by electroencephalography (EEG).
Auras with an alteration of actual percepts involving the visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory or gustatory systems.

Term textual definition: Impaired ability to form peer relationships
column5: Alteración para la habilidad de establecer relaciones con compañeros

Spanish Translation: A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints.
column5: Deterioro o pérdida de la propiocepción distal

Spanish Translation: A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
column5: Disminución de la sensación táctil distal

Spanish Translation: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the distal portions of the limbs.
column5: Disminución de la sensación de vibración distal

Spanish Translation: Reduced ability to perceive painful stimuli.
column5: Disminución en la sensación de dolor

Spanish Translation: A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position.

Difficulty in social interactions related to an impairment of characteristics such as eye contact, smiling, appropriate facial expressions, and body postures and characterized by difficulty in forming peer relationships and forming friendships.

A reduced ability to participate in the back and forth flow of social interaction, which is normally characterized by an influence of the behavior of one person on the behavior of another person who is in conversation with the first.
A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures.
column5: Deterioro de la sensación de temperatura

Spanish Translation: A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip.
column5: Deterioro para localizar el lugar donde han tocado a la persona

Spanish Translation: A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart.
column5: Disminución de la habilidad para discriminar dos puntos

Spanish Translation: Reduced ability to use nonverbal behavior for communication, such as eye-to-eye gaze, facial expression, body posture, and gestures.
column5: Deterioro de la capacidad de usar comportamientos no verbales

Spanish Translation: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration at the ankles. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to the malleoli of the ankles.
column5: Deterioro de la sensación vibratoria en tobillos

Term textual definition: Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
Spanish Translation: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the legs.
column5: Deterioro de la sensación vibratoria en extremidades inferiores

Spanish Translation: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to bony prominences such as the malleoli at the ankles or the metacarpal-phalangeal joints. There is a slow decay of vibration from the tuning fork. The degree of vibratory sense loss can be crudely estimated by counting the number of seconds that the examiner can perceive the vibration longer than the patient.

Reduced ability affecting mainly  visuospatial cognition which may be tested using pattern construction (for example by Differential Ability Scales, which test a person's strengths and weaknesses across a range of intellectual abilities).
column5: Deterioro cognitivo para la construcción visuoespacial

Spanish Translation: Incapability to ambulate.

column5: Incapacidad para caminar en la infancia / adolescencia

Spanish Translation: Increased concentration of interferon alpha in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
column5: Aumento de interferón alfa en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Spanish Translation: Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
column5: Aumento de lactato en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Spanish Translation: Increased concentration of protein in the cerebrospinal fluid.
column5: Aumento de proteínas en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Spanish Translation: An elevated concentration of lactate in the caudate nucleus. This finding can be elicited by magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging.
column5: Aumento de lactato en núcleo caudado

Spanish Translation: Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes.  This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.

Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the extraneuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.
An increase of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid.

Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the neuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.
Encephalopathy with onset in the infantile period.
Infantile spasms represent a subset of "epileptic spasms". Infantile Spasms are epileptic spasms starting in the first year of life (infancy).
Underdevelopment of the inferior portion of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).

Term textual definition: Inflexible adherence to routines or rituals
column5: Inflexibilidad para adherirse a rutinas o rituales

Spanish Translation: Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70.
Borderline intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 70-79.
Mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 50-69.
Moderate mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 35-49.
Profound mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) below 20.
The term progressive intellectual disability should be used if intelligence decreases/deteriorates over time.
Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34.

An oscillatory cerebellar ataxia that tends to be absent when the limbs are inactive and during the first part of voluntary movement but worsening as the movement continues and greater precision is required (e.g., in touching a target such as the patient's nose or a physician's finger).
Episodes or attacks of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours.
History of repeated intermittent involuntary muscle contractions that were painful.
The presence of `calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) in the cerebral white matter surrounding the cerebral ventricles.
A cystic lesion originating within the brain.

A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from the inclusion of ectodermally committed cells at the time of neural tube closure (3rd-5th week of embryogenesis). The capsule of dermoid cysts consists of simple epithelium supported by collagen. In thicker parts, the lining is supplemented with dermis containing hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and apocrine glands.
A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from ectodermal cells that normally form skin cells being left behind in the nervous system during development.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring within the `skull` (FMA:46565).
An arachnoid cyst located within the ventricular system.
Involuntary contractions of muscle leading to involuntary movements of extremities, neck, trunk, or face.
An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in brain tissue.
column5: Acumulación de hierro en el cerebro

Spanish Translation: An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in the `globus pallidus` (FMA:61835).
column5: Acumulación de hierro en el globo pálido

Spanish Translation: An anomalous build up of iron (Fe) in the `substantia nigra` (FMA:67947).
column5: Acumulación de hierro en la sustancia negra

Term textual definition: Irregular loops and focal folding of myelin sheaths
column5: Bucles irregulares y plegamientos focales de la vaina de mielina

Spanish Translation: A subjective feeling that an experience which has occurred before is being experienced for the first time.
column5: Jamais vu o fenómeno de lo "jamás visto"

Spanish Translation: Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in jaw.

Damage to cerebral nuclei caused in infants by highly increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin. The basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei could be shown to have a yellow staining historically in infants who died of kernicterus, that is, kernicterus is strictly speaking a pathological diagnosis. The presence of kernicterus may be inferred in infants with characteristic acute or chronic bilirubin-induced neurological dysfunction.
A kinked appearance of the brainstem, i.e., an exaggerated flexure.
.Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes.
An intraneuronal inclusion body composed of acid mucopolysaccharides.
Increased size of the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).

A form of focal dystonia that affects the vocal cords, associated with involuntary contractions of the vocal cords causing interruptions of speech and affecting the voice quality and often leading to patterned, repeated breaks in speech.
A state of  disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.

Leukodystrophy refers to deterioration of white matter of the brain resulting from degeneration of myelin sheaths in the CNS. Their basic defect is directly related to the synthesis and maintenance of myelin membranes.
This term describes abnormality of the white matter of the cerebrum resulting from damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells.
A kind of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) that affects movements of the extremities.
A type of `dysmetria` (HP:0001310) involving the limbs.
A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the limbs.
Fasciculations affecting the musculature of the arms and legs.

Term textual definition: Lipomas of the central neryous system

Spanish Translation: A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure.

A type of holoprosencephaly in which most of the right and left cerebral hemispheres and lateral ventricles are separated but the most rostral aspect of the telencephalon, the frontal lobes, are fused, especially ventrally.
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment extends proximal to the sigmoid.

Term textual definition: Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellar vermis
column5: Pérdida de células de Purkinje del vermis cerebeloso
Pérdida de la capacidad para caminar

Term textual definition: Loss of ability to walk in early childhood
column5: Pérdida de la capacidad de caminar en la infancia temprana

Term textual definition: Loss of ability to walk in first decade
column5: Pérdida de la capacidad para caminar en la primera década

Spanish Translation: A reduced concentration of `5-methyltetrahydrofolate(2-)` (CHEBI:18608) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). 5-methyltetrahydrofolate is the active folate metabolite.
column5: Nivel bajo de 5-metiltetrahidrofolato en líquido cefaloraquídeo

Spanish Translation: Set definition of ID:0000013 to "EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz).
A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes in the lower limbs.
Increased size of cerebral gyri, often associated with a moderate reduction in the number of sulci of the cerebrum.

Term textual definition: Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
column5: Tumor maligno del sistema nervioso central

Spanish Translation: A state of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, arousal, and or energy levels.

A rapidly growing embryonic tumor arising in the posterior part of the `cerebellar vermis` (FMA:76928) and neuroepithelial roof of the fourth ventricle in children. More rarely, medulloblastoma arises in the `cerebellum` (FMA:67944) in adults.
Enlargement of all or parts of the cerebral hemispheres.
An impairment of memory as manifested by a reduced ability to remember things such as dates and names, and increased forgetfulness.
`Calcium deposition` (MPATH:36) affecting the `Meninges` (FMA:231572).
The presence of a `meningioma` (MPATH:251), i.e., a benign tumor originating from the `dura mater` (FMA:9592) or `arachnoid mater` (FMA:9591).
`Inflammation` (MPATH:212) of the `meninges` (FMA:231572).
Protrusion of the meninges through a defect of the vertebral column.
Loss of previously present mental abilities, generally in adults.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the `middle cerebral artery` (FMA:50079).
column5: Estenosis de la arteria cerebral media
Calcificaciones en la línea media del cerebro
Lipomas en la línea media del sistema nervioso central

Spanish Translation: Migraine is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by episodic attacks of headache and associated symptoms.

A type of `migraine` (HP:0002076) in which there is an aura characterized by focal neurological phenomena that usually proceed, but may accompany or occur in the absence of, the headache. The symptoms of an aura may include fully reversible visual, sensory, and speech symptoms but not motor weakness. Visual symptoms may include flickering lights, spots and lines and/or loss of vision and/or unilateral sensory symptoms such as paresthesias or numbness. At least one of the symptoms of an aura develops gradually over 5 or more minutes and/or different symptoms occur in succession.

Repeated headache attacks lasting 4-72 h fulfilling at least two of the following criteria: 1) unilateral location, 2) pulsating quality, 3) moderate or severe pain intensity, and 4) aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity such as climbing stairs. Headache attacks are commonly accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia.
A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
column5: Retraso leve en la expresión del lenguaje

Spanish Translation: A kind of `ventriculomegaly` (HP:0002119) occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (pmid:16100637).
A mild delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
column5: Retraso leve en el lenguaje receptivo

Spanish Translation: Auras which reflect ictal dysmnesia such as: feelings as familiarity (d??j??-vu) and unfamiliarity (jamais-vu).
A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
column5: Retraso moderado en la expresión del lenguaje

Spanish Translation: A moderate delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
column5: Retraso moderado en el lenguaje receptivo

Spanish Translation: An abnormal appearance of the midbrain in axial magnetic resonance imaging in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth.
column5: Signo de la muela en resonancia magnética nuclear

Spanish Translation: A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution.
An exaggeration of emotional affects such as laughing crying, or yawning beyond what the person feels.

Term textual definition: Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system
Spanish Translation: A structural abnormality of the `central nervous system` (FMA:55675).
column5: Anomalía morfológica del sistema nervioso central

Term textual definition: Morphological abnormality of the pyramidal tract
Spanish Translation: Any structural abnormality of the `pyramidal tract` (FMA:72634), whose chief element, the corticospinal tract, is the only direct connection between the brain and the spinal cord. In addition to the corticospinal tract, the pyramidal system includes the corticobulbar, corticomesencephalic, and corticopontine tracts.
Impairment of expressive language  and relative preservation of receptive language abilities. That is, the patient understands language (speech, writing) but cannot express it.

Progressive impairment of function of motor axons with muscle weakness, atrophy, and cramps. The deficits are length-dependent, meaning that muscles innervated by the longest nerves are affected first, so that for instance the arms are affected at a later age than the onset of deficits involving the lower leg.
Blockade of impulses at a focal site along the course of a motor axon.
A type of `Developmental delay` (HP:0001263) characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills.
Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities.
Movement-based tics affecting discrete muscle groups.
A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the `circle of Willis` (FMA:50454).

column5: Alteraciones multifocales de la sustancia blanca cerebral

Spanish Translation: A abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG) and being identified at multiple locations (foci).

Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG.
The presence of excessive redundant myelin in the peripheral nerve sheath.
A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons.
Inflammation of the `spinal cord` (FMA:7647).
Protrusion of the meninges and portions of the spinal cord through a defect of the vertebral column.
Absence seizures that are additionally characterized by rhythmic bilateral myoclonias of the arms and shoulders synchronous with EEG discharges, with additional tonic components of the arms.
Seizures with sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone with a preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting one to two seconds or more, involving head, trunk, jaw or limb musculature.
Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements.

Successive and rapid contractions of motor units associated with chronic nerve injury. The discharges arise from the peripheral aspects of regenerating nerves, and clinically impart a nearly continuous undulation of the body surface overlying the muscle.
Habitual biting of one's own fingernails.
A type of encephalopathy (brain disease, damage, or malfunction accompanied by an altered mental state) that is characterized by evidence of necrosis of brain tissue.

Term textual definition: Neoplasm of the central nervous system
Spanish Translation: A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the `central nervous system` (FMA:55675).
A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) affecting the `nervous system` (FMA:7157).

Term textual definition: Neoplasm of the peripheral nervous system
Spanish Translation: A benign or malignant `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) (tumour) of the `peripheral nervous system` (FMA:9903).

Neuroblastoma is a solid tumor that originate in neural crest cells of the sympathetic nervous system. Most neuroblastomas originate in the abdomen, and most abdominal neuroblastomas originate in the adrenal gland. Neuroblastomas can also originate in the thorax, usually in the posterior mediastinum.
Progressive loss of neural cells and tissue.
A deviation from normal of the neurological development of a child, which may include any or all of the aspects of the development of personal, social, gross or fine motor, and cognitive abilities.
Pathological protein aggregates formed by hyperphosphorylation of a microtubule-associated protein known as tau, causing it to aggregate in an insoluble form.
The presence of multiple cutaneous neurofibromas.
A reduction in the number of nerve cells in the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).
column5: Pérdida de neuronas en los ganglios basales

Term textual definition: Neuronal loss in central nervous system
column5: Pérdida de neuronas en el sistema nervioso central

Term textual definition: Neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex
column5: Pérdida de neuronas en la corteza cerebral

Spanish Translation: A form of `hydrocephalus` (HP:0000238) in which the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the cerebral ventricular system or in the outlets of the CSF to the arachnoid space is obstructed.
A form of `hydrocephalus` (HP:0000238) characterized by enlarged cerebral ventricles and normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure upon lumbar puncture.
Recurrent obsessions or compulsions that are severe enough to be time consuming (i.e., they take more than 1 hour a day) or cause marked distress or significant impairment (DSM-IV).

The presence of one or more obsessive-compulsive personality traits. Obsessions refer to persistent intrusive thoughts, and compulsions to intrusive behaviors, which the affected person experiences as involuntary, senseless, or repugnant.

A condition characterized by obstruction of the airway and by pauses in breathing during sleep occurring many times during the night. Obstructive sleep apnea is related to a relaxation of muscle tone (which normally occurs during sleep) leading to partial collapse of the soft tissues in the airway with resultant obstruction of the air flow.
Atypical absence lasting for more than 30 minutes.
Neurofibromas present in a smaller number than usually seen in neurofibromatosis type 1.
Atrophy of the `occipital cortex` (FMA:67325).
A distinct type of headache characterized by piercing, throbbing, or electric-shock-like chronic pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears, usually on one side.
A type of `dyssynergia` (HP:0010867) affecting eye movements and characterized by the inability to smoothly follow a visual target across the visual field.

An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications.
Auras with sensation of odor, usually disagreeable.
Degeneration of the olivary bodies, prominent oval structures in the medulla oblongata.
Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.
Hypoplasia of the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.

Repeated episodes of segmental demyelination and remyelination lead to the accumulation of supernumerary Schwann cells around axons, which is referred to as onion bulb formation. This finding affects peripheral nerves.
Underdevelopment of the operculum.

An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents.
A `glioma` (HP:0009733) originating in the `optic nerve` (FMA:50863) or `optic chiasm` (FMA:62045).

Reluctance or refusal of a child to be breastfed or eat, manifested as gagging, vomiting, turning head away from food, or avoidance of sensation in or around the mouth (i.e. toothbrushing or face-washing).
A kind of focal dystonia characterized by forceful contractions of the face, jaw, and/or tongue causing difficulty in opening and closing the mouth and often affecting chewing and speech.
A form of hypotension characterized by a sudden fall in blood pressure that occurs when a person assumes a standing position.

Term textual definition: Orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction
column5: Hipotensión ortostática debido a disfunción autonómica

Spanish Translation: An increase in heart rate with standing of 30 beats per minute or more.

Term textual definition: Osteomyelitis or necrosis, distal, due to sensory neuropathy (feet)
column5: Osteomielitis o necrosis distal (pies) debida a neuropatía sensitiva

Spanish Translation: A form of hypersociability that presents as mostly inappropriate people-orientation and friendliness towards others on an inadequate level which might go as far as being dangerous considering for example young children following strangers without restriction.
A congenital abnormality of the cerebral hemisphere chacterized by unusually thick gyrations (convolutions) of the cerebral cortex.
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage.
Inability to perceive painful stimuli.
Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate.
Neurodegeneration involving the globus pallidus,a part of the basal ganglia that is involved in the regulation of voluntary movement.

Term textual definition: Pallor of dorsal columns of the spinal cord
column5: Palidez de las columnas dorsales de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: A carotid body tumor (also called paraganglionoma or chemodectoma) is a tumor found in the upper neck at the branching of the carotid artery. They arise from the chemoreceptor organ (paraganglion) located in the adventitia of the carotid artery bifurcation.

column5: Paraganglioma de la cabeza y cuello

Spanish Translation: A cranial nerve palsy associated with a paraganglioma of the head or neck.
column5: Parálisis de los nervios craneales asociada a la presencia de paraganglioma

Spanish Translation: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Motor paralysis results from deficits of the upper motor neurons (corticospinal, corticobulbar, or subcorticospinal). Motor paralysis is often accompanied by an impairment in the facility of movement.

Term textual definition: Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts
Spanish Translation: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts is related to a lesion in the corticospinal, corticobulbar or brainstem descending (subcorticospinal) neurons.
column5: Parálisis debida a lesiones de los tractos motores principales

Spanish Translation: A persecutory delusion of supposed hostility of others.
Weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs.
Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities.
Weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities. Paraplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas paraparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength.
Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause.
Atrophy of the `parietal cortex` (FMA:61826).
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose  (FDG) in the parietal cortex as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
column5: Hipometabolismo parietal en la tomografía por emisión de positrones PET con fdg

Spanish Translation: Characteristic neurologic anomaly resulting form degeneration of dopamine-generating cells in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain, characterized clinically by shaking, rigidity, slowness of movement and difficulty with walking and gait.

Term textual definition: Parkinsonism with favorable response to dopaminergic medication
column5: Parkinsonismo con respuesta favorable a la medicación dopaminérgica

Spanish Translation: Episodes of choreoathetosis that can occur following triggers such as quick voluntary movements.
Attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness.
Episodic bouts of involuntary movements with dystonic, choreic, ballistic movements, or a combination thereof. There is no loss of consciousness during the attacks.
A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes.
Repeated episodes of sudden-onset and transient `lethargy` (HP:0001254).
Congenital absence of a part of the `vermis of cerebellum` (FMA:76928).

Term textual definition: Partial agenesis of the corpus callosum
Spanish Translation: A partial failure of the development of the corpus callosum.
EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz).
column5: EEG dominado por ondas beta difusas

Term textual definition: Patchy demyelination of subcortical white matter
Spanish Translation: Patchy loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
column5: Desmielinización en parches de la sustancia blanca subcortical

Term textual definition: Paucity of anterior horn motor neurons
column5: Disminución de neuronas motoras del asta anterior

Spanish Translation: Episodes of muscle weakness associated with elevated levels of potassium in the blood.
Episodes of muscle weakness associated with reduced levels of potassium in the blood.
Episodes of muscle weakness.
The presence of a `peripheral` (PATO:0002107) `schwannoma` (MPATH:438).
Atrophic changes of `axons` (FMA:67308) of the peripheral nervous system.
Progressive deterioration of peripheral axons.
An abnormality characterized by disruption of  the normal functioning of peripheral axons.
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths.
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system.

Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the `peripheral nervous system` (FMA:9903). The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.
An excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of the brain in the region surrounding the sylvian fissures.

Increased dimensions of the Virchow-Robin spaces (also known as perivascular spaces), which surround the walls of vessels as they course from the subarachnoid space through the brain parenchyma. Perivascular spaces are commonly microscopic, and not visible on conventional neuroimaging. This term refers to an increase of size of these spaces such that they are visible on neuroimaging (usually magnetic resonance imaging). The dilatations are regular cavities that always contain a patent artery.

A form of gray matter heterotopia were the mislocalized gray matter is typically located periventricularly, also sometimes called subependymal heterotopia. Periventricular means beside the ventricles. This is by far the most common location for heterotopia. Subependymal heterotopia present in a wide array of variations. There can be a small single node or a large number of nodes, can exist on either or both sides of the brain at any point along the higher ventricle margins, can be small or large, single or multiple, and can form a small node or a large wavy or curved mass.
column5: Heterotopia periventricular de la sustancia gris

Spanish Translation: Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter that surrounds the cerebral ventricles.
column5: Hipodensidades periventriculares de la sustancia blanca

Spanish Translation: An abnormal shift in patterns of thinking, acting, or feeling.

An abnormality of mental functioning affecting the personality and behavioural tendencies of an individual and characterized by a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking and behavior. The definition of a personal disorder implies that the abnormality is not the result of damage or insult to the brain or from another psychiatric disorder.

Pheochromocytomas (also known as chromaffin tumors) produce, store, and secrete catecholamines. Pheochromocytomas usually originate from the adrenal medulla but may also develop from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia. A common symptom of pheochromocytoma is hypertension owing to release of catecholamines.
Involuntary sounds produced by moving air through the nose, mouth, or throat. The vocal cords are not involved in all tics that produce sound.
An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds.
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures that are triggered by flashing or flickering light.
An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month.
A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the `pineal gland` (FMA:62033).
Deposition of calcium salts in the pituitary gland.
A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure.
A congenital abnormality of the cerebral hemisphere characterized by an excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of the brain.
Focal epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies.
A generalized disorder of peripheral nerves.
A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat.
Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum.
Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye.
A morphological abnormality of the `metencephalon` (FMA:62003).
A disorder of the brain in which a cyst or cavity filled with cerebrospinal fluid develops in the cerebral hemisphere.

The patient stands with the feet placed together and balance and is asked to close his or her eyes. A loss of balance upon eye closure is a positive Romberg sign and is interpreted as indicating a deficit in proprioception.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the `posterior cerebral artery` (FMA:50583).
column5: Estenosis de la arteria cerebral posterior

Spanish Translation: A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position.
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose  (FDG) in the prefrontal cortex as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
column5: Hipometabolismo prefrontal en tomografía por emisión de positrones pet con fdg

Spanish Translation: A profound delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
A progressive degree of muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement).
A type of `gait ataxia` (HP:0002066) displaying progression of clinical severity.
Progressive loss of previously present language abilities.
Leukoencephalopathy that gets more severe with time.
Spasticity that increases in degree with time.

column5: Potenciales evocados auditivos de tronco cerebral prolongados

Spanish Translation: An abnormal prolongation of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction.
column5: Potenciales miniatura de placa terminal prolongados

Spanish Translation: Inability to recognize faces of familair persons.
Individuals with `Pseudobulbar signs` (HP:0002200) often also demonstrate abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.

Bilateral impairment of the function of the cranial nerves 9-12, which control musculature involved in eating, swallowing, and speech. Pseudobulbar paralysis is characterized clinically by dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia with bifacial paralysis, and may be accompanied by `Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms` (HP:0002193) such as enforced crying and laughing.

Pseudobulbar signs result from injury to an upper motor neuron lesion to the corticobulbar pathways in the pyramidal tract. Patients have difficulty chewing, swallowing and demonstrate slurred speech (often initial presentation) as well as abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.
Auras with affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual phenomena including illusory or composite hallucinatory events.
Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities.
A condition characterized by changes of personality and thought patterns often accompanied by hallucinations and delusional beliefs.
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
An increased susceptibility to bacterial meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of bacterial meningitis.
Recurrent bleeding into the parenchyma of the brain.
Recurrent episodes of brain dysfunction that may be triggered by factors such as metabolic disturbances or infections.
A type of stereotypic behavior in which the affected individual repeatedly waves the hands up and down.
An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis.
Decreased concentration of `dopamine` (CHEBI:18243) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
column5: Reducción del nivel de dopamina en el líquido cefalorraquideo

Term textual definition: Reduced brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
Spanish Translation: A decrease in the level of N-acetyl aspartate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
column5: Nivel cerebral disminuído de n-acetil aspartato en la resonancia magnética por spectroscopia

Spanish Translation: Diminution of tendon reflexes, which is an invariable sign of peripheral nerve disease.
A resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved. Resting tremors are often slow and coarse.
A feeling of uneasiness and restlessness in the legs after going to bed (sometimes causing insomnia).
Behavior characterized by an abnormal limitation to few interests and activities.

Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction. When an affected muscle is passively stretched, the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from muscle spasticity.
Thick, elongated, worm-like or corkscrew eosinophilic bundle that are found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders.
The presence of a cleft in the cerebral cortex unilaterally or bilaterally, usually located in the frontal area.

A mental disorder characterized by a disintegration of thought processes and of emotional responsiveness. It most commonly manifests as auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3-0.7%.
A benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells.

A form of gait abnormality characterized by hypertonia and flexion in the legs, hips and pelvis accompanied by extreme adduction leading to the knees and thighs hitting, or sometimes even crossing, in a scissors-like movement. The opposing muscles (abductors) become comparatively weak from lack of use.
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers from segments of the peripheral nervous system.
A segmental pattern of demyelination and regeneration (remyelination) affecting peripheral nerves.

Seizures are an intermittent `abnormality of the central nervous system` (FMA:HP:0002011) due to a sudden, excessive, disorderly discharge of cerebral neurons and characterized clinically by some combination of disturbance of sensation, loss of consciousness, impairment of psychic function, or convulsive movements. The term epilepsy is used to describe chronic, recurrent seizures.
Habitual biting of one's own body.
column5: Auto mutilación compulsiva / auto mordida compulsiva

Spanish Translation: Aggression towards oneself.

Term textual definition: Self-mutilation of tongue and lips due to involuntary movements
column5: Automutilación de la lengua y los labios por movimientos involuntarios

Spanish Translation: A type of holoprosencephaly in which the left and right frontal and parietal lobes are fused and the interhemispheric fissure is only present posteriorly.
Senile plaques are extracellular deposits of amyloid in the gray matter of the brain.

Term textual definition: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs
column5: Polineuropatía sensoriomotora que afecta los brazos más que las piernas

Spanish Translation: Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms.
An axonal neuropathy of peripheral sensory nerves.

An abnormality of the primary sensation that is mediated by peripheral nerves (pain, temperature, touch, vibration, joint position). The word hypoesthesia (or hyesthesia) refers to a reduction in cutaneous sensation to a specific type of testing.
Peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves.

Term textual definition: Severe demyelination of the white matter
Spanish Translation: A severe loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
column5: Retraso en el lenguaje expresivo grave

Spanish Translation: A severe delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
column5: Retraso en el lenguaje receptivo grave

Spanish Translation: Reduced attention span characterized by distractibility and impulsivity but not necessarily satisfying the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment does not extend beyond the upper sigmoid.

column5: Marcha con arrastre de los pies

Spanish Translation: Discomfort and partial inhibition of the usual forms of behavior when in the presence of others.
Febrile seizures with generalized tonic-clonic semiology, duration less than 15 minutes, and without recurrence within the next 24 hours.
Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage.

An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep.

An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness.
Myoclonus that occurs during the initial phases of sleep.
Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech.
Decreased size of the `basal ganglia` (FMA:84013).
Reduced size of the `cerebral cortex` (FMA:61830).
Auras with sensation of tingling, numbness, electric shock sensations, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move.
Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.

A type of dysarthria related to bilateral damage of the upper motor neuron tracts of the pyramidal and extra- pyramidal tracts. Speech of affected individuals is slow, effortful, and has a harsh vocal quality.
Unilateral paralysis with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes.
Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles.
Spastic weakness affecting all four limbs.
Spastic paralysis affecting all four limbs.
A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.

Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence.

A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur.
Incomplete closure of the embryonic neural tube, whereby some vertebral arches remain unfused and open. The mildest form is spina bifida occulta, followed by meningocele and meningomyelocele.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of a vertebral body with intact overlying skin.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of the vertebra L5 with intact overlying skin.
External mechanical compression of the spinal cord.

Term textual definition: Spinal cord posterior columns myelin loss
column5: Pérdida de mielinización de los cordones posteriores de la médula espinal

Spanish Translation: A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) affecting the `spinal cord` (FMA:7647).
A heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in fetal life.
A 'hemangioblastoma` (HP:0010797) of the `spinal cord` (FMA:7647).
An outpouching of the spinal meninges.

Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia.
Neurofibromas originating in the spine.
Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space.
Atrophy affecting the cerebellum and the spinocerebellar tracts of the spinal cord.

Term textual definition: Spinocerebellar tract disease in lower limbs
column5: Enfermedad del tracto espinocerebeloso de miembros inferiores

Spanish Translation: Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger.
Seizures lasting for more than 30 minutes or longer or multiple seizures repeated frequently without regaining consciousness between seizures.

An abnormal gait pattern that arises from weakness of the pretibial and peroneal muscles due to a lower motor neuron lesion. Affected patients have footdrop and are unable to dorsiflex and evert the foot. The leg is lifted high on walking so that the toes clear the ground, and there may be a slapping noise when the foot strikes the ground again.
column5: Marcha neuropática / marcha del gran paso

Spanish Translation: A repetitive behaviour that does not serve an observable goal. In general the movements are not aimed at the environment, but at the person itself. Stereotypical behaviour is seen especially in children with sensory, intellectual and/or cognitive handicaps.
Habitual repetitive movement of the body.
Habitual clasping and squeeezing of the hands.
Sudden impairment of blood flow to a part of the brain due to occlusion or rupture of an artery to the brain.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring between the `arachnoid mater` (FMA:9591) and the `pia mater` (FMA:9590).
Atrophy of the cerebral subcortical white and gray matter, termed subcortical atrophy, reflects loss of nerve cells in the basal ganglia or fibers in the deep white matter.
A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change.

column5: Calcificaciones subcorticales de la sustancia blanca

Spanish Translation: The presence of `Neurofibromas` (HP:0001067) in the subcutis.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring between the `dura mater` (FMA:9592) and the `arachnoid mater` (FMA:9591).

A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter.
The presence of `gliosis` (MPATH:182) in the `substantia nigra` (FMA:67947).

An arachnoid cyst that progressively enlarges from an abnormality in the membrane of Liliequist or in the interpeduncular cistern, and typically, expands from the prepontine space, displacing the floor of the third ventricle upwards, the pituitary stalk and optic chiasm upwards and forwards, and the mammillary bodies upwards and backwards.

Term textual definition: Symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia
column5: Lesiones simétricas de los ganglios basales

Spanish Translation: A symmetric loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
Multiple neurofibromas of the spinal nerve roots with a symmetric distribution.
column5: Neurofibromas radiculares simétricos de nervios espinales

Spanish Translation: A symmetric and progressive loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
A seizure that occurs in the context of a brain insult (systemic, toxic, or metabolic) and may not recur when the underlying cause has been removed or the acute phase has elapsed.
Dilated, glial-lined cavity in spinal cord. This cavity does not communicate with the central canal, and usually is between the dorsal columns unilaterally or bilaterally along the side of the cord.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting all of the basal ganglia.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MIR) of the brainstem. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire brainstem.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire thalamus.
Atrophy of the `temporal cortex` (FMA:61825).

A type of headache that last hours with continuous pain of mild or moderate intensity, bilateral location, a pressing/tightening (non-pulsating) quality and that is not aggravated by routine physical activity such as walking or climbing stairs.

During normal embryological development, the spinal cord first occupies the entire length of the vertebral column but goes on to assume a position at the level of L1 due to differential growth of the conus medullaris and the vertebral column. The filum terminale is a slender, threadlike structure that remains after the normal regression of the distal embryonic spinal cord and attaches the spinal cord to the coccyx. A tethered cord results if there is a thickened rope-like filum terminale which anchors the cord at the level of L2 or below, potentially causing neurologic signs owing to abnormal tension on the spinal cord.
Weakness of all four limbs.

Paralysis of all four limbs, and trunk of the body below the level of an associated injury to the spinal cord. The etiology of quadriplegia is similar to that of paraplegia except that the lesion is in the cervical spinal cord rather than in the thoracic or lumbar segments of the spinal cord.
Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose  (FDG) in the thalamus as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
column5: Hipometabolismo talámico en en tomografía por emisión de positrones pet con fdg

Spanish Translation: Increased vertical dimension of the corpus callosum. This feature can be visualized by sagittal sections on magnetic resonance tomography imaging of the brain.
Increased width of the `superior cerebellar peduncle` (FMA:72495).
A tic is a sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic, stereotyped motor movement or vocalization involving discrete muscle groups.
Sustained involuntary  muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body.
Excessive bending, twisting, and winding of a cerebral artery.
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment comprises the entire colon.
A congenital defect characterized by the lack of ganglion cells in the entire intestine, i.e., the aganglionic segment comprises the entire large and small bowel.
A paroxysmal, transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement.
A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected.
Triplication of the spinal cord - extremely rare.

Trophic changes is a term used to describe abnormalities in the area of pain that include primarily wasting away of the skin, tissues, or muscle, thinning of the bones, and changes in how the hair or nails grow, including thickening or thinning of hair or brittle nails.
column5: Cambios tróficos relacionados con el dolor

Spanish Translation: `Trophic changes` (HP:0010834) occuring in a limb.
A kind of `ataxia` (HP:0001251) that affects the proximal musculature, especially that involved in gait stability.

A form of `lissencephaly` (HP:0001339) in which the cortex is thickened and has four more or less disorganized layers rather than six normal layers resulting from incomplete neuronal migration during brain development.
A form of `lissencephaly` (HP:0001339) characterized by an uneven cortical surface with a so called 'cobblestone' appearace. There are no distinguishable cortical layers.
Typical absences are brief for seconds generalized epileptic seizures of abrupt onset and abrupt termination with impairment of consciousness.
Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates that show positive staining with antibodies against ubiquitin within cells of the brain.

Term textual definition: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
Spanish Translation: Epileptiform discharges identified at multiple locations temporarily in both hemispheres and temporarily in one hemisphere.
column5: Descargas epileptiformes multifocales uni y bilaterales

Spanish Translation: Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in one hemisphere.
Excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of one side of the brain.
A unilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position.
A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregulatory functions.
An increase in size of the ventricular system of the brain.
Tonic seizures with a sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline.

A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear.
Overgrowth of the `choroid plexus` (FMA:61934).
column5: Hipertrofia de las vellosidades del plexo coroideo

Spanish Translation: Auras with sensation of flashing or flickering lights, spots, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis.

A wavering, unsteady voice that reflects involuntary and approximately sinusoidal oscillation of motor unit firings of laryngeal muscles. Vocal tremor results in low frequency modulations of voice frequency or amplitude and intermittent voice instability.

Term textual definition: White mater abnormalities in the posterior periventricular region
column5: Anomalías de la sustancia blanca de la región periventricular posterior

Spanish Translation: An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater in the region surrounding the cerebellum.
An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater in the region surrounding the cerebrum.
An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater.
A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of S1 with intact overlying skin.
`Distention` (PATO:0001602) of the `abdomen` (FMA:9577).
Pain perceived to originate in the abdomen.
A left-right reversal (or "mirror reflection") of the anatomical location of the `viscera of the abdomen` (FMA:259123).
An `incomplete closure` (PATO:0000609) of the `abdominal wall` (FMA:259054).
`Decreased strength` (PATO:0001779) of the `abdominal musculature` (FMA:86917).
column5: Debilidad muscular de la pared abdominal

Spanish Translation: A structural abnormality of the `biliary tree` (FMA:14665).
A functional abnormality of the `biliary tree` (FMA:14665).
A structural anomaly of the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202).
column5: Morfología anormal de la vesícula biliar

Spanish Translation: A functional anomaly of the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202).
column5: Fisiología anormal de la vesícula biliar

Spanish Translation: A functional anomaly of the large intestine.

Term textual definition: Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy
column5: Pruebas de función hepática anormales durante el embarazo

Spanish Translation: A deviation from the normal size of the pancreas.
An abnormality of the abdominal situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the abdomin and its organs.
A function abnormality of the endocrine pancreas.
column5: Anormalidad de la fisiología del páncreas endocrino

Spanish Translation: A functional anomaly of the acinar gland portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes.
column5: Anormalidad de la fisiología del páncreas exocrino
Anormalidad de la morfología de páncreas

Spanish Translation: An anomaly of the function of the pancreas.
column5: Anormalidad de la fisiología del páncreas

Term textual definition: Abnormality of small intestinal villus morphology
column5: Anormalidad de la morfología de las vellosidades intestinales

Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the `abdomen` (FMA:9577) ('belly'), that is, the part of the body between the pelvis and the thorax.
An abnormality of the `abdominal musculature` (FMA:86917).
An abnormality of the `viscera of the abdomen` (FMA:259123).
The presence of any abnormality affecting the `abdominal wall` (FMA:259054).
Abnormality of the `anal canal` (FMA:15703).
An abnormality of the `biliary system` (FMA:79646).
Any abnormality of the `diaphragm` (FMA:13295).

An abnormality of the `Common bile duct` (FMA:14667), a tube-like anatomic structure in the human gastrointestinal tract, formed by the union of the `Common hepatic duct` (FMA:14668) and the `Cystic duct` (FMA:14539) from the gall bladder.
An abnormality of the duodenum, i.e., the first section of the small intestine.
An abnormality of the `esophagus` (FMA:7131).
An abnormality of the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202).
An abnormality of the `gastric mucous membrane` (FMA:14907).
An abnormality of the `gastrointestinal tract` (FMA:71132).
An abnormality of the `hepatic vasculature` (FMA:73748).
An abnormality of the `intestine` (FMA:7199). The closely related term enteropathy is used to refer to any disease of the intestine.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `intrahepatic bile duct` (FMA:15766).
column5: Anormalidad de la vía biliar intrahepática

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `jejunum` (FMA:7207), i.e., of the middle section of the small intestine.
Any abnormality of the `large intestine` (FMA:7201).
An abnormality of the `liver` (FMA:7197).

Folds of membranous tissue (peritoneum, mesothelium) attached to the wall of the abdomen and enclosing viscera. Examples include the mesentery for the small intestine; the transverse mesocolon, which attaches the transverse portion of the colon to the back wall of the abdomen; and the mesosigmoid, which enfolds the sigmoid portion of the colon. Cells of the same embryologic origin also surround the other organs of the body such as the lungs (pleura) or the heart (pericardium).
An abnormality of the `pancreas` (FMA:7198).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the islet of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells. These are the alpha cells, which produce glucagon, the beta cells, which produce insulin and amylin, the delta cells, which produce somatostatin, the PP cells, which produce pancreatic polypeptide, and the epsilon cells, which produce ghrelin.
column5: Anormalidad de las células de los islotes pancreáticos

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `peritoneum` (FMA:9584).
An abnormality of the `pylorus` (FMA:14581).
An abnormaltiy of the `rectum` (FMA:14544), the final segment of the large intestine that stores solid waste until it passes through the anus.
An abnormality of the `small intestine` (FMA:7200).
An abnormality of the `spleen` (FMA:7196).
An abnormality of the `stomach` (FMA:7148).
Abnormality of the `umbilicus` (FMA:61584).
Absence of `gastric intrinsic factor` (PRO:000007975), which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.
A developmental defect in which the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202) fails to form.
Congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm.

An accessory spleen is a round, iso-echogenic, homogenic and smooth structure and is seen as a normal variant mostly on the medial contour of the spleen, near the hilus or around the lower pole. This has no pathogenic relevance.

A disorder of esophageal motility characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax during swallowing and by inadequate or lacking peristalsis in the lower half of the body of the esophagus.
Clay colored stools lacking bile pigment.
An acute and self-limited inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
Constipation of sudden onset and lasting for less than three months.

A condition characterized by necrosis of the mucosal and submucosal layers of the esophagus not related to ingestion of caustic or other injurious agents. Endoscopically, there is a dark lesion ('black esophagus') distributed in a circumferential manner in the distal one-third of the esophagus with or without exudates. There is involvement of the distal esophagus ending sharply at the gastroesophageal junction.

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
An `acute` (PATO:0000389) form of `hepatic steatosis` (HP:0001397).
A `acute` (PATO:0000389) form of `pancreatitis` (HP:0001733).
Presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon.
Congenital lack, i.e., `aplasia` (MPATH:58) of the `diaphragm` (FMA:13295).
Failure to develop of the small intestine.
Congenital absence of the anus, i.e., the opening at the bottom end of the intestinal tract.
A small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. It appears as a crack or slit in the mucous membrane of the anus.
An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin.

Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation.
Abnormal narrowing of the anal opening.
A congenital anomaly in which the pancreas completely (or sometimes incompletely) encircles the second portion of duodenum and occasionally obstructs the more proximal duodenum.
An abnormality of the anus or rectum.
A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition).
Anterior malposition of the anus.

Term textual definition: Aplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
Spanish Translation: Absence of the `abdominal musculature` (FMA:86917).
column5: Aplasia de la musculatura de la pared abdominal

Term textual definition: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of the `abdominal musculature` (FMA:86917).
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la musculatura de la pared abdominal

Spanish Translation: Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the colon.
Absence or underdevelopment of the `diaphragm` (FMA:13295).
Absence or underdevelopment of the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202).
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la vesícula biliar

Spanish Translation: A congential underdevelopment (aplasia or hypoplasia) of the pancreas.
Absence or underdevelopment of the `spleen` (FMA:7196).
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.
Absence (aplasia) of the `spleen` (FMA:7196).
Failure of formation of the lumen of the gallbladder, often associated with gallbladder hypoplasia.

An abnormal change (metaplasia) in the cells of the inferior portion of the esophagus. The normal squamous epithelium lining of the esophagus is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium. Columnar epithelium refers to a cell type that is typically found in more distal parts of the gastrointestinal system.
Proliferative changes of the `bile ducts` (FMA:9706).
`Atresia` (PATO:0001819) in of the `biliary tree` (FMA:14665).
Progressive destruction of the small-to-medium bile ducts of the `intrahepatic biliary tree` (FMA:68016), which leads to progressive cholestasis and often end-stage liver disease.
A motility disorder characterized by biliary colic in the absence of gallstones with a reduced gallbladder ejection fraction.

`Hyperplasia` (MPATH:134) of the `biliary tree` (FMA:14665), as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia.
An abnormality of the `biliary tree` (FMA:14665).
A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the `biliary system` (FMA:79646).
`Obstruction` (MPATH:80) affecting the `biliary tree` (FMA:14665).
The presence of a `bilobed` (PATO:0002214) `gallbladder` (FMA:7202), related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.
A type of pigment gallstone that is hard and black, containing calcium carbonate and calcium phosphates.
The presence of `multiple` (PATO:0002118) `diverticula` (MPATH:68) of the `intestine` (FMA:7199).
Involuntary fecal soiling in adults and children who have usually already been toilet trained.
A sudden, irresistible need to have a bowel movement.
A type of pigment gallstone that is brown, containing calcium fatty acids. These stones are softer than black pigment gallstones.
The presence of `inflammatory` (PATO:0002104) changes in the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202).
Hard, pebble-like deposits that form within the `gallbladder` (FMA:7202).
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in bile ducts.
Gallstones composed primarily of cholesterol, usually about 2-3 cm in length with an oval form and a yellow or green/brown color.
