A form of `chronic gastritis` (HP:0005231) associated with `atrophic` (PATO:0001623) `gastric mucous membrane` (FMA:14907).
A form of `chronic pancreatitis` (HP:0006280) that is characterized by `calcification` (PATO:0001447).
A chronic inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
Constipation for longer than three months with fewer than 3 bowel movements per week, straining, lumpy or hard stools, and a sensation of anorectal obstruction or incomplete defecation.
The presence of chronic `diarrhea` (HP:0002014), which is usually taken to mean diarrhea that has persisted for over 4 weeks.
A `chronic` form of `gastritis` (HP:0005263).

Term textual definition: Chronic hepatitis due to cryptospridium infection
column5: Hepatitis crónica por infección de cryptospridium

Spanish Translation: A `chronic` (PATO:0001863) form of `pancreatitis` (HP:0001733).
Extravasation of chyle into the peritoneal cavity.

A chronic disorder of the `liver` (FMA:7197) in which liver tissue becomes `scarred` (PATO:0001850) and is partially replaced by regenerative nodules and fibrotic tissue resulting in loss of liver function.

Colitis refers to an inflammation of the colon and is often used to describe an inflammation of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum). Colitides may be acute and self-limited or chronic, and broadly fit into the category of digestive diseases.

A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or `atresia` (PATO:0001819) of the tubular structure of the `colon` (FMA:14543).
The presence of `multiple` (PATO:0002118) `diverticula` (MPATH:68) of the colon.
The inability of the colon to modify stool to an acceptable consistency and move the stool from the cecum to the rectosigmoid area at least once every three days.
A narrowing of a segment of colon whereby bowel continuity is maintained.
The presence of varices (enlarged and convoluted blood vessels) in the colon.
The presence of a `hernia` (MPATH:75) of the `diaphragm` (FMA:13295) present at birth.
The presence of `fibrosis` (MPATH:181) of that part of the `liver` (FMA:7197) with `congenital onset` (HP:0003577).
`Congenital` (HP:0003577) atresia of the `pylorus` (FMA:14581).
Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces.

A chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease of the intestines that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide variety of symptoms. It primarily causes abdominal pain, diarrhea which may be bloody, vomiting, or weight loss, but may also cause complications outside of the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, tiredness, and lack of concentration. Crohn's disease is thought to be an autoimmune disease, in which the body's immune system attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation.
Reduced ability of the liver to perform its functions.

Term textual definition: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
Spanish Translation: Decreased activity of complex II Of the mitochondrion in the liver.
column5: Disminución de la actividad mitocondrial del complejo iii en el tejido hepático

Spanish Translation: The presence of `degenerative` (PATO:0000639) changes of the `liver` (FMA:7197).
A delay in the development of skills required to feed oneself in the toddler period (between one and three years of age).
Interruption of the innervation of the `diaphragm` (FMA:13295).

Term textual definition: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
Spanish Translation: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes.
column5: Depleción del adn mitocondrial en el hígado

Spanish Translation: Benign, slow-growing tumors without any metastatic potential. Despite their benign nature, they can damage nearby structures causing organ dysfunction. Histologically they resemble low-grade fibrosarcomas, but they are very locally aggressive and tend to recur even after complete resection. There is a tendency for recurrence in the setting of prior surgery and the most common localisation of these tumors is intraabdominal from smooth muscle cells of the instestine.
A congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms, resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development.
The presence of a `paralyzed` (PATO:0000763) `diaphragm` (FMA:13295).
A decrease in the strength of the diaphragm.
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements.
A separation of the rectus abdominis muscle into right and left halves (which are normally joined at the midline at the linea alba).
A `diffuse` (PATO:0001513) form of `hepatic steatosis` (HP:0001397).
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the duodenal lumen, that is, an abnormal closure of the duodenum.
Wasting or decrease in size of all or part of the duodenum.
Presence of multiple polyps in the duodenum.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the duodenum.
An erosion of the mucous membrane of in a portion of the duodenum.
An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the `spleen` (FMA:7196).
Abnormal displacement or malposition of the anus.
The presence of pancreatic tissue outside the normal pancreas, in many cases along the foregut and proximal midgut.

Elevations of the levels of SGOT and SGPT in the serum. SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) are transaminases primarily found in the liver and heart and are released into the bloodstream as the result of liver or heart damage. SGOT and SGPT are used clinically mainly as markers of liver damage.
Elevations of the levels of SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) that occur during infections.
An inflammation of the colon and small intestine. However, most conditions are either categorized as Enteritis (inflammation of the small intestine) or Colitis (inflammation of the large intestine).
An `intermittent` (PATO:0000690) form of `abdominal pain` (HP:0002027).
Paroxysmal, recurrent episodes of vomiting.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the esophagus such that the esophagus ends in a blind pouch rather than connecting to the stomach.
The presence of a `carcinoma` (MPATH:549) of the `esophagus` (FMA:7131).
The presence of a `diverticulum` (MPATH:68) of the `esophagus` (FMA:7131).
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication of a portion of the muscle and submucosa of the esophagus without epithelial duplication.
A white patch or plaque occurring on the surface of the esophageal mucous membranes that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be characterized clinically as any other disease.
An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.
A pathological narrowing of the esophagus that is caused by the development of a ring of scar tissue that constricts the esophageal lumen.
Defect in the epithelium of the esophagus, essentially an open sore in the lining of the esophagus.
Extreme dilation of the submucusoal veins in the lower portion of the esophagus.

Thin (2-3mm) membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa that can be congenital or acquired. Congenital webs commonly appear in the middle and inferior third of the esophagus, and they are more likely to be circumferential with a central or eccentric orifice. Acquired webs are much more common than congenital webs and typically appear in the cervical area (postcricoid). Clinical symptoms of this condition are selective (solid more than liquids) dysphagia, thoracic pain, nasopharyngeal reflux, aspiration, perforation and food impaction (the last two are very rare).
Inflammation of the esophagus.
Impaired function of the exocrine pancreas associated with a reduced ability to digest foods because of lack of digestive enzymes.
Eversion of a hollow organ and exposure, inside out, and protruded through the abdominal wall.
`Atresia` (PATO:0001819) in the `extrahepatic bile duct` (FMA:14678).
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in large bile ducts outside the liver.
`Increased pressure` (PATO:0001576) in the `pre-hepatic portal vein` (FMA:71904).
Abnormality of the absorption of fat from the gastrointestinal tract.
Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.

Impaired feeding performance of an infant as manifested by difficulties such as weak and ineffective sucking, brief bursts of sucking, and falling asleep during sucking. There may be difficulties with chewing or maintaining attention.
column5: Dificultades para alimentarse durante la lactancia

Spanish Translation: A hernia which occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where abdominal contents pass through a naturally occurring weakness called the femoral canal.
Intermittently `increased size` (PATO:0000586) of the `liver` (FMA:7197).
Intermittently `increased size` (PATO:0000586) of the `spleen` (FMA:7196).
Increased susceptibility to Giardia lamblia infection of the intestine, as manifested by a medical history of multiple episodes of Giardia lamblia intestinal infection.

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as fulminant if there is onset of encephalopathy within 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
Acute hepatitis complicated by acute liver failure with hepatic encephalopathy occurring less than 8 weeks after the onset of jaundice.

Term textual definition: Functional abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
Spanish Translation: `Abnormal` (PATO:0000460) `functionality` (PATO:0001509) of the gastrointestinal tract.
Reduced motility of the gallbladder with reduced emptying fraction.
Gastric duplication is a usually cystic malformation of gastrointestinal tract, usually attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and has no communication with the stomach.
`Hypertrophy` (MPATH:159) of the `stomach` (FMA:7148).
An `ulcer` (MPATH:579), that is, an erosion of an area of the `gastric mucous membrane` (FMA:14907).
The presence of `inflammation` (MPATH:212) of the `gastric mucous membrane` (FMA:14907).
A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter.
`Dysplasia` (MPATH:589) affecting the vasculature of the `gastrointestinal tract` (FMA:71132).
A spherical hollow structure with a smooth muscle coat, lined by a mucous membrane, and attached to any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the base of the tongue to the anus.
Abnormal intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis, related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) affecting the `gastrointestinal tract` (FMA:71132).
`Telangiectasia` (MPATH:476) affecting the`gastrointestinal tract` (FMA:71132).
`Decreased strength` (PATO:0001779) of the `Muscle layer of stomach` (FMA:14909), which leads to a decreased ability to empty the contents of the stomach despite the absence of obstruction.

A type of congenital ventral `incomplete closure` (PATO:0000609) of the `abdominal wall` (FMA:259054) in which the intestines and sometimes other organs to extend freely into the amniotic fluid space through a small opening in the abdomen, usually to the right of the umbilicus.
Feeding problem necessitating gastrostomy tube feeding.
column5: Alimentación por sonda de gastrostomía en la infancia

Spanish Translation: A type of `gastritis` (HP:0005263) characterized by excessive proliferation of the gastric mucosa and diffuse thickening of the gastric mucosal folds.
Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas. These can occur throughout the gastrointestinal tract.
Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas located in the stomach.
The vomiting of blood.
The passage of fresh (red) blood per anus, usually in or with stools. Most rectal bleeding comes from the colon, rectum, or anus.
Bleeding into the biliary tree.
Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage.
A form of `amyloidosis` (HP:0011034) that affects the liver.
Hepatic fibrosis that reaches from a portal area to another portal area.
The presence of `fibrosis` (MPATH:181) of the `liver` (FMA:7197) tissue.

The presence of multiple granulomas in the liver as based on pathological examination. Granulomas are small 0.5 to 2 mm collections of modified macrophages called epithelioid cells usually surrounded by lymphocytes.

The presence of `steatosis` (MPATH:622) in the `liver` (FMA:7197).
Inflammation of the liver.
A kind of `neoplasm of the liver` (HP:0002896) that originates from immature liver precursor cells and macroscopically is composed of tissue resembling fetal or mature liver cells or bile ducts.

Simultaneous `enlargement` (PATO:0000586) of the `liver` (FMA:7197) and `spleen` (FMA:7196).

A malfunctioning of the `spleen` (FMA:7196) in which it prematurely destroys red blood cells.

Developmental hypoplasia of the `intestine` (FMA:7199).
Angiectasia of lymph vessels (i.e., dilatation of lymphatic vessels) in the intestines.
Fluid retention and edema in the intestine caused by a compromised lymphatic system.

A lymphoproliferative abnormality of the intestine characterized by numerous visible mucosal nodules measuring up to, and rarely exceeding, 0.5 cm in diameter Histologically, hyperplastic lymphoid follicles with large germinal centres are seen in the lamina propria and superficial submucosa. There is enlargement of the mucosal B cell follicles caused by hyperplasia of the follicle centres; surrounded by a normal appearing mantle zone. Disease may involve the stomach, the entire small intestine, and the large intestine.

An abnormality of the intestinal rotation and fixation that normally occurs during the development of the gut. This can lead to volvulus, or twisting of the intestine that causes obstruction and necrosis.
Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
The presence of multiple polyps in the intestine.
A functional rather than mechanical obstruction of the intestines.

Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in the small bile ducts within the liver.
An abnormality of the `intestine` (FMA:7199) in which part of the intestine invaginates (telescopes) into another part of the intestine.
Yellow pigmentation of the skin or sclera due to bilirubin, which in turn is the result of increased bilirubin concentration in the bloodstream.
A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or `atresia` (PATO:0001819) of the tubular structure of the `jejunum` (FMA:7207).

A deviation from the normal rotation of the midgut during embryologic development with mislocalization of the small bowel.
Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum.
Obstruction of the intestine due to abnormally thick meconium.

The passage of blackish, tarry feces associated with gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Melena occurs if the blood remains in the colon long enough for it to be broken down by colonic bacteria. One degradation product, hematin, imbues the stool with a blackish color. Thus, melena generally occurs with bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., sotmach ulcers or duodenal ulcers), since the blood usually remains in the gut for a longer period of time than with lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
A colon of abnormally small caliber.
A type of `cirrhosis` (HP:0001394) characterized by the presence of small regenerative nodules.
A form of `hepatic steatosis` (HP:0001397) characterized by the presence of small, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.
A type of `cirrhosis` (HP:0001394) characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules of a variety of sizes.

`Inflammation` (MPATH:212) of the `peritoneum` (FMA:9584).
Gallstones composed primarily of bilirubin and calcium salts (calcium bilirubinate) with a low cholesterol concentration.
Polysplenia is a congenital disease manifested by multiple small accessory spleens.
An inadequate sucking reflex, resulting in the difficult of newborns to be breast-fed.
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule.
`Increased pressure` (PATO:0001576) in the `portal vein` (FMA:66645).
Posterior malposition of the anus.
Vomiting that ejects the gastric contents with great force.

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants.
Abnormally prominent umbilicus (belly button).
Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract related to excessive leakage of plasma proteins into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.
A thrusting or bulging out of the abdomen.
A kind of congenital defect of the anterior `abdominal wall` (FMA:259054) in which the intestines are evident through the thin, lax, and protruding abdominal wall in affected infants.
An abnormal narrowing of the `pylorus` (FMA:14581).
A collection of pus in the area of the rectum.
The presence of multiple rectal hyperplastic/adenomatous polyps.
Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus.

Term textual definition: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract
Spanish Translation: `Recurrent` (PATO:0000427) infection of the `gastrointestinal tract` (FMA:71132).
A `recurrent` (PATO:0000427) form of `pancreatitis` (HP:0001733).

A contraction of the diaphragm that repeats several times per minute. In humans, the abrupt rush of air into the lungs causes the epiglottis to close, creating a hic sound. Also known as synchronous diaphragmatic flutter (SDF), or singultus, from the Latin singult, the act of catching one's breath while sobbing. The hiccup is an involuntary action involving a reflex arc.

A left-right reversal (or "mirror reflection") of the anatomical location of the major thoracic and abdominal organs.
Bleeding from the small intestine.

Abnormal small intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
column5: Alteración de la motilidad del intestino delgado

Spanish Translation: A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the small intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the small intestine.
Reduced motility through the `sphincter of Oddi` (FMA:15077), resulting in impedance of bile and pancreatic juice flow from the common bile duct into the duodenum.
A breach of the capsule of the spleen.
Abnormal `increased size` (PATO:0000586) of the `spleen` (FMA:7196).
The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus.
Greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces. This is a result of malabsorption of lipids in the small intestine and results in frothy foul-smelling fecal matter that floats.
An ulcer of the colon due to pressure and irritation from retained fecal masses.
A cancer arising in any part of the stomach.
The presence of two or more accessory spleens.
A repeated, painful urge to defecate without excreting stool.
An abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea.

A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that includes characteristic ulcers, or open sores, in the colon. The main symptom of active disease is usually constant diarrhea mixed with blood, of gradual onset and intermittent periods of exacerbated symptoms contrasting with periods that are relatively symptom-free. In contrast to Crohn's disease this special form of colitis begins in the distal parts of the rectum, spreads continually upwards and affects only mucose and submucose tissue of the colon.
Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall musculature around the umbilicus. Skin and subcutaneous tissue overlie the defect.
Ventral hernia refers to a condition in which abdominal contents protrude through a weakened portion of the abnominal wall.
The enteric villi are atrophic or absent.
Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus.
Abnormal `increased size` (PATO:0000586) of the `viscera of the abdomen` (FMA:259123).
Abnormal twisting of a portion of intestine around itself or around a stalk of mesentery tissue.
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions.

A condition in which there is increased production of gastrin by a gastrin-secreting tumor (usually located in the pancreas, duodenum, or abdominal lymph nodes) that stimulates the gastric mucosa to maximal activity, with consequent gastrointestinal mucosal ulceration.
Excessive fat around the stomach and abdomen.

column5: Radio anormal segmento superior segmento inferior

Spanish Translation: Deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
An abnormal increase or decrease of weight or an abnormal distribution of mass in the body.
A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side.

column5: Talla al nacer superior al percentil 97
Talla al nacer menor del percentil 3

column5: Talla baja desproporcionada con miembros cortos

Spanish Translation: A tall and slim body build with increased arm span to height ratio (>1.05) and a reduced upper-to-lower segment ratio (<0.85), i.e., unusually long arms and legs. The extremities as well as the hands and feet are unusually slim.
A body habitus that is tall, slim and underweight, with long legs and long arms (i.e., arm span exceeds height by 5 cm or more).
Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.

column5: Retraso en el medro en la primera infancia

Term textual definition: Increased upper to lower segment ratio

column5: Incremento del radio segmento superior inferior

Spanish Translation: An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.
The term large for gestational age applies to babies whose birth weight lies above the 90th percentile for that gestational age.

column5: Talla baja  letal con extremidades cortas

Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 2 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 3 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age.
column5: Leve retraso en el crecimiento intrauterino

Spanish Translation: A mild degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between two and three standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms.
column5: Leve retraso en el crecimiento postnatal

Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 3 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 4 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age.
column5: Moderado retraso en el crecimiento intrauterino

A moderate degree of short stature, more than -3 SD but not more than -4 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
A type of short-limbed dwarfism that is manifest beginning in the neonatal period.
column5: Talla baja neonatal con miembros cortos

Spanish Translation: Body weight that is grossly above the acceptable or desirable weight, usually due to accumulation of excess fats in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the body mass index (BMI), a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese.
Excessive postnatal growth which may comprise increased weight, increased length, and/or increased head circumference.
Slow or limited growth after birth.
A kind of `short stature` (HP:0004322) in which different regions of the body are shortened to a comparable extent.

Term textual definition: Reduced upper to lower segment ratio
Spanish Translation: Decreased ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis.
column5: Reducción del radio segmento superior inferior

Spanish Translation: Intrauterine growth retardation that is 4 or more standard deviations below average, corrected for sex and gestational age.
Severely slow or limited growth after birth, being four standard deviations or more below age- and sex-related norms.
A severe degree of short stature, more than -4 SD from the mean corrected for age and sex.

A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to "short stature" as height more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender (or below the 3rd percentile for age and gender dependent norms).
Asthenic habitus refers to a slender build with long limbs, an angular profile, and prominent muscles or bones.
Smaller than normal size according to sex and gestational age related norms, defined as a weight below the 10th percentile for the gestational age.
A height above that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
Obesity located preferentially in the trunk of the body as opposed to the extremities.
Reduction inexisting body weight.
The presence of one or more bullae on the skin, defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls.
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs (fingerprints), which are present on fingers, palms, toes, and soles.
Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity.

Hair growth from a single point on the scalp in any location other than lateral to the midline and close to the vertex of the skull.

In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth that is acquired during the course of life.

A type of cutaneous melanoma localized to the palm, sole, or beneath the nail (subungual melanoma). Acral lentiginous melanoma starts as a slowly-enlarging flat patch of discoloured skin and usually displays a size above 6 mm and often several centimetres or more in diameter upon diagnosis and variable pigmentation with a mixutre of colors including brown, and blue-grey, black and red. The surface of the lesion is initially smooth but later in the course may become thicker and irregular, and may ulcerate or bleed.
Overgrowth of the stratum corneum characterized by nodular configurations of the backs of the toes and fingers.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of skin, hair and eye (iris and retina).
Loss of hair from the head or body.
Loss of round patches of scalp hair.
Loss of all scalp hair.
Loss of all hair on the entire body.
A type of `pallor` (HP:0000980) that is secondary to the presence of `anemia` (HP:0001903).

Rapid swelling (edema) of the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, mucosa and submucosal tissues of the skin of the face, normally around the mouth, and the mucosa of the mouth and/or throat, as well as the tongue during a period of minutes to several hours. The swelling can also occur elsewhere, typically in the hands. Angioedema is similar to urticaria, but the swelling is subcutaneous rather than on the epidermis.

A vascular lesion defined histologically as one or more dilated blood vessels lying directly subepidermal and showing an epidermal proliferative reaction. Clinically, angiokeratoma presents as a small, raised, dark-red spot.
Inability to sweat.
`Aplasia` (MPATH:58) of the `nail` (FMA:54326).
Anterior cervical hypertrichosis (ACH) or 'hairy throat' refers to the presence of a tuft of terminal hair on the anterior neck, just above the laryngeal prominence.

A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin in multiple or solitary non-inflammatory, well-demarcated, oval or circular ulcers with a diameter of about 1 to 2 cm. Aplasia cutis congenita most commonly occurs on the scalp, but may present in the face, trunk, or limbs.

Term textual definition: Aplasia cutis congenita of midline scalp vertex
column5: Aplasia cutis congénita del vértice del cuero cabelludo en la línea media

Spanish Translation: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp.
column5: Aplasia cutis congénita del cuero cabelludo

Term textual definition: Aplasia cutis congenita on trunk or limbs
Spanish Translation: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the trunk or the limbs.
column5: Aplasia cutis congénita en el tronco o las extremidades

Term textual definition: Aplasia cutis congenita over parietal area
Spanish Translation: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp in the parietal area.
column5: Aplasia cutis congénita en el área parietal

Term textual definition: Aplasia cutis congenita over posterior parietal area
column5: Aplasia cutis congénita en el área parietal posterior

Term textual definition: Aplasia cutis congenita over the scalp vertex
Spanish Translation: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp vertex, often just lateral to the midline.
column5: Aplasia cutis congénita sobre el vértice del cuero cabelludo

Spanish Translation: Absence of the `sweat glands` (FMA:59152).
`Aplasia` (MPATH:58) or developmental hypoplasia of the `nail` (FMA:54326).
Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the `sweat glands` (FMA:59152).
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de las glándulas sudoríparas

Term textual definition: Aplasia/Hypoplastia of the eccrine sweat glands
Spanish Translation: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the `eccrine sweat glands` (FMA:59154).
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de las glándulas sudoríparas ecrinas

Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of the `toenail`(FMA:54328).

Term textual definition: Areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation that do not follow Blaschko lines
column5: Áreas de hipopigmentación e hiperpigmentación que no siguen líneas blaschko
Defectos de la piel asimétricos, lineales
Xantoma en piel secundario a las alteraciones de los lípidos

Spanish Translation: A chronic inflammatory genetically determined disease of the skin manifested by lichenification, excoriation, and crusting, mainly on the flexural surfaces of the elbow and knee.

Term textual definition: Atypical nevi (>5mm with irregular edge and pigmentation)
column5: Nevus atípicos (> 5 mm con borde irregular y pigmentación)

Term textual definition: Atypical nevi in non-sun exposed areas
column5: Nevus atípicos en zonas no expuestas al sol

Spanish Translation: Atypically `scarred` (PATO:0001850) `skin` (FMA:7163) .

Term textual definition: Axillary and groin hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation
column5: Hiperpigmentación e hipopigmentación axilar y de la ingle

Spanish Translation: Developmental hypoplasia of the `apocrine sweat glands` (FMA:59155) in the region of the `axilla` (FMA:24864).
An epidermoid cyst in the armpit.
The presence of a `basal cell carcinoma` (MPATH:234) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).
A digit with two nails, with at least some soft tissue between them.

column5: Ronchas o manchas de pigmentación de la piel

Spanish Translation: Fragile, easily breakable hair, i.e., with reduced tensile strength.
Fragile, easily breakable scalp hair.
Increased width of nail.

An ecchymosis (bruise) refers to the skin discoloration caused by the escape of blood into the tissues from ruptured blood vessels. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to bruising. The corresponding phenotypic abnormality is generally elicited on medical history as a report of frequent ecchymoses or bruising without adequate trauma.
Cafe-au-lait spots are hyperpigmented lesions that can vary in color from light brown to dark brown with smooth borders and having a size of 1.5 cm or more in adults and 0.5 cm or more in children.

A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection.
Persistent overgrowth of Candida albicans in the gastrointestinal tract.
Chronic infection of the nails by Candida species.
column5: Infección crónica de las uñas por monilias

Spanish Translation: Recurrent or persistent superficial Candida infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and nails.
A thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of the skin, in the region surrounding the nails.
Hair shafts are rough in texture.
The natural longitudinal (posterodistal) convex arch is not present or is inverted.

Term textual definition: Confetti hypopigmentation pattern of lower leg skin
column5: Patrón de hipopigmentación en confeti de la piel de la pierna

Spanish Translation: A congenital abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.

Term textual definition: Congenital absence of skin of limbs
column5: Ausencia congénita de la piel de las extremidades

Spanish Translation: Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset.

An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin that presents at birth or shortly thereafter with generalized, erythema, blistering, erosions, and peeling. In the subsequent months, erythema and blistering improves but patients go on to develop hyperkeratotic scaling that is especially prominent along the joint flexures, neck, hands and feet.

Term textual definition: Congenital curved nail of fourth toe
column5: Uñas encurvada congénita del cuarto dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: The giant congenital nevus is greater than 8 cm in size, pigmented and often hairy. A giant congenital nevus is smaller in infants and children, but it usually continues to grow with the child.
An `ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin` (HP:0008064) with `congenital onset` (HP:0003577).

column5: Ausencia localizada de la piel congénita

Spanish Translation: The term collodion baby applies to newborns who appear to have an extra layer of skin (known as a collodion membrane) that has a collodion-like quality. It is a descriptive term, not a specific diagnosis or disorder (as such, it is a syndrome). Affected babies are born in a collodion membrane, a shiny waxy outer layer to the skin. This is shed 10-14 days after birth, revealing the main symptom of the disease, extensive scaling of the skin caused by hyperkeratosis. With increasing age, the scaling tends to be concentrated around joints in areas such as the groin, the armpits, the inside of the elbow and the neck. The scales often tile the skin and may resemble fish scales.
Loss of hair in the occipital region of the scalp with congenital onset.
A confluent, generalized overgrowth of silvery blonde to gray lanugo hair at birth.
Connective tissue nevi are hamartomas in which one or several components of the dermis is altered.
The contour of the foot in lateral profile has a convex shape.
column5: Empeine convexo del dorso del pie / empeine

Spanish Translation: The presence of `leiomyoma` (MPATH:425) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).
The presence of `leiomyosarcoma` (MPATH:426) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).
The presence of a `melanoma` (MPATH:359) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).

An increased sensitivity of the skin to light. Photosensitivity may result in a rash upon exposure to the sun (which is known as photodermatosis). Photosensitivity can be diagnosed by phototests in which light is shone on small areas of skin.
Wrinkled, redundant, inelastic and sagging skin.

A reticular discoloration of the skin with cyanotic (reddish-blue appearing) areas surrounding pale central areas due to dilation of capillary blood vessels and stagnation of blood within the vessels. Cutis marmorata, also called livedo reticularis, generally occurs on the legs, arms and trunk and is often more severe in cold weather.
A bluish or purplish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes due to an increase in the amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood or a structural defect in the hemoglobin molecule.
The presence of `fewer` (PATO:0001999) than normal `sweat glands` (FMA:59152).
column5: Disminución del número de glándulas sudoríparas

Term textual definition: Decreased sweating due to autonomic dysfunction
column5: Disminución del sudor debido a una disfunción autonómica

Spanish Translation: Narrow, paramedian longitudinal depressions in the plantar skin of the forefoot.
The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the `skin of sole of foot` (FMA:37849).
Deeply placed nails.
Partial or complete wasting (atrophy) of the skin.
An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility.

An exaggerated wealing tendency when the skin is stroked, that is, formation of red, itchy bumps and lines on the skin as a result of pressure on the skin (for instance, stroking the skin with a pen or tongue depressor).

Term textual definition: Desquamation of skin soon after birth
column5: Descamación de la piel inmediatamente después del nacimiento

Spanish Translation: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) with a diffuse localization.

Term textual definition: Discrete 2 to 5-mm hyper- and hypopigmented macules
column5: Máculas hiper e hipopigmentadas de 2 a 5 mm

Spanish Translation: Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair.
Skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture.
The presence of misshapen or partially destroyed nail plates, often with accumulation of soft, yellow keratin between the dystrophic nail plate and nail bed, resulting in elevation of the nail plate.
Toenail changes apart from changes of the color of the toenail (nail dyschromia) that involve partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.
Loss of scalp hair at an earlier than normal age.
Photosensitivity of the skin occurring early in life.
Ectodermal dysplasia is a group of conditions in which there is abnormal development of the skin, hair, nails, teeth, or sweat glands.

Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the elbow region.
Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood.
Thickening of the epidermal layer of the skin.
The presence of one or more `cysts` (MPATH:62) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).
Intermittent episodes of abnormally increased perspiration.

Eruptive xanthomas are yellow-orange-to-red-brown papules that are often surrounded by an erythematous halo. They appear in crops on the buttocks, extensor surfaces of the extremities, and flexural creases. Acutely, variable amounts of pruritus and pain occur.
Increased susceptibility to erysipelas, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of erysipelas, which is a superficial infection of the skin, typically involving the lymphatic system.
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
An erythematous eruption commonly associated with drug reactions or infection and characterized by inflammatory nodules that are usually tender, multiple, and bilateral.

An inflammatory exfoliative dermatosis involving nearly all of the surface of the skin. Erythroderma develops suddenly. A patchy erythema may generalize and spread to affect most of the skin. Scaling may appear in 2-6 days and be accompanied by hot, red, dry skin, malaise, and fever.

Term textual definition: Excessive skin wrinkling on dorsum of hands and fingers
column5: Arrugas en la piel excesivas en el dorso de las manos y los dedos
Arrugamiento excesivo de la piel palmar

Spanish Translation: Redness of the skin of the face, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.

column5: Rubor facial después de la ingesta de alcohol

Spanish Translation: Excess facial hair.
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the face.

Term textual definition: Facial telangiectasia in butterfly midface distribution
Spanish Translation: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution.
column5: Telangiectasia facial con distribución en mariposa

Spanish Translation: Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face.
A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected.
The presence of two to five cafe-au-lait macules.
column5: Manchas de color café con leche escasas

Spanish Translation: Hair that is fine or thin to the touch.

column5: Pigmentación de la piel reticulada fina

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the development of the fingernails.
Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers.
column5: Telangiectasias en las puntas de los dedos

Spanish Translation: Lichenification affecting primarily flexural areas of the skin.

A skin condition characterized by excessive development of keratin in hair follicles, resulting in rough, cone-shaped, elevated papules resulting from closure of hair follicles with a white plug of sebum.
Nails that easily break.

column5: Pecas en las áreas expuestas al sol

Spanish Translation: Absence of hair in the anterior midline and/or parietal areas.
Presence of a cutaneous lipoma on the forehead.
Upward and/or sideward growth of anterior hair.
A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation with partially separated nails, each with a separate lateral radius of curvature.
An abnormality of the skin that is not localized to any one particular region.
Abnormally increased hair growth over much of the entire body.
Generalized excessive, abnormal hairiness.
Reduced pigmentation of hair diffusely.
Reduced or lacking hair growth in a generalized distribution.
The presence of large spherical melanosomes (1 to 6 micrometer in diameter) in the cytoplasm of melanocytes.
An uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation originating in a hair follicle, which is an epidermal adnexal structures responsible for hair growth.

Term textual definition: Hair shafts flattened at irregular intervals and twisted through 180 degrees about their axes
column5: Tallo del cabello aplanado a intervalos irregulares y retorcido en 180 grados alrededor de su eje

Spanish Translation: Abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair (androgenic hair).

column5: Queratodermia palmoplantar en panal de abeja

Spanish Translation: When viewed on end (with the finger tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the fingernail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
When viewed on end (with the digit tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the nail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
A condition in which the skin can be stretched beyond normal, and then returns to its initial position.
Abnormal excessive perspiration (sweating).

Hyperkeratosis is thickening of the outer layer of the skin, the stratum corneum, which is composed of large, polyhedral, plate-like envelopes filled with keratin which are the dead cells that have migrated up from the stratum granulosum.

Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans (HLP), also known as Flegel disease, is a keratinization abnormality characterized by small, asymptomatic erythematous papules that leave characteristic punctate bleeding when they become detached. The lesions generally occur symmetrically along the top of the foot and on the legs, appearing more rarely on the arms, forearms, palms, and soles, and even on the oral mucosa.
A hyperpigmented circumscribed area of change in normal skin color without elevation or depression of any size.

column5: Hiperpigmentación en áreas expuestas al sol

Spanish Translation: A darkening of the skin related to an increase in melanin production and deposition.
Hypertrichosis is increased hair growth that is abnormal in quantity or location.

column5: Hipertrofia de la piel de las plantas de los pies

Spanish Translation: Abnormally diminished capacity to sweat.

Hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots") are white or lighter patches of skin that may appear anywhere on the body and are caused by a lack of melanin. White ash leaf-shaped macules are considered to be characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.
A reduction of skin color related to a decrease in melanin production and deposition.

column5: Manchas hipopigmentadas de la piel en los brazos

Spanish Translation: A nail of the fifth finger that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped `nail of little finger` (FMA:54341).
column5: Hipoplasia de la uña del quinto dedo de la mano

Spanish Translation: Underdeveloped nails of the fifth toes.
column5: Hipoplasia de la uña del quinto dedo del pie

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of a `fingernail`(FMA:54327).
Underdevelopment of the sweat glands.
A thumbnail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped `thumb nail` (FMA:54329).
column5: Hipoplasia de la uña del pulgar

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the `toenail`(FMA:54328).
column5: Hipoplasia de la uñas del pie
Hipoplasia o ausencia de glándulas sebáceas

Spanish Translation: Congenital lack of hair growth.
Reduced or lacking hair growth of the scalp.
An abnormality of the skin characterized the presence of excessive amounts of dry surface scales on the skin resulting from an abnormality of keratinization.

Term textual definition: Increased groin pigmentation with raindrop depigmentation
column5: Hiperpigmentación de la ingle con depigmentación en gota de lluvia
Aumento del número de los pliegues de la piel

Spanish Translation: The presence of `inflammation` (MPATH:212) of the `skin` (FMA:7163). That is, an abnormality of the skin resulting from the local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes.
Excessive growth of a nail laterally into the nail fold.
The formation of bullae (blisters) with cleavage in the `lamina lucida` (FMA:62921) layer of the skin.
column5: Separación dermo-epidérmica al nivel de la lámina lúcida

Spanish Translation: A systemic disease which can present with cutaneous lesions with or without internal involvement. Tumors are caused by Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).

Presence of one or more keloids. A keloid is a sharply elevated, irregularly shaped, progressively enlarging scar resulting from formation of excessive amounts of collagen in the dermis during connective tissue repair.

column5: Falta de elasticidad de la piel

Term textual definition: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
Spanish Translation: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders.
column5: Manchas café con leche con bordes irregulares

Spanish Translation: A subtype of melanoma in situ that typically develops on sun-damaged skin. The lesion is typically a large, irregularly pigmented macule that has developed from an ordinary lentigo (a small pigmented spot on the skin with a clearly-defined edge). Change to a malignant lentigo typically takes place over 20 years or more, and many patients accept the change as a consequence of aging.
White discoloration  of the `nails` (FMA:54326).
Thickening and hardening of the epidermis seen with exaggeration of normal skin lines.

Term textual definition: Linear arrays of macular hyperkeratoses in flexural areas
column5: Disposición linear o en rayas de hiperqueratosis macular en áreas de flexión

Spanish Translation: A type of `nevus sebaceous` (HP:0010815) with a linear form, raised borders and yellowish color.
Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution.
A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the lumbar region.
Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region.

Term textual definition: Macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches
column5: Hipopigmentación en rayas, manchas o remolinos

Spanish Translation: A flat, distinct, discolored area of skin less than 1 cm wide that does not involve any change in the thickness or texture of the skin.

Term textual definition: Melanin pigment aggregation in hair shafts
column5: Acumulación de pigmento de melanina en los tallos del cabello

Spanish Translation: A oval and round, colored (usually medium-to dark brown, reddish brown, or flesh colored) lesion. Typically, a melanocytic nevus is less than 6 mm in diameter, but may be much smaller or larger.
Brown or black discoloration  of the `nails` (FMA:54326).
Presence of multiple small cysts containing keratin (skin protein) and presenting as tiny pearly-white bumps just under the surface of the skin.

Term textual definition: Mixed hypo- and hyperpigmentation of the skin
column5: Hipo e hiperpigmentación mixta de la piel

Spanish Translation: Bluish-grey, spongy nodules associated with scars over pressure points and easily traumatized areas like the elbows and knees.
Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area.

An exanthema consisting of widespread pink-to-red macules (flat spots of 2-10 mm in diameter) or papules (red bumps) that blanch with pressure. The macules and papules may cluster and merge to form sheets over several days.
Isolated patches of hardened skin (scleroderma).
Patchy and irregular skin pigmentation.

Term textual definition: Mottled pigmentation of the trunk and proximal extremities
column5: Pigmentación moteada del tronco y extremidades proximales

Spanish Translation: `Telangiectasia` (HP:0001009) of the mucosa, the mucous membranes which are involved in absorption and secretion that line cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs.
The presence of six or more cafe-au-lait spots.
The presence of `multiple` (PATO:0002118) `leiomyomas` (MPATH:425) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).
Presence of an unusually high number of lentigines (singular: lentigo), which are flat, tan to brown oval spots.
Presence of multiple trichilemmomata, a benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
Telangiectases in the area of the `nails` (FMA:54326).
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `nail` (FMA:54326).

Onychodystrophy (nail dystrophy) refers to nail changes apart from changes of the color (nail dyschromia) and involves partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.
Small (typically about 1 mm or less in size) depressions on the dorsal nail surface.
Decreased width of nail.

Term textual definition: Neonatal wrinkled skin of hands and feet
column5: Piel arrugada de manos y pies neonatal

Spanish Translation: A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the `skin` (FMA:7163).
A nevus is a type of hamartoma that is a circumscribed stable malformation of the skin.

A macular lesion on the side of the face, involving the conjunctiva and eyelids, as well as the adjacent facial skin, sclera, oculomotor muscles, and perisoteum. Histological features vary from those of a Mongoloian spot to those of a blue nevus.

A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly.
A type of melanoma that starts as a raised area that is usually dark blackish-blue or bluish-red but may not have any color.
Pale reddish slightly elevated papules and plaques of 0.5-3 cm in diameter and not accompanied by pruritus.
Thickened nails without deformity.
Thickened toenails.
column5: Onicogriposis de las uñas de los pies

Spanish Translation: Detachment of the nail from the nail bed.
Detachment of the distal fingernails from the nail bed.
column5: Onicolisis de la región distal de las uñas

Spanish Translation: A squamous cell carcinoma that originates in the oropharnyx.
column5: Carcinoma de células escamosas de la orofaringe

Spanish Translation: The presence of multiple subcutaneous `lipoma` (MPATH:417) that cause pain.
Abnormally `pale` (PATO:0000328) `skin` (FMA:7163).
`Hyperkeratosis` (HP:0000962) affecting the palm of the hand.
An abnormally increased perspiration on palms and soles.
Abnormal thickening of the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
A tumor of the skin or mucous membrane with finger-like projections.
A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
Abnormal formation of the keratinocytes of the epidermis characterized by persistence of nuclei, incomplete formation of keratin, and moistness and swelling of the keratinocytes.

The nail disease paronychia is an often-tender bacterial or fungal hand infection or foot infection where the nail and skin meet at the side or the base of a finger or toenail. The infection can start suddenly (acute paronychia) or gradually (chronic paronychia).
Absence of melanin pigment in various areas, which is found at birth and is permanent. The lesions are known as leucoderma and are often found on the face, trunk, or limbs.
Reduced pigmentation of hair in patches.
A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in whichonly certain areas of the palms and soles are affected.
Subcutaneous nodules that are located in the vicinity of joints.
Inflammation surrounding hair follicles.
A type of `eczema` (HP:0000964) that occurs in the lips and perioral area.

Petechiae are pinpoint-sized reddish/purple spots, resembling a rash, that appear just under the skin or a mucous membrane when capillaries have ruptured and some superficial bleeding into the skin has happened. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to developing petechiae.
Piebaldism is characterized by stable and persistent, well-circumscribed depigmented patches present at birth affecting the skin of the face, trunk, and extremities in a symmetrical distribution.

column5: Anomalías de pigmentación de la piel expuesta al sol

Spanish Translation: Uncombable hair.
Pili (from Latin pilus, hair) torti (from Latin tortus, twisted) refers to short and brittle hairs that appear flattened and twisted when viewed through a microscope.

Term textual definition: Plantar crease between first and second toes
Spanish Translation: The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the `skin of sole of foot` (FMA:37849) located between the first and second toe.
column5: Pliegue plantar entre el primer y segundo dedos del pie

Spanish Translation: `Hyperkeratosis` (HP:0000962) affecting the sole of the foot.
The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the `skin of sole of foot` (FMA:37849).
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located on the `skin of sole of foot` (FMA:37849).
Poikiloderma refers to a patch of skin with (1) reticulated hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, (2) wrinkling secondary to epidermal atrophy, and (3) telangiectasias.
Circumscribed depigmentation of the hair of the head or the eyelashes.
A reduced ability to heal cutaneous wounds.
A clonal disorder of keratinization with one or multiple atrophic patches surrounded by a clinically and histologically distinctive hyperkeratotic ridgelike border called the cornoid lamella.
A type of ichthyosiform erythroderma with postnatal onset.
Development of gray hair at a younger than normal age.
The presence of an increased degree of wrinkling (irregular folds and indentations) of the skin as compared with age-related norms.

A type of ulcer that is caused when an area of skin is subject to pressure over a prolonged period of time, ranging in range in severity from patches of discolored skin to open wounds that expose the underlying bone or muscle. The most common sites are the sacrum, coccyx, heels and the hips.
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the tibial region.
A diffuse, non-pitting edema and thickening of the skin usually on the anterior aspect of the lower legs spreading to the dorsum of the feet.
A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
Progressive loss of hair.
Progressively reduced or lacking hair growth.
A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips or toe tips.
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus.
A skin abnormality characterized by  redness and irritation, with thick, red skin that displays flaky, silver-white patches (scales).

column5: Hiperqueratosis punteada de palmas y plantas

Spanish Translation: Purpura (from Latin: purpura, meaning "purple") is the appearance of red or purple discolorations on the skin that do not blanch on applying pressure. They are caused by bleeding underneath the skin. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to developing purpura. Purpura are larger than petechiae.
A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells.
Any manifestation of a skin disease associated with the production of pus.

Term textual definition: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails

Connective tissue naevi are uncommon skin lesions that occur when the deeper layers of the skin do not develop correctly or the components of these layers occur in the wrong proportion. A form of telangiectasis characterized by a central elevated red dot the size of a pinhead, representing an arteriole, with numerous small blood vessels that radiate out thereby resembling the legs of a spider. Spanish Translation: Multiple, localized or widespread, asymptomatic or inflammatory dermal cysts involving the pilosebaceous units. Lesions can appear anywhere on the body, but steatocystoma multiplex is more commonly involved with those areas of the skin with a high density of developed pilosebaceous units (e.g., the axilla, groin, neck, and proximal extremities).

Spanish Translation: Thinned, erythematous, depressed bands of atrophic skin. Initially, striae appear as flattened and thinned, pinkish linear regions of the skin. Striae tend to enlarge in length and become reddish or purplish. Later, striae tend to appear as white, depressed bands that are parallel to the lines of skin tension. Striae distensae occur most often in areas that have been subject to distension such as the lower back, buttocks, thighs, breast, abdomen, and shoulders.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair.

An abnormality of the base of the skull, which forms the floor of the cranial cavity and separates the brain from other facial structures. The skull base is made up of five bones: the ethmoid, sphenoid, occipital, paired frontal, and paired parietal bones, and is subdivided into 3 regions: the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossae. The petro-occipital fissure subdivides the middle cranial fossa into 1 central component and 2 lateral components.
