Anteriorly-facing nostrils viewed with the head in the Frankfurt horizontal and the eyes of the observer level with the eyes of the subject. This gives the appearance of an upturned nose (upturned nasal tip).
A congenital defect characterized by absence of the `Maxilla` (FMA:9711).
Absence of the `nasal bone` (FMA:52745).
Complete absence of all nasal structures.
Absence of the parotid gland.
Absence of the `Premaxilla` (FMA:76869), which is the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla.
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyelid.

Term textual definition: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the skull
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de los huesos del cráneo

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment or absence of the nose or parts thereof.
Absence or underdevelopment of a cranial sinus or sinuses.
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyebrow.
Absence or underdevelopment of `frontal sinus` (FMA:57417).
column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de los senos frontales

Spanish Translation: Absence or underdevelopment of the mandible.
Absence or underdevelopment of the `Maxilla` (FMA:9711).
Absence or underdevelopment of the `nasal bone` (FMA:52745).
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal septum.
Absence or underdevelopment of the `premaxilla` (FMA:76869).
Absence or underdevelopment of the `tongue` (FMA:54640).
Underdevelopment or absence of the `uvula` (FMA:55022).
Asymmetry observed in the face of a neonate or infant whose face appears symmetric at rest and asymmetric during crying as the mouth is pulled downward on one side while not moving on the other side.
Lack of symmetry between the left and right `mandible` (FMA:52748).
Asymmetry between the left and right portions of the maxilla.
The presence of an `asymmetric` (PATO:0000616) `mouth` (FMA:49184).
Asymmetry or size difference between the left and right nostril.
A congenital defect in the occipital region of the skull, covered by skin of the scalp and containing meninges or remnants of glial or neural tissues.

Symmetrical vermiform facial atrophy that affects mainly the forehead, the chin, the ear lobes and helices. Atrophodermia vermiculata is characterized by erythema and follicular plugs on the cheeks, developing into painless reticular impressions.

Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.
Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum.

Projection of the tip of the dens more than 5 mm above a line joining the hard palate to the posterior lip of the foramen magnum (Chamberlain's line) or the tip of the dens is greater than 7 mm above McGregor's line (the back of the hard palate to the lowest point of the occipital squama).
Synostosis affecting the right and the left coronal suture.
A splitting of the nasal tip. Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal tip.
Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip.
`Tongue` (FMA:54640) with a median apical indentation or fork.
`Uvula` (FMA:55022) separated into two parts most easily seen at the tip.
Premature synostosis of both lambdoid sutures.
Bilateral absence (atresia) of the posterior nasal aperture (choana).
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on the left and right sides.
Cleft lip and cleft palate affecting both sides of the face.
column5: Hendidura de labio y paladar bilateral

Spanish Translation: Nonmidline cleft palate on the left and right sides.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of both eyes.
A narrowing of the biparietal diameter (i.e., of the transverse distance between the protuberances of the two parietal bones of the skull).
Bilateral temporal scarlike defects, which are said to resemble forceps marks.
Inflammation of the eyelids.

Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads.
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures.
A focal dystonia that affects the muscles of the eyelids and brow, associated with involuntary recurrent spasm of both eyelids.

An `abnormality of skull shape` (HP:0002648) characterized by a `decreased anterior-posterior diameter` (PATO:0002042). That is, a cephalic index greater than 81%. Alternatively, an apparently shortened anteroposterior dimension (length) of the head compared to width.
Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus.

A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region.
A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft.

A congenital branchial sinus is a remnant of the embryonic branchial arches and their intervening clefts and pouches that has failed to regress completely. Sinuses typically have their external orifice inferior to the ramus of the mandible. They may traverse the parotid gland, and run in close vicinity to the facial nerve in the external auditory canal.
Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.
Increased width of the columella.
Regional increase in the width (height) of the eyebrow.
Bizygomatic (upper face) and bigonial (lower face) width greater than 2 standard deviations above the mean (objective); or an apparent increase in the width of the face (subjective).
Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently increased distance between the two sides of the forehead.
Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 SD above the mean (objective); or an apparently increased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).
Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow.
Increase in width of the `nasal tip` (FMA:59518).
Increased side-to-side width of the neck.

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
`Increased width` (PATO:0000600) of the skull.
Increased width of the `uvula` (FMA:55022) (subjective finding).
Increased volume and globular shape of the anteroinferior aspect of the nose.
Excessive growth of the `calvaria` (FMA:52800).
Caries is a multifactorial bacterial infection affecting the structure of the tooth. This term has been used to describe the presence of more than expected dental caries.
An odontogenic tumor of the `cementum of tooth` (FMA:55630).

A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect.
Stagnation of head growth seen as flattening of the head circumference curve.
column5: Cese del crecimiento de la cabeza

Spanish Translation: A chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland. A chalazion or meibomian cyst appears as a painless tuberous swelling in the upper lid without loss of eyelashes.
Enlargement of the zygomatic process of the temporal bone of the skull, which forms the middle and lateral inferior orbital margin.

Underdevelopment of the `zygomatic bone` (FMA:52747). That is, a reduction in size of the zygomatic process of the temporal bone of the skull, which forms the middle and lateral inferior orbital margin.
Inflammation of the lip.
A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the `chin` (FMA:46495).
H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.
column5: Pliegue en forma de H en la barbilla

Spanish Translation: Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest.
Absence or abnormal closure of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Abnormal narrowing of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Chronic inflammation of the bronchi.
Chronic inflammation of the nasal mucosa.

Term textual definition: Chronic rhinitis due to narrow nasal airway
column5: Rinitis crónica debido a vía aérea nasal estrecha

Spanish Translation: A chronic form of `sinusitis` (HP:0000246).
The presence of a notch in the margin of the `ala nasi` (FMA:59519).
A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower or upper eyelid.
A bony defect in the skull base.
column5: Hendidura de la base del cráneo

Spanish Translation: A gap in the lower lip.
Midline deficiency of the mandible and some or all overlying tissues.
Incomplete fusion of the chin, resulting from a developmental defect and manifesting as a midline cleft or fissure of the chin.

Cleft palate is a developmental defect of the `palate` (FMA:54549) resulting from a failure of fusion of the palatine processes and manifesting as a separation of the roof of the mouth (soft and hard palate).

Cleft of the soft palate (also known as the velum, or muscular palate) as a result of a developmental defect occurring between the 7th and 12th week of pregnancy. Cleft soft palate can cause functional abnormalities of the Eustachian tube with resulting middle ear anomalies and hearing difficulties, as well as speech problems associated with hypernasal speech due to velopharyngeal insufficiency.
column5: Hendidura del paladar blando (velo del paladar)

Spanish Translation: A gap in the `upper lip` (FMA:59817). This is a congenital defect resulting from nonfusion of tissues of the lip during embryonal development.
`Trilobar` (PATO:0002241) skull configuration when viewed from the front or behind.

Absence of fine and sharp appearance of brows, nose, lips, mouth, and chin, usually because of rounded and heavy features or thickened skin with or without thickening of subcutaneous and bony tissues.
A depression located at an oral commissure.
Nasal ridge curving posteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip.
Facial diplegia (that is, bilateral facial palsy) with congenital onset).
Microcephaly (HP:0000252) that is present already at the time of birth.
A congenital form of torticollis resulting from shortening of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and leading to a limited range of motion in both rotation and lateral bending.
An abnormal `conical` (PATO:0002021) morphology of the `incisor tooth` (FMA:12823).
An abnormal `conical` (PATO:0002021) morphology of the primary or permanent mandibular incisors.
An abnormal `conical` (PATO:0002021) morphology of either `maxillary primary incisor tooth` (FMA:84214) or `maxillary permanent incisor tooth` (FMA:55712) or both.
An abnormal `conical` (PATO:0002021) morphology of the primary incisor.
An abnormal `conical` (PATO:0002021) form of the `teeth` (FMA:12516), that is, a tooth whose sides converge or taper together incisally.
Nasal ridge curving anteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip. The nose appears often also prominent, and the columella low.
Premature closure of the `coronal suture of skull` (FMA:52928).
Asymmetry of the bones of the skull.
Excessive growth of the `bones of cranium` (FMA:71325), i.e., of the skull.
Asymmetry of the bones of the skull and the face.
A characteristic appearance resulting from defective ossification of craniofacial bones.
Excessive growth of the craniofacial bones.

Craniosynostosis refers to the premature closure of the cranial sutures. Primary craniosynostosis refers to the closure of one or more sutures due to abnormalities in skull development, and secondary craniosynostosis results from failure of brain growth.
A type of dental misalignment with `crowded` (PATO:0000619) central incisors, i.e., of `maxillary secondary incisor` (FMA:55712), or of `maxillary central primary incisor` (FMA:84216).

Cryptophthalmos is a condition of total absence of eyelids and the skin of forehead is continuous with that of cheek, in which the eyeball is completely concealed by the skin, which is stretched over the orbital cavity.
Abnormally curly or curved eyelashes.

Term textual definition: Curved linear dimple below the lower lip
column5: Hoyuelo lineal curvo debajo del labio inferior

Spanish Translation: The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the `scalp` (FMA:46494), resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction.
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
A cystic lymphatic lesion of the `neck` (FMA:7155).
Dagger-shaped calcifications in the `dental pulp` (FMA:55631).
column5: Calcificaciones en forma de daga de la pulpa dentaria

Spanish Translation: A congenital brain malformation typically characterized by incomplete formation of the cerebellar vermis, dilation of the fourth ventricle, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. In layman's terms, Dandy Walker malformation is a cyst in the cerebellum (typically symmetrical) that is involved with the fourth ventricle. This may interfere with the ability to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain, resulting in hydrocephalus. Dandy Walker cysts are formed during early embryonic development, while the brain forms. The cyst in the cerebellum typically has several blood vessels running through it connecting to the brain, thereby prohibiting surgical removal.
Abnormal reduction in ossification of the calvaria (roof of the skull consisting of the frontal bone, parietal bones, temporal bones, and occipital bone).
column5: Disminución de la osificación de la bóveda craneal
Disminución de la osificación del base del cráneo

Spanish Translation: A reduced degree of voluntary and involuntary facial movements involved in responded to others or expressing emotions.
A reduction in the magnitude or amount of ossification of the skull.
column5: Disminución de la osificación del cráneo

Spanish Translation: Accentuated, prominent philtral ridges giving rise to an exaggerated groove in the midline between the nasal base and upper vermillion border.
An `eye` (FMA:54448) that is more deeply recessed into the plane of the face than is typical.

Term textual definition: Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
Spanish Translation: A delay in closure (ossification) of the anterior fontanelle, which generally undergoes closure around the 18th month of life.
column5: Retraso del cierre de la fontanela anterior

Spanish Translation: Infants normally have two fontanels at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures, and the posterior fontanelle at the intersection of the occipital and parietal bones. The posterior fontanelle usually closes by the 8th week of life, and the anterior fontanel closes by the 18th month of life on average. This term applies if there is delay of closure of the fontanelles beyond the normal age.
column5: Retraso del cierre de la sutura craneal

Spanish Translation: `Delayed` (PATO:0000502) `tooth eruption` (MeSH:D014078) affecting the `secondary dentition` (FMA:55654).
column5: Retraso en la erupción de los dientes permanentes

Spanish Translation: `Delayed` (PATO:0000502) `tooth eruption` (MeSH:D014078) affecting the `primary dentition` (FMA:75151).
column5: Retraso en la erupción de los dientes primarios

Spanish Translation: `Delayed` (PATO:0000502) `tooth eruption` (MeSH:D014078), which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD beyond the mean eruption age.
column5: Retraso en la erupción de los dientes

Term textual definition: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
Spanish Translation: An abnormally reduced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the `mastoid process` (FMA:52872) with respect to age-dependent norms.
column5: Retraso en la neumatización diferida de la apófisis mastoides

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the incisor characterized by invagination of the enamel, giving a radiographic appearance that suggests a tooth within a tooth.
An abnormal increase of density of the bones making up the calvaria.
column5: Aumento de la densidad ósea de la bóveda craneal

Spanish Translation: Overlapping teeth within an alveolar ridge.
The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel.
column5: Fositas o muescas (pits) del esmalte dental

Spanish Translation: Dental malocclusion refers to an abnormality of the occlusion, or alignment, of the teeth and the way the upper and lower teeth fit together, resulting in overcrowding of teeth or in abnormal bite patterns.
`Developmental dysplasia` of `dentin` (FMA:55628).

Term textual definition: Dentinogenesis imperfecta limited to primary teeth
Spanish Translation: `Developmental dysplasia` of `dentin` (FMA:55628) affecting only the `primary dentition` (FMA:55655).
column5: Dentinogénesis imperfecta limitada a los dientes primarios

Term textual definition: Dentinogenesis imperfecta of primary and permanent teeth
Spanish Translation: `Developmental dysplasia` of `dentin` (FMA:55628) or both the `primary dentition` (FMA:55655) and the `permanent dentition` (FMA:55654).
column5: Dentinogénesis imperfecta de los dientes primarios y permanentes

Spanish Translation: Posterior positioning of the `glabella` (FMA:52851), i.e., of the midline forehead between the supraorbital ridges.
Posterior positioning of the nasal root in relation to the overall facial profile for age.
Lack of prominence of the nose resulting from a posteriorly-placed nasal ridge.
Decreased distance from the nasal tip to the nasal base.
Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge.
Positioning of the nasal septum to the right or left in contrast to the normal midline position of the nasal septum.
Nasal tip positioned to one side of the midline.
Increased space between two adjacent teeth in the same dental arch.

column5: Dificultad en los movimientos de la lengua

Spanish Translation: An abnormal indentation of the skin in the region of the nasal tip.
The presence of `discolored` (PATO:0000331) lateral incisors.
Double rows of eyelashes.
An abnormality of the gestures or movements executed with the facial muscles with which emotions such as fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and disgust can be expressed.

An `abnormality of skull shape` (HP:0002648) characterized by a `increased anterior-posterior diameter` (PATO:0002043), i.e., an increased antero-posterior dimension of the skull. Cephalic index less than 76%. Alternatively, an apparently increased antero-posterior length of the head compared to width. Often due to premature closure of the sagittal suture.
A characteristic facial appearance with a round facial form, full cheeks, a short nose, and a relatively small chin.
This may present as a partial or complete duplication of the eyebrows.
A dental anomaly characterized by the presence of a two fused teeth.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations below the mean.
A morphological `abnormality of the mouth` (HP:0000153) in which the `angle of the mouth` (FMA:77269) is downturned. The oral commissures are positioned inferior to the midline labial fissure.
column5: Comisuras de la boca de oblicuidad descendente

Spanish Translation: Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth.
A turning outward of the lip or lips, that is, eversion of the lips.
An outward turning (eversion) or rotation of the eyelid margin.

Term textual definition: Elevated imprint of the transverse sinuses
column5: Impronta elevada de los senos transversos

Spanish Translation: This is a description previously used to describe a facial form characterized by a short, upturned nose, wide mouth, widely spaced eyes, and full cheeks. Because of the imprecision in this definition it is preferable to describe these features precisely. This term is retained because it was often used in the past, but it should not be used for new annotations.
A neural tube defect characterized by sac-like protrusions of the brain and the membranes that cover it through openings in the skull.
Increased aperture of the `nostril` (FMA:59645).
Increased size of the parotid gland.
column5: Aumento del tamaño de la glándula parótida

Spanish Translation: An inward turning (inversion) of the eyelid margin.
Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva.
A fold of skin starting above the medial aspect of the upper eyelid and arching downward to cover, pass in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
A fold of skin starting at or just below the medial aspect of the lower lid and arching upward to cover, extend in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
Epistaxis, or nosebleed, refers to a `hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) localized in the`nose` (FMA:46472).

Euryblepharon is a congenital eyelid anomaly characterized by horizontal enlargement of the palpebral fissure. The eyelid is shortened vertically compared with the horizontal dimension, with associated lateral canthal malpositioning and lateral ectropion abnormally wide lid opening.

Term textual definition: Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids
column5: Eversión del tercio lateral del párpado inferior

Spanish Translation: An abnormal configuration of the `lower lip` (FMA:59818) such that it is turned outward i.e., `everted` (PATO:0001597), with the Inner aspect of the lower lip vermilion (normally opposing the teeth) being visible in a frontal view.
column5: Eversión del bermellón del labio inferior

Spanish Translation: Inner aspect of the upper lip vermilion (normally apposing the teeth) visible in a frontal view, i.e., the presence of an `everted` (PATO:0001597) `upper lip` (FMA:59817).
column5: Eversión del bermellón del labio superior

Spanish Translation: More pronounced paramedian peaks and median notch of the Cupid's bow.
Increased depth of the median tongue furrow.
column5: Surco medio de la lengua exagerado

Term textual definition: Extension of eyebrows towards upper eyelid
Spanish Translation: The eyebrows extend towards - or even all the way down to - the margin of the upper eyelid.
column5: Extensión de las cejas hacia párpado superior

Term textual definition: Extension of hair growth on temples to lateral eyebrow
Spanish Translation: A pattern of hair growth in which there is hair exnteding from the temples to the lateral eyebrows.
column5: Extensión del crecimiento del pelo en la región temporal hacia las cejas

Spanish Translation: Bony defects situated along the cranial suture lines or at the junction of the bone plates of the skull.
An abnormal difference between the left and right sides of the face.
A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the face.
Facial diplegia refers to bilateral facial palsy (bilateral facial palsy is much rarer than unilateral facial palsy).
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the face.
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the `facial skeleton` (FMA:53673).
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the midline region of the face.
column5: Hemangioma facial de la línea media

Spanish Translation: Facial myokymia is a fine fibrillary activity of the facial muscles.

Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form.

Term textual definition: Facial palsy secondary to cranial hyperostosis
Spanish Translation: Paralysis of the facial nerves on the basis of overgrowth of the cranial bones causing impingement upon the seventh cranial nerve.
column5: Parálisis facial secundaria a hiperostosis craneal

Spanish Translation: Complete loss of ability to move facial muscles innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve).
Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face.

Term textual definition: Failure of eruption of permanent teeth
Spanish Translation: Lack of `tooth eruption` (MeSH:D014078) of the `secondary dentition` (FMA:55654).
column5: Ausencia de erupción de los dientes permanentes

Spanish Translation: The presence during the prenatal period of a cystic mass with multiple septa with multiple, asymmetric, thin-walled cysts near the posterior aspect of the neck. Fetal cystic hygroma can be defined as nuchal translucency with or without septations measuring greater than 3.0 mm.
Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges.
Absence of concavity or convexity of the face when viewed in profile.
A forehead with abnormal flatness.

An abnormal degree of flatness of the `Ala of nose` (FMA:59519), which can be defined as a reduced nasal elevation index (lateral depth of the nose from the tip of the nose to the insertion of the nasal ala in the cheek x 100 divided by the side-to-side breadth of the nasal alae).
Reduced convexity of the `occiput` (FMA:49187) (posterior part of skull).
An abnormally flat sella turcica.
Underdevelopment of the `frontal bone` (FMA:52734).
Bilateral bulging of the lateral frontal bone prominences with relative sparing of the midline.
Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.
Reduced strength of the frontalis muscle (which is located on the forehead).
column5: Debilidad muscular de los músculos de la frente

Spanish Translation: Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible.
Increased bulk of tissue alongside the nose. The fullness can be caused by both bony and soft tissues.
Accentuation of the grooves on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
column5: Aumento de los surcos del dorso de la lengua

Spanish Translation: Lack of separation of the upper and lower lips.
The union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected dental arch.
A congenital defect with an abnormal joining of the gums of the upper and lower jaw.
The development of two teeth from a single tooth bud, leading to a larger fused tooth.
A `generalized` (PATO:0001513) form of developmental hypoplasia of the `dental enamel` (FMA:55629).
A generalized form of `microdontia` (HP:0000691).
A generalized form of `periodontitis` (HP:0000165).

column5: Granuloma de células gigantes de la mandíbula

Spanish Translation: `Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) affecting the `gingiva` (FMA:59762).
The presence of `fibrosis` (MPATH:181) of the `gingiva` (FMA:59762).
`Hyperkeratosis` (MPATH:154) of the `gingiva` (FMA:59762).

`Hyperplasia` (MPATH:134) of the `gingiva` (FMA:59762, that is, a thickening of the soft tissue overlying the alveolar ridge. The degree of thickening ranges from involvement of the interdental papillae alone to gingival overgrowth covering the entire tooth crown.
`Inflammation` (MPATH:212) of the `gingiva` (FMA:59762).
Inflammation of the tongue.
Posterior displacement of the tongue into the pharynx, i.e., a `tongue` (FMA:54640) that is `mislocalised posteriorly` (PATO:0001922).
A `grey` (PATO:0000950) `discoloration` (PATO:0000331) of the `dental enamel` (FMA:55629).
A green staining of teeth.
Noticeably unpleasant odors exhaled in breathing.
Unilateral atrophy of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
Unilateral overgrowth of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
Unilateral underdevelopment of the  facial tissues, including muscles and bones.
Increased length and width of one half of the tounge.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
An abnormally increased height of the forehead.
Insertion of the posterior columella superior to the nasal base.
Height of the palate more than 2 SD above the mean (objective) or palatal height at the level of the first permanent molar more than twice the height of the teeth (subjective).
Hair on the neck extends less inferiorly than usual.
The presence of a high and narrow palate.
Increased height of the central portion of the eyebrow, forming a crescent, semicircular, or inverted U shape.
column5: Aumento del arqueamiento de las cejas

Spanish Translation: An acute purulent infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or the meibomian sebacious glands often caused by staphylococcus infections. Hordeola can either occur as Hordeola externa affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or as Hordeola interna affecting the meibomian sebacious glands. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painful and can cause extreme local swelling.

Hordeola externa are acute purulent infections affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.

Hordeola interna are acute purulent infections affecting the meibomian sebacious glands, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia (chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland), hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.
An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve.
Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the `calvaria` (FMA:52800) and the `base of skull` (FMA:52801 ).
Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the `frontal bone` (FMA:52734).
Interpupillary distance more than 2 SD above the mean (alternatively, the appearance of an increased interpupillary distance or widely spaced eyes).
A form of `hypomineralization of enamel` (HP:0006285) characterized by reduced calcification.
A developmental anomaly characterized by a `reduced number of` (PATO:0001999) teeth, whereby up to 6 teeth are missing.
A form of `hypomineralization of enamel` (HP:0006285) characterized by a chalky appearance of the enamel with orange, brown, or white color.
A `decreased amount` (PATO:0001997) of `enamel mineralization` (GO:0070166).
Developmental hypoplasia of the `dental enamel` (FMA:55629).
Developmental hypoplasia of `teeth` (FMA:12516).

Term textual definition: Hypoplasia of the anterior nasal spine
Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the `anterior nasal spine of maxilla` (FMA:75770).
column5: Hipoplasia de la espina nasal anterior

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the `lower eyelid` (FMA:54442).
Underdevelopment of the `Maxilla` (FMA:9711).

column5: Nariz grande con forma de pico

Spanish Translation: Increased size of the  ocular globe (eyeball).

In newborns, the two frontal bones, two parietal bones, and one occipital bone are joined by fibrous sutures, which form a small posterior fontanelle, and a larger, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle. These regions allow for the skull to pass the birth canal and for later growth. The fontanelles gradually ossify, whereby the posterior fontanelle usually closes by eight weeks and the anterior fontanelle by the 9th to 16th month of age. Large fontanelles are diagnosed if the fontanelles are larger than age-dependent norms.
An abnormal increase in the size of the foramen magnum.
An enlargement of the `posterior fontanelle` (FMA:75440) relative to age-dependent norms.
An abnormal enlargement of the `sella turcica` (FMA:54709).
An eyebrow that extends laterally beyond the orbital rim rather than turning gently downward at that location.
Synostosis affecting only the left coronal suture.
Premature synostosis of only the left lambdoid suture.

column5: Limitación de la flexión del cuello

Spanish Translation: Increased focal pigmentation of the vermilion of the lips.
A depression located on a lip.
`Telangiectasia` (MPATH:476) (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the `lips` (FMA:59815).
Multiple indentations and/or elevations on the edge and/or surface of the tongue producing an irregular surface contour.
A `localized` (PATO:0000627) form of developmental hypoplasia of the `dental enamel` (FMA:55629).
A `localized` (PATO:0000627) form of `periodontitis` (HP:0000165).
Increased length of the hairs of the eyebrows.

Increased length of the upper eyelashes.

Increased length of the `uvula` (FMA:55022).

Insertion of the posterior columella below the nasal base.

Term textual definition: Metopic suture patent to nasal root
Spanish Translation: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root.

Spanish Translation: Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.

A type of encephalocele (that is, a a protrusion of part of the cranial contents including brain tissue through a congenital opening in the cranium, typically covered with skin or mucous membrane) in the occipital region of the skull. Occipital encephalocele presents as a midline swelling over the occipital bone.   It is usually covered with normal full-thickness scalp.

A developmental anomaly characterized by a `reduced number of` (PATO:0001999) teeth, whereby more than 6 teeth are missing.

The presence of a cleft in the oral cavity, the two main types of which are cleft lip and cleft palate. In cleft lip, there is the congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse, forming a groove or fissure in the lip. In cleft palate, there is a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly, forming a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately.
A white patch on the oral mucosa that cannot be rubbed off.
Fibrous band between the mucosal surfaces of the upper and lower alveolar ridges.
Erosion of the mucous mebrane of the mouth with local excavation of the surface, resulting from the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.

Presence of a cyst in the region of the orbita. Orbital cysts can be derived from epithelial or glandular tissue within or surrounding the orbit (lacrimal glands, salivary glands, conjunctival, oral, nasal, or sinus epithelium).
A face with a rounded and slightly elongated outline.
Maxillary teeth cover the mandibular teeth when biting to an increased degree.
Positioning of the nasal tip inferior to the nasal base.
An abnormal anteroposterior extension of the maxillary teeth beyond the plane of the mandibular teeth upon jaw closure.
Oxycephaly (from Greek oxus, sharp, and kephalos, head) refers to a conical or pointed shape of the skull.
A fistula which connects the oral cavity and the pharyngeal area via the aspects of the soft palate.

Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations below the mean, or alternatively, an apparently decreased length from the nasal root to the nasal tip.
Distance between the medial and lateral canthi is more than 2 SD below the mean for age (objective); or, apparently reduced length of the palpebral fissures.

Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border.
`Decreased width` (PATO:0000599) of the `upper lip` (FMA:59817).
Decreased length of the uvula.
Incisors with a thick marginal ridge surrounding a deep lingual fossa are termed shovel-shaped incisors.
column5: Incisivos centrales superiores en forma de pala

Spanish Translation: The presence of a single, median maxillary incisor, affecting both the `primary maxillary incisor` (FMA:84214) and the `permanent maxillary incisor` (FMA:55712).
The presence of only a single `nostril` (FMA:59645).
Inflammation of the `paranasal sinuses` (FMA:59679) owing to a viral, bacterial, or fungal infection, allergy, or an autoimmune reaction.

A localized defect in the bone of the skull resulting from abnormal embryological development. The defect is covered by normal skin. In some cases, skull x-rays have shown underlying lytic bone lesions which have closed before the age of one year.

Inclination of the anterior surface of the forehead from the vertical more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently excessive posterior sloping of the forehead in a lateral view.
Scalp hair whose growth is slower than normal.
column5: Crecimiento lento del pelo del cuero cabelludo

Spanish Translation: Abnormally decreased size of  the `anterior fontanelle` (FMA:75439) with respect to age-dependent norms.
A face that is short (HP:0011219) and narrow (HP:0000275).
An abnormally small and flat configuration of the posterior cranial fossa.
A fontanelle that is small for age.
An abnormal narrowing of the `foramen magnum` (FMA:75306).
The presence of a forehead that is abnormally small.
An abnormally small sella turcica.
Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border.
Glossy appearance of the entire tongue surface.
Decreased number of `head hairs` (FMA:54241) per unit area on the anterior region of the scalp.
column5: Pelo escaso en zona anterior del cuero cabelludo

Spanish Translation: Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
Decreased density/number of eyelashes.
Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of lateral eyebrow hairs.
column5: Ceja poco pobladas en su porción lateral

Spanish Translation: Decreased number of `head hairs` (FMA:54241) per unit area.
column5: Escasez del pelo del cuero cabelludo

Spanish Translation: Anosmia for one particular odor.
Facial contours, as viewed from the front, show a broad upper face/cranium and lower face/mandible, creating a square appearance.
Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth.

Hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the bony palate that are covered by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth. It may be possible to detect a submucous cleft hard palate upon palpation as a notch in the bony palate.
A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane.
A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.
Lack or loss of the soft tissues between the zygomata and mandible.
The presence of a `supernumerary` (PATO:0000470), i.e., extra, maxillary incisor, either the `primary maxillary incisor` (FMA:84214) or the `permanent maxillary incisor` (FMA:55712).
The presence of more than two nostrils.
Meeting of the medial `eyebrows` (FMA:54237) in the midline.
Talon cusp is an accessory cusp located near the cingulum (the portion of the lingual or palatal aspect of the tooth that forms a convex protuberance at the cervical third of the anatomic crown).
`Increased volume` (PATO:0000595) of `dental pulp` (FMA:55631) of `permanent molar` (FMA:84207).
`Telangiectasia` (MPATH:476) (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the oral mucosa.
Distance between the inner canthi more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparently increased distance between the inner canthi.
Fusion of the mandibular condyle to the base of the skull, resulting in limitation of jaw opening.
Noises from the temporomandibular joint during mandibular movement (e.g., chewing). Temporomandibular joint crepitus is often described as a clicking,  popping, grating sound.
Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.
column5: Filtro con forma de V invertida

Spanish Translation: Triangular appearance of the oral aperture with the apex in the midpoint of the upper vermilion and the lower vermilion forming the base.
column5: Bermellón labial con forma de V invertida

Spanish Translation: Increased density/number and/or increased diameter of eyebrow hairs.

Increased thickness of the lower lip, leading to a prominent appearance of the lower lip. The height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the midline is more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi.
Abnormally increased thickness of the nasal septum.

Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Increased width of the "skin of vermilion border region of upper lip" (FMA:312645).
The presence of an abnormally thick calvaria.

A thickening of the skin thickness in the posterior aspect of the fetal neck. A nuchal fold measurement is obtained in a transverse section of the fetal head at the level of the cavum septum pellucidum and thalami, angled posteriorly to include the cerebellum. The measurement is taken from the outer edge of the occiput bone to the outer skin limit directly in the midline. A measurement 6 mm or more is considered significant between 18 and 24 weeks and a measurement of 5 mm or more is considered significant at 16 to 18 weeks (pmid:16100637).
column5: Engrosamiento de los pliegues cutáneos de la nuca

Spanish Translation: The presence of an abnormally thin calvarium.

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lower lip more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Reduced width of the "skin of vermilion border region of upper lip" (FMA:312645).

Term textual definition: Thinning and bulging of the posterior fossa bones
column5: Adelgazamiento y abultamiento de los huesos de la fosa posterior

Spanish Translation: Wasting of the `tongue` (FMA:54640).
Fasciculations or fibrillation affecting the tongue muscle.
`Telangiectasia` (MPATH:476) (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the tongue.
Involuntary contractions of the `neck musculature` (FMA:71290) resulting in an abnormal posture of or abnormal movements of the head.
A bony protrusion present on the midline of the hard palate.
Inability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation.
Reduced ability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation.
A horizontal cleft of the face, varying from slight widening of the mouth, to a cleft extending to the ear.
Facial contour, as viewed from the front, triangular in shape, with breadth at the temples and tapering to a narrow chin.
The presence of a `triangular` (PATO:0001875) form of the `mouth` (FMA:49184).
Inversion and rubbing of the eyelashes against the globe of the eye.
Wedge-shaped, or triangular head, with the apex of the triangle at the midline of the forehead and the base of the triangle at the occiput.
Limitation in the ability to open the mouth.
Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts.  No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination.
Tall head relative to width and length.
Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures.
column5: Bermellón del labio superior en forma de U

Spanish Translation: Thinned, deficient, or excessively arched `ala nasi` (FMA:59519).

Reduced bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion or commissure).
Flatness of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.
The presence of one or more embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt.
Synostosis affecting only one of the coronal sutures.
Premature synostosis of only one lambdoid suture.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on one side only.
One-sided weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye.
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures on one side only.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the `upper eyelid` (FMA:54439).
Edema in the region of the upper eyelid.
Depression located on the vermilion of the upper lip, usually paramedian.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, the inclination of the palpebral fissure is greater than typical for age.
Oral commissures positioned superior to the midline labial fissure.
Inability of velopharyngeal sphincter to sufficiently separate the nasal cavity from the oral cavity during speech.
An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum).
Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest.
Reduced strength of the `orbicularis oculi` (FMA:46779), the circumorbital muscle in the face that closes the eyelid.
column5: Debilidad del músculo orbicular de los párpados

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of facial morphology characterized by a small mouth opening and constant contraction of the lips as if the patient were whistling.
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyebrow.
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyelashes.
Enlargement of the `anterior fontanelle` (FMA:75439) with respect to age-dependent norms.
An abnormally increased width of the cranial sutures for age-related norms (generally resulting from delayed closure).
Distance between the oral commissures more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
Increased distance between the attachments of the alae nasi to the face.
Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root).
Increased width of the nasal ridge.
Interalar distance more than two standard deviations above the mean for age, i.e., an apparently increased width of the nasal base and alae.
The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
column5: Persistencia de la sutura coronal no osificada

Spanish Translation: An abnormally increased width of the cranial fontanelles and sutures.
The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
column5: Persistencia de la sutura sagital no osificada

Spanish Translation: Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia.
Increased spaces (diastemata) between most of the teeth in the same dental arch.
Increased distance between the `maxillary central permanent incisor tooth` (FMA:55722).
Frontal hairline with bilateral arcs to a low point in the midline of the forehead.
The presence of extra bones within a cranial suture. Wormian bones are irregular isolated bones which appear in addition to the usual centers of ossification of the cranium.
The presence of xanthomata in the skin of the eyelid.
Dryness of the mouth due to salivary gland dysfunction.
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that deviates from normal.
An anomaly in the amount or timing of melatonin secretion by the pineal gland. Note that melatonin is also synthesized by multiple tissues outside of the pineal gland.
An abnormal increase or decrease in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
A deviation from the normal size of the `pituitary gland` (FMA:13889).
column5: Tamaño anormal de la glándula pituitaria

Spanish Translation: Any structural anomaly of the `adrenal glands` (FMA:9604).
A functional abnormality of the `adrenal glands` (FMA:9604).
An `abnormal` (PATO:0000460) `concentration` (PATO:0000033) of `corticotropin` (CHEBI:3892) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de adrenocorticotropina

Spanish Translation: An abnormal `catecholamine` (CHEBI:33567) concentration in the blood.
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de catecolaminas

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the concentration of `corticosterone` (CHEBI:16827) in the blood.
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de corticosterona

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the concentration of `cortisol` (CHEBI:17650) in the blood.
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de cortisol

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the concentration of a `glucocorticoid` (CHEBI:24261) in the blood.
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de glucocorticoides

Spanish Translation: An `abnormal` (PATO:0000460) `concentration` (PATO:0000033) of a `hormone` (CHEBI:24621) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de hormonas circulantes

Spanish Translation: An `abnormal` (PATO:0000460) `concentration` (PATO:0000033) of `leptin` (PRO:000009758) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Alteración del nivel plasmático de leptina

Spanish Translation: A structural abnormality of the `pineal gland` (FMA:62033).
A functional abnormality of the `pineal gland` (FMA:62033).
An abnormality of the `renin-angiotensin system` (FMA:74787).
Abnormality of the `adrenal glands` (FMA:9604), i.e., of the endocrine glands located at the top of the kindneys.
An abnormality of the `adenohypophysis` (FMA:74627), which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
Ab abnormality of the `endocrine system` (FMA:9668).

Abnormality of the pituitary gland (also known as hypophysis), which is an endocrine gland that protrudes from the bottom of the hypothalamus at the base of the brain. The pituitary gland secretes the hormones ACTH, TSH, PRL, GH, endorphins, FSH, LH, oxytocin, and antidiuretic hormone. The secretion of hormones from the anterior pituitary is under the strict control of hypothalamic hormones, and the posterior pituitary is essentially an extension of the hypothalamus, so that  hypothalamus and pituitary gland may be regarded as a functional unit.
An abnormality of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).
A structural abnormality of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).
A functional abnormality of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).
An anomaly of the `pineal gland` (FMA:62033),a small endocrine gland in the brain that produces melatonin.
An anomaly of the `pituitary gland` (FMA:13889).
An abnormality of the `neurohypophysis` (FMA:74628), which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.
An abnormality of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
A structural abnormality of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
column5: Alteración de la morfología del tiroides

Spanish Translation: An abnormal `functionality` (PATO:0001509) of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
An `abnormal` (PATO:0000460) `concentration` (PATO:0000033) of a `hormone` (CHEBI:24621) in the urine.
column5: Alteración del nivel de hormonas en la orina

Spanish Translation: No secondary sexual characteristics are present at puberty.
Accessory ectopic thyroid tissue arising from remnants of the thyroglossal duct anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct tract.
Gain-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.
column5: Déficit del receptor de la hormona estimulante de la tiroides (TSHR) defecto

Spanish Translation: Calcification within the `adrenal glands` (FMA:9604).
Absent development of the adrenal gland.
Abnormal development of the adrenal gland.
Enlargement of the adrenal gland.
Developmental hypoplasia of the `adrenal glands` (FMA:9604).
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands as a result of a primary defect in the glands themselves.
Developmental hypoplasia of the `adrenal medulla` (FMA:15633).
Adrenocortical adenomas are benign tumors of the adrenal cortex.
A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone.
The presence of large polyhedral cells with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei in the adrenal cortex.
A reduced ability to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), a hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete of glucocorticoids such as cortisol.
Overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which generally leads secondarily to overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal cortex.
Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in ACTH production.
column5: Insuficiencia suprarrenal por déficit de adrenocorticotropina (ACTH)

Spanish Translation: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the ACTH receptor.

Adrenogenital syndrome is also known as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which results from disorders of steroid hormone production in the adrenal glands leading to a deficiency of cortisol. The pituitary gland reacts by increased secretion of corticotropin, which in turn causes the adrenal glands to overproduce certain intermediary hormones which have testosterone-like effects.
Failure to develop of the pineal gland, defined clinically as the absence of the pineal gland with no indication of the pineal gland even having been present.
Insufficient amount of androgenic activity.

A condition of reduced function of the pituitary gland characterized by decreased secretion of one or more of the pituitary hormones growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone.
Absence of the pituitary gland resulting from a developmental defect.
Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland, also known as the `adenohypophysis` (FMA:74627).
Underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland.
A type of hypoparathyroidism with circulating antiparathyroid or anti-calcium sensing receptor antibodies indicative of autoimmunity.
A tumor formed from the endocrine (argentaffin) cells of the mucosal lining of a variety of organs including the stomach and intestine. These cells are from neuroectodermal origin.
A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected.
A form of diabetes insipidus related to a failure of vasopressin (AVP) release from the hypothalamus.

A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects.
A type of `adrenal hyperplasia` (HP:0008221) with `congenital onset` (HP:0003577).
A type of `adrenal hypoplasia` (HP:0000835) with `congenital onset` (HP:0003577).
An enlargement of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603) with `congenital onset` (HP:0003577).
Deficiency of parathyroid hormone with congenital onset.
A type of `hypothyroidism` (HP:0000821) with `congenital onset` (HP:0003577).
Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in corticotropin-releasing hormone production.
column5: Insuficiencia suprarrenal por déficit de hormona liberadora de corticotropina (CRH)

Spanish Translation: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor.
column5: Déficit del receptor de hormona liberadora de corticotropina (CRHR)

Spanish Translation: A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is lower than normal.
An `abnormal` (PATO:0000460) reduction in the `concentration` (PATO:0000033) of `corticotropin` (CHEBI:3892), also known as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Déficit del nivel de ACTH circulante

Spanish Translation: A decreased level of `aldosterone` (CHEBI:27584) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Déficit del nivel de aldosterona circulante

Spanish Translation: Abnormally reduced concentration of `cortisol` (CHEBI:17650) in the blood.
column5: Déficit del nivel de cortisol circulante

Spanish Translation: An decreased level of renin (PRO:000013883) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Déficit del nivel de renina circulante

Spanish Translation: An abnormal reduction in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
A `decreased concentration` (PATO:0001163) of `leptin` (PRO:000009758) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
Passing the age when puberty normally occurs with no physical or hormonal signs of the onset of puberty.
A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone can be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone.

A state of excessive water intake and hypotonic (dilute) polyuria. Diabetes insipidus may be due to failure of vasopressin (AVP) release (central or neurogenic diabetes insipidus) or to a failure of the kidney to respond to AVP (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).
A group of abnormalities characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance.
A type of diabetic metabolic abnormality with an accumulation of ketone bodies.
An early onset of puberty, in this case early does not refer to precocious.
Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland.
An abnormal anatomical location of the anterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the `adenohypophysis` (FMA:74627).
Abnormal anatomic location of the anterior pituitary gland.
An abnormal anatomical location of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).

An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the `neurohypophysis` (FMA:74628). The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis.
`Mislocalised` (PATO:0000628) `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
An abnormal increase in `catecholamine` (CHEBI:33567) concentration in the blood.
An abnormal increased concentration of parathyroid hormone.
column5: Nivel circulante de hormona paratiroidea (PTH) elevado

Spanish Translation: An elevated concentration of follicle-stimulating hormone in the blood.
column5: Nivel de FSH (hormona estimulante del folículo) elevado

Spanish Translation: An elevated concentration of luteinizing hormone in the blood.
An abnormally increased size of the `pituitary gland` (FMA:13889).
A `goiter` (HP:0000853) that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities.
An `abnormality of thyroid physiology (`HP:0002926) characterized by increased levels of `thyroxine` (CHEBI:30660) without evidence of clinical thyroid disease.
An `increased concentration` (PATO:0001162) of `insulin` (PRO:000009054) in the `blood` (FMA:9670) in the fasting state, i.e., not as the response to food intake.
The presence of an `follicular adenocarcinoma` (MPATH:278) of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone cannot be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone or similar glucocorticoids.
column5: Hiperaldosteronismo primario no sensible a glucocorticoides

Spanish Translation: An enlargement of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).

A reduced ability to secrete gonadotropins, which are re protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary gland, including the hormones follitropin (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
Overproduction of gonadotropins (FSH, LH) by the anterior pituitary gland.

An autoimmune disease where the thyroid is overactive, producing an excessive amount of thyroid hormones (a serious metabolic imbalance known as hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis). This is caused by autoantibodies to the TSH-receptor (TSHR-Ab) that activate that TSH-receptor (TSHR), thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, and thyroid growth (causing a diffusely enlarged goiter). The resulting state of hyperthyroidism can cause a dramatic constellation of neuropsychological and physical signs and symptoms, which can severely compromise the patients.
Insufficient production of growth hormone, which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland. Growth hormone is a major participant in control of growth and metabolism.

Acromegaly is a condition resulting from overproduction of growth hormone by the pituitary gland in persons with closed epiphyses, and consists chiefly in the enlargement of the distal parts of the body. The circumference of the skull increases, the nose becomes broad, the tongue becomes enlarged, the facial features become coarsened, the mandible grows excessively, and the teeth become separated. The fingers and toes grow chiefly in thickness.
A chronic, autoimmune type of `thyroiditis` (HP:0100646) associated with `hypothyroidism` (HP:0000821).
A kind of `thyroid adenoma` (HP:0000854) characterized by the presence of `oxyphil cells` (CL:0002200).
An abnormally increased activity of the renin-angiotensin system, causing hypertension by a combination of volume excess and vasoconstrictor mechanisms.
Overproduction of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone by the adrenal cortex.

Overproduction of the hormone of `cortisol` (CHEBI:17650) by the adrenal cortex, resulting in a characteristic combination of clinical symptoms termed Cushing syndrome, with truncal obesity, a round, full face, striae atrophicae and acne, muscle weakness, and other features.
An `increased concentration` (PATO:0001162) of `insulin` (PRO:000009054) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
An `increased concentration` (PATO:0001162) of `insulin` (PRO:000009054) combined with a `decreased concentration` (PATO:0001163) of `glucose` (CHEBI:17234) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
Excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.

Hypersecretion of one or more pituitary hormones. This can occur in conditions in which deficiency in the target organ leads to decreased hormonal feedback, or as a primary condition most usually in connection with a pituitary adenoma.

An `abnormality of thyroid physiology (`HP:0002926) characterized by refers to excessive secretion of the thyroid hormones `thyroxine` (CHEBI:30660) (i.e., T4) and/or `3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine zwitterion` (CHEBI:533015) (i.e., triiodothyronine or T3).
Abnormally reduced levels of `aldosterone` (CHEBI:27584).
A reduced concentration of `cortisol` (CHEBI:17650) in the blood.
A condition caused by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
Deficiency of thyroid hormone.

column5: Alteración en la secreción de FSH y LH

Spanish Translation: Loss-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.
column5: Déficit del receptor de la hormona estimulante del tiroides (TSHR)

Spanish Translation: A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is higher than normal.
An `abnormal` (PATO:0000460) increased in the `concentration` (PATO:0000033) of `corticotropin` (CHEBI:3892), also known as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Aumento del nivel circulante de ACTH

Spanish Translation: Abnormally increased concentration of `cortisol` (CHEBI:17650) in the blood.
column5: Aumento del nivel circulante de cortisol

Spanish Translation: An increased level of renin (PRO:000013883) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
column5: Aumento del nivel circulante de renina

Spanish Translation: An abnormal elevation in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
An elevated concentration of `3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine` (CHEBI:18258) in the blood.
A `increased concentration` (PATO:0001162) of `serotonin` (CHEBI:28790) in the `blood` (FMA:9670).
Abnormally increased concentration of `cortisol` (CHEBI:17650) in the urine.
column5: Elevación del nivel de cortisol urinario

Spanish Translation: Ketosis-resistant diabetes is a synonym for type II diabetes. This term thus refers to a form of type II diabetes in which patients are dependent on insulin.

A type of diabetes mellitus related not to lack of insulin but rather to lack of response to insulin on the part of the target tissues of insulin such as muscle, fat, and liver cells. This type of diabetes is typically associated with increases both in blood glucose concentrations as will as in fasting and postprandial serum insulin levels.

column5: Diabetes mellitus resistente a insulina en la pubertad

Spanish Translation: A type of tumor of the pancreatic beta cells that secretes excess insulin and can result in hypoglycemia.

column5: Insensibilidad de las células de Leydig a la gonadotropina

Spanish Translation: An aberrant thyroid gland or `Ectopic thyroid` (HP:0100028) located at the base of the tongue (FMA:54645), just posterior to the foramen cecum as a result of a failure of the thyroid to descend.

Term textual definition: Low urinary cyclic AMP response to PTH administration
column5: Baja respuesta de AMP cíclico urinario a la administración de PTH

Spanish Translation: A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of more than 10 mm diameter.

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.

The term Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) was initially used for patients diagnosed with fasting hyperglycemia that could be treated without insulin for more than two years, where the initial diagnosis was made at a young age (under 25 years). Thus, MODY combines characteristics of type 1 diabetes (young age at diagnosis) and type 2 diabetes (less insulin dependence than type 1 diabetes). The term MODY is now most often used to refer to a group of monogenic diseases with these characteristics. Here, the term is used to describe hyperglycemia diagnosed at a young age with no or minor insulin dependency, no evidence of insulin resistence, and lack of evidence of autoimmune destruction of the beta cells.
The presence of a `medullary carcinoma` (MPATH:291) of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of less than 10 mm diameter.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland.

A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism.
Abnormal embryonic development of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).
`Hyperplasia` (MPATH:134) of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).
Developmental hypoplasia of the `parathyroid gland` (FMA:13890).
A glial uniloculated or multiloculated fluid-filled sac that either reside within or completely replace the pineal gland.
Accumulation of calcium salts in the `pineal gland` (FMA:62033).

A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern.

column5: Adenoma acidófico de células madre hipofisarias

A type of pituitary adenoma that produces adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

A type of reduced stature with normal proportions related to dysfunction of the pituitary gland related to either an isolated defect in the secretion of growth hormone or to panhypopituitarism, i.e., a deficit of all the anterior pituitary hormones.
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces gonadotropins.
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces grwoth hormone.
column5: Adenoma hipofisario de células secretoras de hormona de crecimiento

A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers.  Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.

column5: Adenoma hipofisario de células secretoras de prolactina

column5: Resistencia hipofisaria a la hormona tiroidea

A type of pituitary adenoma that produces thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).
Absence of the `neurohypophysis` (FMA:74628) owing to a developmental defect.
Abnormal development of the `neurohypophysis` (FMA:74628) during embryonic growth and development.
Underdevelopment of the `neurohypophysis` (FMA:74628).

The onset of secondary sexual characteristics before a normal age. Although it is difficult to define normal age ranges because of the marked variation with which puberty begins in normal children, precocious puberty can be defined as the onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls or 9 years in boys.
The onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls.
The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys.
Onset of adrenarche at an earlier age than usual.
The onset of growth of pubic hair at an earlier age than normal.
Premature development of the breasts.
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands as a result of a primary defect in the glands themselves.
A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland.
Hypercortisolemia associated with a primary defect of the adrenal gland leading to overproduction of cortisol.
A type of hyperparathyroidism caused by a primary abnormality of the parathyroid glands (e.g., adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia). Primary hyperparathyroidism is associated with hyercalcemia.

A reduced ability to secrete prolactin, a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production.

The presence of abnormally increased levels of prolactin in the blood. Prolactin is a peptide hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland that plays a role in breast development and lactation during pregnancy.
A state of renal tubular unresponsiveness or resistance to the action of aldosterone.

An abnormally decreased size of the `pituitary gland` (FMA:13889).

A type of hyperparathyroidism that occurs following kidney transplantation, which is a treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although kidney transplantation leads to a normalization of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone in most patients. The state of persistent hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism is referred to as tertiary hyperparathyroidism.

An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.
The presence of a `adenoma` (MPATH:270) of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
The congenital absence of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).
The presence of a `carcinoma` (MPATH:549) of the `thyroid gland` (FMA:9603).

column5: Defecto de la oxidación y organificación tiroidea de yoduro

Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to a singular nodule in the thyroid gland.

Term Name: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: A deviation from the normal contents of the platelet alpha granules, which normally contain hemostatic proteins such as fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, and growth factors such as platelet-derived growth factor.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: An anomalous location and arrangement of platelet alpha granules.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: Defective structure, size or content of alpha granules, platelet organelles that contain several growth factors destined for release during platelet activation at sites of vessel wall injury.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: An abnormal susceptibility to bleeding, often referred to as a bleeding diathesis. A bleeding diathesis may be related to vascular, platelet and coagulation defects.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: Delay in cutaneous immune reaction to specific antigens mediated not by antibodies but by cells. The delayed hypersensitivity test is an immune function test measuring the presence of activated T cells that recognize a specific antigen and is performed by injecting a small amount of the antigen into the skin. The area of the injection is examined 48-72 hours thereafter.
column5: Prueba de hipersensibilidad cutánea retardada anormal

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: A deviation from the normal contents of the platelet alpha granules, which normally contain adenosine triphosphate (ATP), adenosine diphosphate (ADP), serotonin, calcium, and pyrophosphate, which are secreted when platelets are activated.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: Defective structure, size or content of dense granules, platelet organelles that  contain granules proaggregatory factors such as adenosine diphosphate (ADP), adenosine triphosphate (ATP), ionized calcium , histamine and serotonin.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: An anomaly of the intracellular membrane complexes known as the dense tubular system.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: Anomaly in the level or the function of hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: An abnormal deviation from normal levels of immunoglobulins in blood.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: Number of leukocytes per volume of blood beyond normal limits.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: An anomaly in the number of `monocytes` (CL:0000576), which are myeloid mononuclear recirculating leukocyte that can act as a precursor of tissue macrophages, osteoclasts and some populations of tissue dendritic cells.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: A functional anomaly of the `natural killer cell` (CL:0000623).
column5: Alteración de la fisiología de las células "natural killers"

Term Identifier: Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
Spanish Translation: A deviation from the normal range of neutrophil cell counts in the circulation.

Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues

Spanish Translation: Anomalous size of platelets. Most normal sized platelets are 1.5 to 3 micrometers in diameter. Large platelets are 4 to 7 micrometers. Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers.

Abnormality of  blood and blood-forming tissues
