column5: Retinopatía pigmentaria en forma de espículas óseas

Spanish Translation: The presence of whitish spots in a ring-like arrangement at the periphery of the iris.
Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation.

Buphthalmos refers to a congenital open-angle glaucoma of the eye. The term buphthalmos (from Greek 'bous' or ox and 'ophthalmos' or eye) is descriptive of an enlarged eyeglobe resulting from increased intraocular pressure. The eyeglobe is especially prone to distension in newborns and infants because its collagen filaments are not as rigid as in adults and may easily be stretched.
Butterfly-shed retinal pigmentation at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.
column5: Distrofia del epitelio pigmentario de la retina en patrón mariposa

Spanish Translation: A cataract that affects the `capsule of the lens` (FMA:58881).
A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline `lens` (FMA:58241) of the eye or in its `capsule` (FMA:58881).

Microscopic aneurysms of the retinal arterioles near the central part of the fundus, visible as small round dark red dots on the retinal surface (not arising from visible vessels) that are by definition less than the diameter of the major optic veins as they cross the optic disc.
column5: Microaneurismas arteriolares del fondo de ojo central

Spanish Translation: The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone.
Reduced transparency of the central portion of the corneal stroma.
Reduced transparency of the central posterior portion of the corneal stroma.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of retinal blood vessels (arteries, arterioles, veins, venules).
column5: Tortuosidad vascular central de la retina

Spanish Translation: An area of depressed vision located at the point of fixation and that interferes with central vision.
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) located between the central point of fixation and the blind spot with a roughly horizontal oval shape.

Cerulean cataracts are a kind of `congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary.
Edema (swelling) of the bulbar conjunctiva.

Term textual definition: Cherry red spot of the macula
Spanish Translation: Pallor of the perifoveal macula of the retina with appearance of a small circular reddish choroid shape as seen through the fovea centralis due to relative transparancy of the macula.
column5: Mancha macular rojo cereza en la retina

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the choroid and retina.
Atrophy of the choroid and retinal layers of the fundus.
Absence of a region of the retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid.
Abnormal development of the choroid and retina.
Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina.
An inflammation of the choroid and retina.
A congenital defect in which a portion of choroid is not developed and the corresponding region of the retina is atrophic.
Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.
Degeneration of the `choroid` (FMA:58298).
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas.

Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the choroid. The classic appearance of choroidal melanoma is a pigmented dome-shaped or collar button-shaped tumor with an associated exudative retinal detachment. Choroidal melanoma is usually pigmented, but can be variably pigmented and even amelanotic (non-pigmented).
Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is the creation of new blood vessels in the choroid layer of the eye.
Choroidal sclerosis is a descriptive term applied to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of prominent white choroidal vessels in which the blood columns are not seen or are sheathed by white lines.
A chronic irritative conjunctivitis, which commonly presents with general irritation and redness of the eyes, with a burning, dry, or foreign-body sensation of the eyes.
Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the ciliary body.
A developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the `eye` (FMA:54448`) or ocular adnexa.
A tendency to hold the child elevated by about 20 to 30 degrees to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
The condition of having both rods and cones, but only a single kind of cone.  Affected individuals have good pattern vision in daylight, but cannot distinguish between colors.
A type of `Horner syndrome` (HP:0002277) with congenital onset.
Blindness with onset at birth.
A congenital `cataract` (HP:0000518).
Congenital abnormality of the `extraocular muscles` (FMA:49033).
column5: Anomalía congénita de los músculos extraoculares

Spanish Translation: Congenital non-progressive ophthalmoplegia with multiple extraocular muscle restrictions. Typically, there is ptosis and variable degrees of restriction of horizontal and vertical eye movements.
column5: Fibrosis congénita de los músculos extraoculares

Spanish Translation: Horizontal nystagmus dating from or present at birth.

Term textual definition: Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
Spanish Translation: Sharply demarcated, congenital hyperpigmentation of thr retinal pigment epithelium.
column5: Hipertrofia congénita del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Spanish Translation: Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset.
Myopia apparent at birth.
A type of `congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) in which the opacities are confined to a small central area within the embryonic or fetal nuclei of the Iens. The remaining lens is clear.
Nystagmus dating from or present at birth.
A developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the crystalline lens.
A nonprogressive (i.e., stationary) form of difficulties with night blindness with congenital onset.
A form of `amyloidosis` (HP:0011034) that affects the `conjunctiva` (FMA:59011).
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) of the conjunctiva.
A lipoma (a benign tumor composed of adipose tissue) located in the conjunctiva.
Presence of nodules in the  `conjunctiva` (FMA:59011) of the eye.
The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the conjunctiva.
The presence of whitish deposits in the  `conjunctiva` (FMA:59011) resembling salt. May be related to calcinosis.
Inflammation of the  `conjunctiva` (FMA:59011).
A 'coral-like' pattern of opacity in the lens of the eye. That is, a cataract with an irregular, stellate form.

A hazy, grayish-white ring about 2 mm in width located close to but separated from the limbus (the corneoscleral junction). Corneal arcus generally occurs bilaterally, and is related to lipid deposition in the cornea. Corneal arcus can occur in elderly persons as a part of the aging process but may be associated with hypercholesterolemia in people under the age of 50 years.
The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea.
An `abnormality of the cornea` (HP:0000481) that is characterized by opacity of one or parts of the cornea.
An erosion or abrasion of the cornea's outermost layer of epithelial cells.

Corneal guttata are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. The presence of focal thickenings of Descemet's membrane histologically named guttae. Cornea guttata can be easily diagnosed in vivo and ex vivo by means of specular microscopy as it gives dark areas where no endothelial cells are visible.
Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea.
A reduction of corneal clarity.
A rupture of the cornea through which a portion of the iris protrudes.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling of the `stroma of cornea` (FMA:58306).
Disruption of the epithelial layer of the cornea with involvement of the underlying stroma.
Developmental abnormality in which the lens and cornea are not separated.
A cataract which affects the layer of the lens surrounding the nucleus, i.e., the `lens cortex` (FMA:58970). It is identified by its unique wedge or spoke appearance.
A type of cataract characterized by punctate, dust-like opacities within the cortical region of the lens.
A form of loss of vision caused by damage to the visual cortex rather than a defect in the eye.
A form of macular degeneration characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the macula.
Cystoid macular edema (CME) is any type of macular edema that involves cyst formation.
Inflammation of the nasolacrimal sac.

An abnormally reduced response to stimulation of the cornea (by touch, foreign body, blowing air). The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex, normally results in an involuntary blinking of the eyelids.
Reduced ability of the cornea to respond to stimulation.
A decreased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
column5: Disminución del grosor de la córnea

Spanish Translation: An abnormal reduction in amplitude of the signal opf electro-oculography (EOG), which is a technique for measuring the resting potential of the retina.
Descreased amplitude of eletrical response upon electroretinography.
column5: Disminución de la amplitud en electrorretinograma (ERG)

Spanish Translation: Abnormally decreased lacrimation, that is, reduced ability to produce tears.

column5: Disminución con dispersión de la pigmentación de la retina

Spanish Translation: Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased.
A type of `posterior cortical cataract` (HP:0010924) characterized by dense lenticular opacities.

Term textual definition: Depigmented lesions of the retinal pigment epithelium
column5: Lesiones despigmentadas del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Spanish Translation: Presence of folds in the Descement membrane, which is the basement membrane of the endothelial (inner) cell layer of the cornea. Descement membrane folds are generally a manifestation of inflammation or edema of the cornea.
column5: Pliegues en la membrana de Descemet

Spanish Translation: A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with abnormal M photopigment, such that the absorption spectrum is shifted toward L wavelengths. Affected individuals have difficulties distinguishing between red and green.
Complete lack of the M photopigment, which is replaced with the L photopigment.  Affected individuals tend to confuse red and green.
Individuals affected by dichromacy possess only two types of cones, instead of three.
Opacity of the entire `lens nucleus` (FMA:58971).
A pale yellow discoloration of the entire optic disc.
Diplopia is a condition in which a single object is perceived as two images, it is also known as double vision.
Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone.
Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye.

Duane anomaly is a congenital eye movement impairment with limitation of the ability to adduct or abduct the eye. When affected eyes are adducted (moved inwards towards the nose), the eyeball retracts and the palpebral fissure narrows.
A form of colorblindness in which only two of the three fundamental colors can be distinguished due to a lack of one of the retinal cone pigments.

The controller signal for saccadic eye movements has two components: the pulse that moves the eye rapidly from one point to the next, and the step that holds the eye in the new position. When both the pulse and the step are not the correct size, a dysmetric refixation eye movement results.

Dislocation or malposition of the crystalline lens of the eye. A partial displacement (or dislocation) of the lens is described as a subluxation of the lens, while a complete displacement is termed luxation of the lens. A complete displacement occurs if the lens is completely outside the patellar fossa of the lens, either in the anterior chamber, in the vitreous, or directly on the retina. If the lens is partially displaced but still contained within the lens space, then it is termed subluxation.
A malposition of the `pupil` (FMA:58252) owing to a developmental defect of the iris.
Positioning of a lacrimal punctum other than at the medial margins of the eyelid.

column5: Potenciales visuales evocados (por flash) con latencia alargada

Spanish Translation: Abnormally big lacrimal glands.
An epibulbar dermoid is a benign tumor typically found at the junction of the cornea and sclera (limbal epibullar dermoid).

An epiretinal membrane is a thin sheet of fibrous tissue that can develop on the surface of the macular area of the retina and cause a disturbance in vision. An epiretinal membrane area can develop on the thin macular area of the retin. An epiretinal membrane is also sometimes called a macular pucker, premacular fibrosis, surface wrinkling retinopathy or cellophane maculopathy.
Inflammation of the `episclera` (FMA:58362), a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed').
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward.
Paralysis of the external ocular muscles.
A type of retinal detachment associated with leakage of fluid (exudate) from under the retina.
An area of the retina that is buckled so that a sector-shaped sheet of retina lies in front of the normal retina. This feature is of congenital onset.

column5: Pigmentación de la retina en forma de red anudada

Spanish Translation: Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age.
This term has been used as a general description of degeneration of the fovea. It is preferable to provide an exact phenotypic description.
Increased amount of pigmentation in the `fovea centralis` (FMA:58658).
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the `fovea centralis` (FMA:58658).
Splitting of the retinal layers in the macula.
Horizontal nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.
Nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.
Generalized reduced transparency of the stroma of the cornea.
Glaucoma refers loss of retinal ganglion cells in a characteristic pattern of optic neuropathy usually associated with increased intraocular pressure.

Term textual definition: Globe retraction and deviation on abduction
column5: Retracción del globo y desviación en abducción

Spanish Translation: The presence of central, fine, whitish granular lesions in the stroma of the cornea. This type of corneal dystrophy is usually asymptomatic and begins in childhood and shows a slow progression. Later in the course, the corneal epithelium and Bowman's layer may be affected. Histologically, the cornea shows a uniform deposition of hyaline material.

Gustatory lacrimation results from an aberrant innervation of fibres from the seventh cranial nerve to the pterygopalatine ganglion which are destined originally for the submandibular ganglion. This aberrant innervation leads to uncontrollable tearing while eating or in anticipation of a meal.
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the eye.
A visual defect characterized by the inability to see as clearly in bright light as in dim light. The word hemeralopia literally means day blindness.
Transient  hemianopsia associated with the aura phase of migraine.
Partial or complete loss of vision in one half of the visual field of one or both eyes.
Bleeding from vessels of the various tissues of the eye.

The presence of one or more dendritic corneal epithelial ulcers characterized by a treelike branching linear pattern with feathery edges and terminal bulbs. Herpetiform corneal ulcers can be identified by fluorescein staining.
Heterochromia iridis is a difference in the color of the `iris` (FMA:58235) in the two eyes.
A severe form of hypermetropia with over +4.00 diopters.

column5: Degeneración de la retina en panal

Spanish Translation: Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements, in which the movement in one direction is faster than in the other.
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements.
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements of equal velocity.

A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a horizontal direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
An abnormality resulting from a lesion of the sympathetic nervous system characterized by a combination of unilateral ptosis, miosis, and often ipsilateral hypohidrosis and conjunctival injection.
A saccade that overshoots the target with the dynamic saccade.
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects in the distance clearly, while objects nearby appear blurry.
A form of astigmatism in which one meridian is hyperopic while the one at a right angle to it has no refractive error.
Increased amount of pigmentation of the retina.
Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
Saccadic undershoot of horizontal saccadic eye movements, i.e., a horizontal saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
Saccadic undershoot, i.e., a saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
Decreased amount of pigmentation of the retina.
Underdevelopment of the `choroid` (FMA:58298).
Underdevelopment of the `ciliary body` (FMA:58295).
Underdevelopment of the `fovea centralis` (FMA:58658).
Congenital underdevelopment of the `iris` (FMA:58235).

Term textual definition: Hypoplasia of the iris dilator muscle
Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the `dilatator pupillae` (FMA:49158).
column5: Hipoplasia del músculo dilatador del iris

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the lacrimal puncta.
Underdevelopment of the `stroma of iris` (FMA:58526).
Reduced ability to turn the eyes inward  in order to focus on a nearby object.
An `abnormality of ocular smooth pursuit` (HP:0000617) characterized by an impairment of the ability to track horizontally moving objects.
An impaired ability of the eye to move in the outward direction (towards the side of the head).
Reduced ability to move the eye in the direction of the nose.

column5: Deterioro del inicio y mantenimiento de la búsqueda visual

Spanish Translation: An impairment of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion.
An increase in the degree of curvature of the cornea compared to normal.
column5: Aumento de la curvatura de la córnea

Spanish Translation: A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
column5: Aumento de grosor de la córnea

Spanish Translation: An elevation in the ratio of the diameter of the cup of the optic disc to the total diameter of the disc. The optic disc has an orange-pink rim with a pale centre (the cup) that does not contain neuroretinal tissue. An increase in this ratio therefoy may indicate a decrease in the quantity of healthy neuroretinal cells.
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye).
Partial displacement of the lens in the inferior direction.
Inflammation of the eye, parts of the eye or the periorbital region.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the vitreous.
Paralysis of the iris and ciliary apparatus.
A malignant melanoma originating within the eye. The tumor originates from the melanocytes in the uvea (which comprises the iris, ciliary body, and choroid).
Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself.
A type of `posterior subcapsular cataract` (HP:0007787) characterized by an iridescent color.
The presence of a coloboma of iris, choroid and retina.
A type of anterior uveitis, in which there is Inflammation of the iris and the ciliary body.
Tremulousness of the iris on movement of the eye, occurring in subluxation of the lens.
The presence of a coloboma affecting the `iris` (FMA:58235) and the retina.
Atrophy of the `iris` (FMA:58235).
A `coloboma` (HP:0000589) of the `iris` (FMA:58235).
An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid.
Reduction in the amount of blood flow to the iris.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation of the `iris` (FMA:58235).
Malignant tumor of melanocytes affecting the iris.
New growth of vessels on the surface of the iris.
A benign brown pigmented area over the iris representing proliferation of melanocyte cells in the stromal layer of the iris. An iris nevus can be flat or occasionally slightly elevated.
Shedding of the pigment granules that normally adhere to the back of the iris into the aqueous humor.
Transmission of light through the iris as visualized upon slit lamp examination or infrared iris transillumination videography. The light passes through defects in the pigmentation of the iris.
Inflammation of the `iris` (FMA:58235).
A type of cataract that is not apparent at birth but that arises in childhood or adolescence.
Grey-green or brownish-pigmented ring in the deep epithelial layers at the outer border of the cornea.
Inflammation of the cornea.
Inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva.

Dryness of the eye related to deficiency of the tear film components (aqueous, mucin, or lipid), lid surface abnormalities, or epithelial abnormalities. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca often results in a scratchy or sandy sensation (foreign body sensation) in the eyes, and may also be associated with itching, inability to produce tears, photosensitivity, redness, pain, and difficulty in moving the eyelids.
A cone-shaped deformity of the cornea.
Limbus-to-limbus corneal thinning, often greatest in the periphery, with globular protrusion of the cornea.
A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct.

A developmental disorder of the lacrimal drainage system that most often affects the lacrimal ostium and resulting in non-opening of the nasolacrimal duct. It usually results from a non-canalization of the nasolacrimal duct.
Narrowing of a tear duct (lacrimal duct).
A congenital defect of development characterized by absence of the lacrimal gland.
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland.
Abnormality of tear production.

A `congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) in which opacity is limited to layers of the lens external to the nucleus (i.e., the perinuclear region), i.e., between the nuclear and cortical layers of the lens.
A `Lamellar cataract` (HP:0007971) with a pulverulent (punctate, "dust-like" opacities) appearance.

column5: Amplio defecto central del campo visual

Spanish Translation: The presence of fine, branching linear opacities in Bowman's layer in the central area that may spread to the periphery in the clinical course. The deep corneal stroma may be involved but the process does not reach Descemet's membrane. Recurrent corneal erosion may occur. Histologic examination reveals amyloid deposits in the collagen fibers of the cornea.
Degeneration of retinal ganglion cells and their axons.
A sectoral indentation of the crystalline lens, usually due to zonular weakness or absence.
Complete dislocation of the lens of the eye.
Partial dislocation of the lens of the eye.
A conical projection of the anterior or posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging.
A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the `iris` (FMA:58235) with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape.
An abnormal white reflection from the pupil rather than the usual black reflection.
Atrophy of the `levator palpebrae superioris` (FMA:49041), the extraocular muscle that  elevates the superior eyelid.
column5: Atrofia del elevador del párpado superior

Spanish Translation: A creamy appearance of the retinal blood vessels that occurs when the concentration of lipids in the blood are extremely increased, with pale pink to milky white retinal vessels and altered pale reflexes from choroidal vasculature.
The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the `iris` (FMA:58235)..

column5: Pérdida de epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Spanish Translation: A congenital defect of the macula distinct from coloboma associated with optic fissure closure defects.
Degeneration of the `macula lutea` (FMA:58637).
Macular dystrophy is a nonspecific term for premature retinal cell aging and cell death, generally confied to the macula in which no clear extrinsic cause is evident.
Pale often indistinct lesions of the macula.
A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina.
Increased amount of pigmentation in the `macula lutea` (FMA:58637).
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the `macula lutea` (FMA:58637).
Underdevelopment of the `macula lutea` (FMA:58637).
Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the `macula lutea` (FMA:58637).
column5: Anomalía pigmentaria en moteado de la mácula lútea

Spanish Translation: Splitting of the retina in the macular region.

An enlargement of the `cornea` (FMA:58238) with normal clarity and function. Megalocornea is diagnosed with a horizontal corneal diameter of 12 mm or more at birth or 13 mm or more after two years of age.
A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens.
A visual anomaly in which images appear distorted. A grid of straight lines appears wavy and parts of the grid may appear blank.

A congenital abnormality of the `cornea` (FMA:58238) in which the cornea and the anterior segment of the eye are smaller than normal. The horizontal diameter of the cornea does not reach 10 mm even in adulthood.
Abnormal smallness of the `lens` (FMA:58241).

column5: Disminución leve de la agudeza visual

Spanish Translation: Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil.
Complete color blindness, a complete inability to distinguish colors. Affected persons cannot perceive colors, but only shades of gray.
Deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye's vitreous humour, which is normally transparent.

Term textual definition: Multiple bilateral congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
Spanish Translation: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital.
column5: Hipertrofia congénita bilateral múltiple del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Spanish Translation: Abnormal dilatation of the iris.
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects nearby clearly, while objects in the distance appear blurry.
Blockage of the ` lacrimal duct` (FMA:61063).
The presence of a `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the eye.

Term textual definition: Neovascularization of peripheral and posterior retina
column5: Neovascularización de la retina periférica y posterior

Spanish Translation: Inability to see well at night or in poor light.

An acute condition characterized by sudden visual loss (usually discovered in the morning), optic disc edema  at onset, optic disc-related visual field defects. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can be associated with flame hemorrhages on the swollen disc or nearby neuroretinal layer, and sometimes with nearby cotton-wool exudates.
column5: Neuropatía óptica isquémica anterior no arterítica

Spanish Translation: A form of `uveitis` (HP:0000554) that is not associated with the formation of granulomas.
A form or retinal dystrophy that is present at birth and does not further progress.

Nonprogressive restriction of movement of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited.

column5: Pérdida de la visión no progresiva

Spanish Translation: A nuclear cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the `lens nucleus` (FMA:58971). That is, a nuclear cataract is one that is located in the center of the lens. The nucleus tends to darken changing from clear to yellow and sometimes brown.
A type of `nuclear cataract` (HP:0008024) involving congenital pulverulent disc-like opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus.
Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.
Head movements associated with nystagmus, that may represent an attempt to compensate for the involuntary eye movements and to improve vision.
column5: Nistagmo inducido por movimiento de la cabeza (tipo asentimiento)

Spanish Translation: An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of the `iris` (FMA:58235) and retina.
Inability to follow objects visually with compensatory head movements, decreased smooth pursuit, and cancellation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
Reduced ability to control the movement of the eye associated with damage to the third cranial nerve (the oculomotor nerve).
Lack of transparency of the `corneal epithelium` (FMA:58263).
Reduced transparency of the `stroma of cornea` (FMA:58306).
column5: Opacidad del estroma de la córnea

Spanish Translation: Ophthalmoplegia is a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the muscles that control eye movement.

Spontaneous, non-rhythmic, multi-directional, chaotic movements of the eyes, giving the appearance of agitation. There may be bursts of conjugate movement of the eyes in varying directions and of varying amplitude.

`Atrophy` (MPATH:127) of the `optic nerve` (FMA:50863). Optic atrophy results from the death of the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve and manifesting as a pale optic nerve on fundoscopy.

Term textual definition: Optic atrophy from cranial nerve compression
column5: Atrofia óptica por compresión del nervio craneal

Spanish Translation: Optic disc drusen are acellular, calcified deposits within the optic nerve head. Optic disc drusen are congenital and developmental anomalies of the optic nerve head, representing hyaline-containing bodies that, over time, appear as elevated, lumpy irregularities on the anterior portion of the optic nerve.
Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve.
A pale yellow discoloration of the optic disk (the area of the optic nerve head in the retina). The optic disc normally has a pinkish hue with a central yellowish depression.
Congenital absence of the `optic nerve` (FMA:50863).
A cleft of the optic nerve that extends inferiorly.
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `optic nerve` (FMA:50863).
Underdevelopment of the `optic nerve` (FMA:50863).
`Inflammation` (MPATH:212) of the `optic nerve` (FMA:50863).
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which inflammation affects the anterior chamber, vitreous, retina or choroid.
Papilledema refers to edema (swelling) of the optic disc secondary to any factor which increases cerebral spinal fluid pressure.
Sudden-onset episode of abnormal, involuntary eye movements.
column5: Movimientos paroxísticos involuntarios de los ojos

Spanish Translation: Sectoral aplasia of the iris.

Term textual definition: Patchy atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
column5: Atrofia irregular del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Spanish Translation: Rhythmic, involuntary sinusoidal oscillations of one or both eyes. The waveform of pendular nystagmus may occur in any direction.
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point.
Chorioretinal atrophy concentrated around the optic papilla (i.e., the optic nerve head).
Reduced transparency of the peripheral region of the cornea.

column5: Anomalías de pigmentación periférica de la retina
Desprendimiento periférico de retina por tracción

Spanish Translation: Loss of peripheral vision with retention of central vision, resulting in a constricted circular tunnel-like field of vision.

Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth.

A failure of regression of the hyaloid vessel, which supplies the primary vitreous during embryogenesis and normally regresses in the third trimester of pregnancy, leading to a particular form of posterior cataract. This condition is known as Persistent Hyperplastic Primary Vitreous (PHPV).
The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil.
A form of anterior segment dysgenesis in which abnormal cleavage of the anterior chamber occurs. Peters anomaly is characterized by central, paracentral, or complete corneal opacity.
Tremulousness (trembling) of the lens of the eye.
Excessive sensitivity to light with the sensation of discomfort or pain in the eyes due to exposure to bright light.
Atrophy of the eyeball with blindness and decreased intraocular pressure due to end-stage intraocular disease.

Term textual definition: Pigment deposition in the trabecular meshwork
Spanish Translation: Accumulation of abnormal amounts of pigment within the trabecular meshwork.
column5: Depósitos de pigmento en la malla trabecular

Spanish Translation: Bilaterally symmetrical chorioretinal atrophy, with accumulation of bone corpuscle pigmentation along the retinal veins.
A type of `Congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) in which the opacities occupy the subcapsular cortex at the anterior or posterior pole of the lens.
Multiple pupils.

This corneal dystrophy affects the posterior limiting membrane of the cornea and is characterized by polymorphous plaques of calcium deposits in the deep stromal layers of the cornea, and occasionally by vesicular lesions of the endothelium and edema of the deep corneal stroma.
A type of `sutural cataract` (HP:0010695) in which the opacity follows the posterior Y suture.
A cataract which is found in the back outer layer of the lens. This type often develops more rapidly.
A `cataract` (HP:0000518) that affects the posterior part of the `cortex of the lens` (FMA:58970).
A posterior embryotoxon is the presence of a prominent and anteriorly displaced `line of Schwalbe` (FMA:58422).
A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
A `polar cataract` (HP:0010696) that affects the `posterior pole of the lens` (FMA:58898).
A type of cataract affecting the `posterior pole of lens` (FMA:58898) immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the `Lens capsule` (FMA:58881).

Term textual definition: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
Spanish Translation: Adhesions between the iris and the lens.
column5: Sinequias posteriores de la cámara anterior

Spanish Translation: Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the retina or choroid.
Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual.
A type of glaucoma with optic nerve damage in an eye that does not have evidence of angle closure and in which there is no evidence of a secondary cause.

A type of glaucoma with optic nerve damage in an eye with evidence of significant obstruction of the functional trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris would be classified as having primary angle closure.
A kind of `cataract` that progresses with age.
Initial bilateral ptosis followed by limitation of eye movements in all directions and slowing of saccades.
A `progressive` (PATO:0001818) form of `ptosis` (HP:0000508).
A reduction of previously attained ability to see.
Abnormal prominence of the corneal nerve fibers.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with defective long-wavelength-sensitive (L) cones, causing the sensitivity spectrum to be shifted toward medium wavelengths. This leads to difficulties especially in distinguishing red and green.
Blue and green cones only; no functional red cones.
Deposition of fibrillar material that can be found on all anterior segment structures bathed by aqueous humor.
Apparent optic disc swelling in the absence of increased intracranial pressure.
The upper eyelid margin is positioned 3 mm or more lower than usual and covers the superior portion of the iris (objective); or, the upper lid margin obscures at least part of the pupil (subjective).
A kind of `congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally.
A type of cataract with punctate opacities of the `lens` (FMA:58241).
A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium.
Punctate opacification (reduced transparency) of the corneal stroma.

column5: Alteración de la pigmentación de la retina

Spanish Translation: The presence of recurrent corneal epithelial erosions. Although most corneal epithelial defects heal quickly, some may show recurrent ulcerations.
Alternating and recurrent weakness of the external ocular muscles.
Difficulty with discriminating red and green hues.
An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the b-wave in electroretinography.

Term textual definition: Reduced amplitude of pattern visual evoked potentials
column5: Amplitud reducida de los patrones en los potenciales evocados visuales

Term textual definition: Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells
Spanish Translation: A reduction in the number of corneal endothelial cells.
column5: Reducción del número de células endoteliales de la córnea

Spanish Translation: Fibrosis of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited.
Fibrosis of only some of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal artery.
Decreased retinal arteriolar diameters, which may decrease blood flow and slow oxygen delivery to regions of the retina.
column5: Constricción de las arteriolas de la retina

Spanish Translation: Blockage of retinal arteriole, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to affected regions of the retina.
column5: Oclusión de las arteriolas de la retina

Spanish Translation: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal arterioles.
A glial tumor of the retinal nerve fiber layer arising from a retinal astrocyte.
Deposition of calcium salts in the retina.

A benign tumor of the retina that appears as a grouping of blood-filled saccules within the inner retinal layers or on the surface of the optic disc. Retinal cavernous angioma are described as having a 'cluster of grapes' appearance.
A notch or cleft of the retina.

A deterioration of the retina. This nonspecific term is retained here because of its wide use in the literature, but if possible new annotations should indicate the precise type of retinal abnormality.
Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium.
The presence of `developmental dysplasia` (MPATH:64) of the `retina` (FMA:58301).

Fluid which has escaped from retinal bllod vessels with a high concentration of lipid, protein, and cellular debris with a typically bright, reflective, white or cream colored appearance on the surface of the retina.
Presence of multiple yellowish-white lesions of various size and configuration on the retina not related to vascular lesions.
A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina.

Retinal hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics. They have been called "retinal angiomas" and "retinal hemangiomas" but hemangioblastoma is the preferred term since they are histologically identical to lesions found in the CNS.
`Hemorrhage` (MPATH:119) occurring within the `retina` (FMA:58301).
A small break in the retina.

Retinal lesions can occur due to multiple reasons for example as a result of decreased blood supply to the retina, angiomas in case of von Hipple-Lindau disease, disseminated bacterial and candidal infections, astrocytic hamartomas (so called phakomas) and many more.
The presence of a `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the retina.
Failure of attachment of the retina during development.
A small hole through the whole thickness of the retina.

column5: Atrofia del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Spanish Translation: Dilatation of small blood vessels of the retina.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal blood vessels.
Blockage of the retinal vein.
Hereditary degeneration and atrophy of the retina.

A variant of retinitis pigmentosa characterized by areas of choroidal degeneration with pigment migration and bony spicule formation in the macular area. In contrast to more typical forms of RP, this anomaly destroys central vision, leaving peripheral vision intact.
A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina.

Any noninflammatory disease of the retina. This nonspecific term is retained here because of its wide use in the literature, but if possible new annotations should indicate the precise type of retinal abnormality.
`Optic neuritis`(HP:0100653) that occurs in the section of the optic nerve located behind the eyeball.

A type of retinal detachment associated with a retinal tear, that is, with a break in the retina that allows fluid to pass from the vitreous space into the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
A congenital malformation of the anterior segment characterized by iridicorneal malformation, glaucoma, iris stroma hypoplasia, posterior embryotoxon, and corneal opacities.
A condition where the retina contains no functional cone cells, so that in addition to the absence of color discrimination, vision in lights of normal intensity is difficult.
A form of nystagmus in which the eyeball makes rotary motions around the axis.
An abnormality of tracking eye movements in which smooth pursuit is interrupted by an abnormally high number of saccadic movements.
Presence of multiple aneurysms (sac-like outpouchings) in the blood vessels of the conjunctiva.
Mottling (Spots or blotches with different shades) of the retinal pigment epithelium.

A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that can preced a migraine, whereby a spot of flickering light near the center of the visual fields occurs. The spot prevents vision, and is thus termed scotoma. The scotoma can extend into one or more shimmering arcs of white or colored flashing lights.
Inflammation of the `sclera` (FMA:58269).
A congenital anomaly in which a part or the whole of the cornea acquires the characteristics of sclera, resulting in clouding of the cornea.
Scotoma refers to an area or island of loss or impairment of visual acuity surrounded by a field of normal or relatively well-preserved vision.

Seesaw nystagmus is a type of pendular nystagmus where a half cycle consists of the elevation and intorsion of one eye, concurrently with the depression and extortion of the fellow eye. In the other half cycle, there is an inversion of the ocular movements.
Underdevelopment of the optic nerve and absence of the septum pellucidum.

An ophthalmologic sign in young children resulting from upward-gaze paresis. In this condition, the eyes appear driven downward, the sclera may be seen between the upper eyelid and the iris, and part of the lower pupil may be covered by the lower eyelid.
A severe form of myopia with greater than -6.00 diopters.
Reduced depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is decreased.

Term textual definition: Single isolated congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
Spanish Translation: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital found in around 3-5% of the population and of no functional significance.
column5: Hipertrofia congénita aislada unilateral del epitelio pigmentario de la retina

Term textual definition: Slitlike anterior chamber angles in children
column5: Ángulos de cámara anterior en forma de ranura en niños
Disminución lenta de la agudeza visual

Spanish Translation: An abnormally slow velocity of the saccadic eye movements.
An abnormally slow velocity of horizontal saccadic eye movements.
The appearance of yellow/white crystalline-like (hence the name) spots in the retina and thickening of the peripheral part of the vitreous.
column5: Degeneración de retina en copo de nieve

Spanish Translation: The combination of pendular nystagmus, head nodding, and torticollis.
Rupture of the eyeball not due to trauma.
A lacy pattern or iris pigmentation that resembles the spokes of a bicycle wheel.
Strabismus (also known as squint) is a condition in which the eyes are not properly aligned with each other.
A cataract that affects the region of the lens directly beneath the `capsule of the lens` (FMA:58881).
Bleeding beneath the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelid.
A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
Partial dislocation of the lens in a superior direction.
Atrophy of the `superior rectus` (FMA:49035), the extraocular muscle whose primary function is to elevate the globe.

A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a particular direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
A type of `congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture.

column5: Desplazamiento en dirección temporal de la mácula

Spanish Translation: A pale yellow discoloration of the temporal (lateral) portion of the optic disc.
column5: Palidez de región temporal del disco óptico

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the pupillary light reaction characterized by a marked slowing of the light reaction of usually just one pupil. The pupil tends to be relatively dilated, and there is reduced accommodation.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the conjunctival blood vessels.
A `Congenital cataract` (HP:0000519) characterized by an opacity of all the fibers of a lens.

A type of retinal detachment associated with traction exerted by fibrous or fibrovascular tissue. The fibrous tissue is visible in the vitreous and may be the result of injury, inflammation or neovascularization. If such membranes contract, they pull the sensory retina apart from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium.
A `nuclear cataract` (HP:0008024) with a triangular form.
Difficulty distinguishing between yellow and blue, possible related to dysfunction of the S photopigment.
A `unilateral` (PATO:0000634) form of ptosis.

A type of strabismus`(HP:0000486) in which only one eye is affected. Unilateral strabismus is to be distinguished from alternating strabismus, in which either of the eyes 'squints' at different times.
In primary position the Upbeat nystagmus beats upward. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient.
Inflammation of one or all portions of the uveal tract.

Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus.

A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a vertical direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components.

Visual impairment (or vision impairment) is vision loss (of a person) to such a degree as to qualify as an additional support need through a significant limitation of visual capability resulting from either disease, trauma, or congenital or degenerative conditions that cannot be corrected by conventional means, such as refractive correction, medication, or surgery.
Loss of visual acuity (implying that vision was better at a certain timepoint in live - otherwise the term is impaired vision or a subclass of that).
Vitelliform maculopathy is a sharply demarcated lesion caused by the accumulation of material, often lipofuscin in the subretinal space underlying the macula.
Inflammation of the vitreous body.
Gradual deterioration of the vitreous humor and retina.
Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye.
Zonular cataracts are defined to be cataracts that affect specific regions of the lens.

Term Name: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the birth process.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally elevated or decreased level of a maternal serum marker analytes used in screening for aneuploidy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A deviation from normal size of the placenta.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
column5: Vasos sanguíneos de cordón umbilical anormales

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Term textual definition: Abnormalities of placenta and umbilical cord
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the placenta (the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall) or of the umbilical cord (the cord that connects the fetus to the placenta).
column5: Anomalías de placenta y cordón umbilical

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Term textual definition: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the fetus or the birth of the fetus, excluding structural abnormalities.
column5: Anomalía del desarrollo prenatal o el parto

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the amniotic fluid, which is the fluid contained in the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `umbilical cord` (FMA:85541), which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Term textual definition: Abnormality of umbilical vein blood flow
Spanish Translation: An first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the umbilical vein.
column5: Anomalía del flujo sanguíneo de la vena umbilical

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Term textual definition: Absence of stomach bubble on fetal sonography
Spanish Translation: By the 14th week of gestation it is nearly always possible to visualized the fluid-filled fetal stomach bubble on prenatal sonography. This term refers to the absence of a normal fetal stomach bubble on fetal ultrasonography performed at around 16 to 20 weeks' gestation.
column5: Ausencia de estómago en ecografía fetal

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A position of the fetus at delivery in which the fetus enters the birth canal with the buttocks or feet first.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Hemorrhage between the skull and periosteum of a newborn resulting from rupture of blood vessels that cross the periosteum.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A kind of `breech presentation` (HP:0001623) in which the hips are flexed and the knees are flexed.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormal reduction in quantity or strength of fetal movements.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit.
column5: Anillo de constricción en dígitos fetales

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A finding of a focus of increased echogenicity upon prenatal ultrasound examination of the fetus. The foci may be present in one or both ventricles. Echogenic intracardiac focus (EICF) is defined as a focus of echogenicity comparable to bone, in the region of the papillary muscle in either or both ventricles of the fetal heart.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An acute and life-threatening complication of pregnancy, which is characterized by the appearance of tonic-clonic seizures, usually in a patient who had developed pre-eclampsia. Eclampsia includes seizures and coma that happen during pregnancy but are not due to preexisting or organic brain disorders.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: The cisterna magna is measured on a transaxial view of the fetal head angled 15 degrees caudal to the canthomeatal line. The anterior/posterior diameter is taken between the inferior/posterior surface of the vemis of the cerebellum to the inner surface of the cranium. An enlarged cisternal magna is defined by an anterior/posterior diameter of 10 mm or more (pmid:16100637).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Decreases fetal activity associated with multiple joint contractures, facial anomalies and pulmonary hypoplasia. Ultrasound examination may reveal polyhydramnios, ankylosis, scalp edema, and decreased chest movements (reflecting pulmonary hypoplasia).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity during the fetal period.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Fetal choroid plexus cysts (CPCs) are sonographically discrete, small cysts (3 mm or more) found in the choroid plexus within the lateral cerebral ventricles of the developing fetus at 14 to 24 weeks gestation. Imaging of the choroid plexus is performed in the transverse plane of the fetal head at the same level that the lateral cerebral ventricle is evaluated. The choroid plexus should be inspected bilaterally for the presence of cysts. The size of CPCs is not of clinical relevance (pmid:16100637).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Fifth finger clinodactyly is defined by a hypoplastic or absent mid-phalanx of the fifth digit. Ultrasound identification of the fetal hand must first be undertaken and then appropriate magnification accomplished. The evaluation requires stretching of the 5 fingers. The diagnosis is established when the middle phalanx of the fifth finger is markedly smaller than normal or absent, which often causes the finger to be curved inward  (pmid:16100637).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Abnormally increased production of urine by the fetus resulting in `polyhydramnios` (HP:0001561).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An finding upon obstetric ultrasound examination performed at around 16 to 20 weeks of gestation that is abnormal but not clearly identifiable as a  fetal anatomic malformation or growth restriction. Such findings are known as soft markers since they are associated with increased risk for fetal aneuploidy or other disorders.
column5: Marcador menor en la ecografía fetal

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A kind of `breech presentation` (HP:0001623) in which the hips are flexed and the knees are extended.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally high concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally high concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: The abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, including ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and skin edema.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Excessive vomiting in early pregnancy, leading to the loss of 5% or more of body weight.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: On prenatal ultrasound, the nasal bone is a thin echogenic line within the bridge of the fetal nose. The fetus is imaged facing the transducer with the fetal face strictly in the midline. The angle of insonation is 90 degrees, with the longitudinal axis of the nasal bone as the reference line. Calibres are placed at each end of the nasal bone. Absence of the nasal bone or measurements below 2.5th percentile are considered significant (pmid:16100637).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A kind of `breech presentation` (HP:0001623) in which one or both hips are extended and one or both of the fetus' feet are pointing down and entering the birth canal.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination).
column5: Aumento de la translucencia nucal fetal

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Increased size of the `placenta` (FMA:63934).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Increased length of the `umbilical cord` (FMA:85541).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally low concentration of serum PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A), as compared to normal values for gestational-age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally low concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally low concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormally high concentration of serum conjugated estriol as compared to normal values for gestational-age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: The presence of circulating autoantibodies to anticardiolipin in the mother.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A medical history of a fetus or child born to a mother with an autoimmune disease.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A medical history of exposure during the fetal period to hyperphenylalaninemia because the mother had phenylketonuria with inadequate control during pregnancy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A medical history of exposure of the mother of a child or fetus to a teratogenic substance during pregnancy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Virilization (deepening of  voice, facial hirsutism and scalp hair loss) with onset during pregnancy (usually towards the end of the first trimester) and regression several months post-partum.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Amniotic fluid containing the earliest stools of a mammalian infant.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A type of `hydrops fetalis` (HP:0001789) in which there is no identifiable circulating antibody to red blood cell antigens .

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A complication of pregnancy and delivery in which the umbilical cord wraps around the fetal neck once or multiple times.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Diminished amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with significant amounts of protein in the urine.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: The birth of a baby of less than 37 weeks of gestational age.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Term textual definition: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility
column5: Parto prematuro debido a insuficiencia cervical o fragilidad de membranas

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) is a condition which occurs in pregnancy when the amniotic sac ruptures more than an hour before the onset of labor.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of fetal movement.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Repeated episodes of abortion (Expulsion of the product of fertilization before completing the term of gestation) without deliberate interference.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A short femur length is defined as either a measurement below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or a measurement that is less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The femur should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (pmid:16100637).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The humerus should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (pmid:16100637).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Decreased length of the `umbilical cord` (FMA:85541).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts against the maternal symphysis following delivery of the vertex.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Single umbilical artery (SUA) is the absence of one of the two umbilical arteries surrounding the fetal bladder and in the fetal umbilical cord.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A deviation from equal (50%) inactivation of each parental X chromosome in maternal cells.
column5: Inactivación preferencial del cromosoma X materna

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Reduced size of the `placenta` (FMA:63934).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 20th week of pregnancy.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Pregnancy-induced toxic reactions of the mother that can be as harmless as slight `Maternal hypertension` (HP:0008071) or as life threatening as `Ecplamsia` (HP:0100601).

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Spanish Translation: Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately.

Term Identifier: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
Term textual definition: premature birth following premature rupture of fetal membranes
column5: Parto prematuro por rotura prematura de membranas fetales

Spanish Translation: Any anomaly of the `inflammatory response` (GO:0006954), a response to injury or infection characterized by local vasodilation, extravasation of plasma into intercellular spaces and accumulation of white blood cells and macrophages.
An abnormality of the morphology or counts of the cells that make up the `immune system` (FMA:9825).

column5: Alteración de la secreción de quimioquinas

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the complement system.

An abnormality in the production or cellular release of a cytokine (i.e., any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells).
column5: Alteración de la secreción de citoquinas

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the humoral immune system, which comprises antibodies produced by B cells as well as the complement system.

Term textual definition: Abnormality of immune serum protein physiology
Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the concentration or function of circulating immune proteins.
column5: Alteración de la fisiología de proteínas séricas inmunitarias

Spanish Translation: A functional abnormality of the `immune system` (FMA:9825).
column5: Alteración de la fisiología del sistema inmune
Alteración de la secreción de interferón
Alteración de la secreción de interleuquina

Spanish Translation: Abnormality of the cytokine levels in the blood, i.e., an abnormality of any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells.
column5: Alteración del nivel de citoquinas en suero

Term textual definition: Abnormality of the alternate complement pathway
column5: Alteración de la vía alterna del complemento

Spanish Translation: An abnormality of the `immune system` (FMA:9825).
A `lymph node` (FMA:5034) abnormality.

An anomaly of the lymphatic system, a network of lymphatic vessels that carry a clear fluid called lymph unidirectionally towards either the right lymphatic duct or the thoracic duct, which in turn drain into the right and left subclavian veins respectively.

Abnormality of the `thymus` (FMA:9607), an organ located in the upper anterior portion of the chest cavity just behind the sternum and whose main function is to provide an environment for T lymphocyte maturation.
An abnormality of the `tonsils` (FMA:9609).

Term textual definition: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
column5: Alteración de la secreción del factor de necrosis tumoral

Term textual definition: Absence of lymph node germinal center
Spanish Translation: Absence of germinal centers in `lymph nodes` (FMA:5034). Germinal centers are the parts of lymph nodes in which B lymphocytes proliferate, differentiate, mutate through somatic hypermutation and class switch during antibody responses.
column5: Ausencia de centros germinales en los nódulos linfáticos

Spanish Translation: An allergy is an immune response or reaction to substances that are usually not harmful.
An acute hypersensitivity reaction due to exposure to a previously encountered antigen.
The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against neutrophils.
The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against nuclei or nuclear components.
The presence of circulating autoantibodies to phospholipids.
Absence of the `thymus` (FMA:9607).
Absence or underdevelopment of the `thymus` (FMA:9607).
The occurrence of an immune reaction against the organisms own cells or tissues.
The presence of cellulitis (a diffuse inflammation of connective tissue) on the basis of an immunodeficiency.
A chronic form of `lymphadenopathy` (HP:0002716) that is not related to infection.
Persistence of immune complexes in the blood circulation.
Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against cow milk protein.
column5: Alergia a la leche de vaca

Spanish Translation: Increased level of cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins, especially IGG or IGM, that precipitate spontaneously when serum is cooled below 37 degrees Celsius.
An abnormal reduction in the `inflammatory response` (GO:0006954) to injury or infection.

column5: Disminución sérica de C3 del complemento
Disminución sérica de C9 del complemento
Disminución sérica del factor B del complemento
Disminución sérica del factor H del complemento
Disminución sérica del factor I del complemento

Spanish Translation: An impairment in the production by leukocytes of NFKB1-dependent cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interferon-alpha.
column5: Producción anómala de citoquinas NFKB1 dependientes

Term textual definition: Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway
column5: Agotamiento de los componentes de la vía alternativa del complemento

Spanish Translation: The presence of ectopic `thymus` (FMA:9607) tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend.

Term textual definition: Failure to thrive secondary to recurrent infections
column5: Retraso en el desarrollo secundario a infecciones recurrentes

Spanish Translation: Lymphadenopathy (enlargement of lymph nodes) owing to hyperplasia of follicular (germinal) centers.
A generalized form of `lymphadenopathy` (HP:0002716).
A severe virus infection of the central nervous system by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
Congenital underdevelopment of lymph vessels.
Underdevelopment of the `thymus` (FMA:9607).
A abnormal increase in the `inflammatory response` (GO:0006954) to injury or infection.
Allergy to iodine contrast media used in radiological studies.
Underdevelopment of the `lymph nodes` (FMA:5034).
Inflammation of a `lymph node` (FMA:5034).
Enlargment (swelling) of a `lymph node` (FMA:5034).

Swelling of lymph nodes within the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavities that contains the heart and the great vessels, the esophagus, and trachea and other structures including lymph nodes.
A benign or malignant `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) (tumour) originating in the `thymus` (FMA:9607).
A fungal infection of the toenails or fingernails that tends to cause the nails to thicken, discolor, disfigure, and split.

column5: Deficiencia parcial del factor H del complemento

Term textual definition: Partial functional complement factor D deficiency
column5: Deficiencia funcional parcial del factor D del complemento

Spanish Translation: The presence in the serum of autoantibodies directed against thrombocytes.
An increased susceptibility to Aspergillus infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of Aspergillus infections.
Increased susceptibility to infections with Burkholderia cepacia, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent.
Increased susceptibility to infections with Escherichia coli, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent.
Increased susceptibility to Haemophilus influenzae infections as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by Haemophilus influenzae.
Increased susceptibility to Klebsiella infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Klebsiella infection.
Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis).
Increased susceptibility to Serratia marcescens  infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Serratia marcescens  infection.
Increased susceptibility to Staphylococcus aureus infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Staphylococcus aureus infection.
An increased susceptibility to abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent abscesses.
Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of bacterial infection.
An increased susceptibility to candida infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of candida infections.
Increased susceptibility to enteroviral infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of enteroviral infection.
Increased susceptibility to fungal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of fungal infection.
Increased susceptibility to infection by gram-negative bacteria, as manifested by a medical history of repeated or frequent infections by these agents.
Increased susceptibility to microbial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection.

Term textual definition: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
Spanish Translation: Recurrent infections at an early age with improvement in later childhood.
column5: Infecciones recurrentes en la infancia y la niñez temprana

Spanish Translation: Recurrent infections by Neisseria meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis), which is also known as meningococcus.
Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.
Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial avium complex infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.
column5: Infecciones complejas recurrentes por Mycobacterium avium

Spanish Translation: Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system.
Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection.
Increased susceptibility to viral infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of viral infection.
The presence in the serum of an autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG.
An allergy experienced at a particular time of year when trees or grasses pollinate and elicit an allergic reaction.
Systemic inflammatory response to infection.
Severe combine immunodeficiency (SCID) is a primary immune deficiency that is characterized by a severe defect in both the T- and B-lymphocyte systems.
The presence in serum of antibodies against smooth muscle.
A chronic, relapsing, inflammatory, and often febrile multisystemic disorder of connective tissue, characterized principally by involvement of the skin, joints, kidneys, and serosal membranes.
Increased susceptibility to infection by the protozan parasite of the genus Leishmania.

Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus.
Pulsatile tinnitus related to a tympanic paraganglioma, which is a benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

Normal muscle tissue has a random distribution of type I and type II fibers.
