column5: Aplasia / hipoplasia de la musculatura de la pelvis

Spanish Translation: Muscular hypotonia of one or more limbs.
column5: Hipotonía de una o más extremidades

Spanish Translation: Stiffness of the limbs (acondition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) occurring in an asymmetric pattern.

The lysosomal-vacuolar pathway has a role in the controlled intracellular digestion of macromolecules such as protein complexes and organelles. This feature refers to the presence of an abnormally increased number of autophagic vacuoles in muscle tissue.
Stiffness (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) of the axial musculature.
Reduced strength of the axial musculature (i.e., of the muscles of the head and neck, spine, and ribs).
Formation of calcium deposits in any soft tissue.
An abnormality in which the nuclei of sarcomeres take on an abnormally central localization (or in which this feature is found in an increased proportion of muscle cells).
column5: Fibras del músculo esquelético con núcleo de localización central
Calambres en las manos causadas por el frío

column5: Calambres musculares causados por el frío

Spanish Translation: An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation that is  induced by exposure to cold.

column5: Ausencia congénita de los músculos de los glúteos

Term textual definition: Decreased activity of cytochrome C oxidase in muscle tissue

column5: Disminución de la actividad de la citocromo C oxidasa en el tejido muscular

column5: Disminución del contenido de glucógeno muscular

column5: Depleción de ADN mitocondrial en el tejido muscular
Depósitos inmunorreactivos a la proteína beta-amiloide

Spanish Translation: Reduced ability to climb stairs.
Reduced ability to run.

Muscular atrophy of distal leg muscles.
Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the legs.

Spanish Translation: Reduced strength of the musculature of the distal extremities.
Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the arms.
column5: Debilidad muscular distal de extremidad superior

Spanish Translation: Abnormal results of investigations using electromyography (EMG).

Electromyographic (EMG) findings characteristic of axonal neuropathy, with normal or slightly decreased nerve conduction velocities,  normal or slightly prolonged distal latencies, but significantly reduced motor potentials and sensory amplitudes. There may be spontaneous activity upon needle EMG studies, such as increased insertional activity, positive sharp waves, and fibrillation potentials.
Evidence of chronic denervation on electromyography.

Term textual definition: EMG: continuous motor unit activity at rest
Spanish Translation: Continuous electromyographic activity of motor units at rest, i.e., without voluntary movement of the muscles.
column5: EMG: actividad motora continua en reposo

Term textual definition: EMG: decremental response of compound muscle action potential (CMAP) to repetitive nerve stimulation
Spanish Translation: A compound muscle action potential (CMAP) is a type of electromyography (EMG). CMAP refers to a group of almost simultaneous action potentials from several muscle fibers in the same area evoked by stimulation of the supplying motor nerve and are recorded as one multipeaked summated action potential. This abnormality refers to a greater than normal decrease in the amplitude during the course of the investigation.
column5: EMG: respuesta decreciente del potencial de acción muscular compuesto (CMAP) de la estimulación nerviosa repetitiva

Spanish Translation: An electromyographic finding associated with erratic or absent neuromuscular transmission with erratic, moment-to-moment changes in the shape of the motor unit potential (MUP).
The presence of abnormal electromyographic patterns indicative of myopathy, such as small-short polyphasic motor unit potentials.

High frequency discharges in electromyography (EMG) that vary in amplitude and frequency, waxing and waning continuously with firing frequencies ranging from 150/second down to 20/second and producing a sound that has been referred to as a dive bomber sound.
Spontaneous, repetitive electrical activity demonstrated by electromyography (EMG).
column5: EMG: descargas miotónicas en trenes o salvas

Spanish Translation: The presence of characteristic findings of denervation on electromyography (fibrillations, positive sharp waves, and giant motor unit potentials).
The presence of reduced conduction velocity of motor nerves on electromyography.
Recurrent episodes of muscle flaccidity, a type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching.
The occurrence of repeated episodes of generalized muscular hypotonia.
Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles of the leg brought on by physical exertion.
column5: Calambres en las piernas inducidos por el ejercicio

Spanish Translation: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles brought on by physical exertion.
column5: Calambres musculares inducidos por el ejercicio

Spanish Translation: An abnormally increased tendency towards muscle fatigue induced by physical exercise.
column5: Fatiga muscular inducida por el ejercicio

Spanish Translation: A type of muscle stiffness that occurs following physical exertion.
column5: Rigidez muscular inducida por el ejercicio

Spanish Translation: The occurrence of an unusually high amount of muscle pain following exercise.
`Rhabdomyolysis` (HP:0003201) induced by exercise.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the facial muscles.

column5: Atrofia del primer músculo interóseo dorsal
Debilidad del primer músculo interóseo dorsal

Spanish Translation: Generalized congenital lack of development of the muscles, which are then replaced by a mixture of dense fat and fibrous tissue.
Generalized (diffuse, unlocalized) amyotrophy (muscle atrophy) affecting multiple muscles.
Generalized muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone).
Generalized (unlocalized) atrophy affecting muscles of the limbs in both proximal and distal locations.
Hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells in a generalized (not localized) distribution.
Generalized weakness or decreased strength of the muscles, affecting both distal and proximal musculature.

column5: Aspecto musculoso generalizado desde el nacimiento

Spanish Translation: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period and affecting the entire musculature.
A phenomenon whereby patients are not able to stand up without the use of the hands owing to weakness of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs.
Difficulty releasing one's grip associated with prolonged first handgrip relaxation times.
Reduced ability to flex the femur, that is, to pull the knee upward.
column5: Debilidad de la flexión de la cadera

Spanish Translation: Underdevelopment of the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in adduction, extension, internal rotation, and transverse extension of the shoulder and assists in movement of the scapula.
Underdevelopment of the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in abduction, upward Rotation, and elevation of the scapula.
Underdevelopment of the musculature.

An abnormal increase in intracellular lipid droplets In a muscle. The number and size of these drops can increase with somd disorders of lipid metabolism affecting muscle. See pmid 20691590 for histological images.
column5: Aumento de gotas de lípidos intramiocelulares

Spanish Translation: An abnormal, increased fatiguability of the musculature.
An increased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue.
An abnormal accumulation of lipids in skeletal muscle.
column5: Contenido aumentado de lípidos en tejido muscular

Term textual definition: Increased variability in muscle fiber diameter
Spanish Translation: An abnormally high degree of muscle fiber size variation. This phenotypic feature can be observed upon muscle biopsy.
column5: Aumento de la variabilidad en el diámetro de la fibra muscular

Spanish Translation: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy.

Atrophy of the interosseus muscles (including the palmar interossei that lie on the anterior aspect of the metacarpals, the dorsal interosseus muscles of the hand, which lie between the intercarpals, the plantar interosseus muscles, which lie underneath the metatarsal bones, and the dorsal interossei, which are located between the metatarsal bones.
Blood clot formed within muscle tissue following leakage of blood into the tissue.

column5: Debilidad muscular distal de inicio tardío

Spanish Translation: Lack of strength of the proximal musculature occuring late in the clinical course.
column5: Debilidad muscular proximal de inicio tardío

Spanish Translation: Reduced strength and weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs.
Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle.
Weakness of the limb-girdle muscles (also known as the pelvic and shoulder girdles), that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders and the pelvis.
Muscular dystrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle (the hips and shoulders).
Muscular atrophy affecting the lower limb.
Weakness of the muscles of the legs.
Severe hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells.
Multiple small zones of sarcomeric disorganization and lack of oxidative activity (known as minicores) in muscle fibers.
A type of myopathy associated with mitochondrial disease and characterized by findings on biopsy such as ragged red muscle fibers.
The presence of multiple deletions of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).

Term textual definition: Muscle abnormality related to mitochondrial dysfunction
column5: Anomalía muscular relacionada con disfunción mitocondrial

Spanish Translation: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles.
The presence of inclusion bodies within the cytoplasm of muscle cells. Inclusion bodies are aggregates (deposits) or stainable material, usually misfolded proteins.
column5: Cuerpos de inclusión citoplasmática en la fibra muscular
Cuerpos hialinos en la fibra muscular
Cuerpos de inclusión en la fibra muscular

Spanish Translation: The presence of inclusion bodies within the nucleus of muscle cells. Inclusion bodies are aggregates (deposits) or stainable material, usually misfolded proteins.
column5: Cuerpos de inclusión intranucleares en la fibra muscular

Spanish Translation: Abnormal cell death involving muscle fibers usually associated with break in, or absence of, muscle surface fiber membrane and resulting in irreversible damage to muscle fibers.

Fiber splitting or branching is a common finding in human and rat skeletal muscle pathology. Fiber splitting refers to longitudinal halving of the complete fiber, while branching originates from a regenerating end of a necrotic fiber as invaginations of the sarcolemma. In fiber branching, one end of the fiber remains intact as a single entity, while the other end has several branches.

Unusual regions of densely packed membranous tubules known as tubular aggregates which present as membranous inclusions, derived from membranes of sarcoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria, containing miscellaneous proteins with a variety of enzymatic activities.
column5: Inclusiones tubulares en la fibra muscular
Inclusiones tubulorreticulares en la fibra muscular

Spanish Translation: A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation.
Hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells (as opposed to hyperplasia, which refers to an increase in the number of muscle cells).

Term textual definition: Muscle hypertrophy of the lower extremities
Spanish Translation: Muscle hypertrophy primarily affecting the legs.
A condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm.
Reduced strength of muscles.

The term dystrophy means abnormal growth. However, muscular dystrophy is used to describe primary myopathies with a genetic basis and a progressive course characterized by progressive skeletal muscle weakness, defects in muscle proteins, and the apoptosis of muscle cells.

Muscular hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle), often involving reduced muscle strength. Hypotonia is characterized by a diminished resistance to passive stretching.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk.
A tendency to experience muscle pain.
Myofibrillar structural changes characterized by abnormal intracellular accumulation of the intermediate filament desmin and other proteins.
A disorder of muscle unrelated to impairment of innervation or neuromuscular junction.
A general term for inflammation of the muscles without respect to the underlying cause.
An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the face.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the jaw.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the leg.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the arm.
Myotonia that occurs after a period of rest and decreases with continuing exercise.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the muscles of the neck.
Underdevelopment of muscles of the neck.

Nemaline rods are abnormal bodies that can occur in skeletal muscle fibers. The rods can be observed on histological analysis of muscle biopsy tissue or upon electron microscopy, where they appear either as extensions of sarcomeric Z-lines, in random array without obvious attachment to Z-lines (often in areas devoid of sarcomeres) or in large clusters localized at the sarcolemma or intermyofibrillar spaces.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period.
Muscular atrophy that does not display a progression in severity with time.
A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the paraspinal muscles.

Term textual definition: Paresis of extensor muscles of the big toe
column5: Paresia de los músculos extensores del dedo gordo del pie

Spanish Translation: Wasting of the pectoral muscles, i.e., of the pectoralis major and  pectoralis minor.
Underdevelopment of the `pectoralis major` (FMA:9627).
Atrophy of the muscles of the pelvic girdle (also known as hip girdle), i.e., the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, the adductors, the psoas major and the iliacus muscle.

Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles that attach to the pelvic girdle (the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, adductor longus, pectineus, and gracilis muscles).
Weakness of the muscles of the pelvic girdle (also known as the hip girdle), that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the pelvis.
A localized myotonic contraction in a muscle in reaction to percussion (tapping with the examiner's finger, a rubber percussion hammer, or a similar object).

column5: Contracciones musculares de balanceo rápido inducidas por la percusión (PIRC)

Spanish Translation: Weakness of the peroneal muscles.
Difficulty to maintain correct position of the head while standing or sitting.
column5: Mal control del tono de cuello y cabeza

Spanish Translation: Progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature.
Progressive muscular atrophy affecting muscles in the distal portions of the extremities.
Lack of strength of the proximal muscles that becomes progressively more severe.
Progressive spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
Amyotrophy (muscular atrophy) affecting the proximal musculature.

column5: Rigidez muscular proximal de las extremidades

Spanish Translation: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles.

Term textual definition: Proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs
Spanish Translation: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the legs.
column5: Debilidad muscular proximal de extremidades inferiores

Term textual definition: Proximal muscle weakness in upper limbs
Spanish Translation: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the arms.
column5: Debilidad muscular proximal de extremidades superiores

Spanish Translation: Proximal spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the arms.
Weakness of the quadriceps muscle (that is, of the muscle fasciculus of quadriceps femoris).

An abnormal appearance of muscle fibers observed on muscle biopsy. Ragged red fibers can be visualized with Gomori trichrome staining as irregular and intensely red subsarcolemmal zones, whereas the normal myofibrils are green. The margins of affect fibers appear red and ragged. The ragged-red  is due to the accumulation of abnormal mitochondria below the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber, leading to the appearance of a red rim and speckled sarcoplasm.
Breakdown of muscle fibers that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents (myoglobin) into the bloodstream.

Presence of abnormal vacuoles (membrane-bound organelles) in the sarcolemma. On histological staining with hematoxylin and eosin, rimmed vacuoles are popcorn-like clear vacuoles with a densely blue rim. The vacuoles are often associated with cytoplasmic and occasionally intranuclear eosinophilic inclusions.

Ring fibers are formed by a bundle of peripheral myofibrils which are circumferentially oriented such that they encircle the internal portion of the sarcoplasm which is normal in structure and orientation.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the scapular muscles.
Muscular atrophy in the distribution of shoulder girdle and peroneal muscles.
A severe degree of muscular hypotonia characterized by markedly reduced muscle tone.
Amyotrophy affecting the muscles of the shoulder girdle.
column5: Atrofia muscular de la cintura escapular

Spanish Translation: Deposition of fat within muscles.
Muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
Wasting of the `sternocleidomastoid muscle` (FMA:13407), the muscle in the anterior part of the neck that acts to flex and rotate the head.

Term textual definition: Subsarcolemmal accumulations of abnormally shaped mitochondria
Spanish Translation: An abnormally increased number of mitochondria in the cytoplasma adjacent to the sarcolemma (muscle cell membrane), whereby the mitochondria also possess an abnormal morphology.
column5: Acumulación en subsarcolema de mitocondrias de forma anómala

Spanish Translation: A disorder characterized by muscle twitches, cramps, and carpopedal spasm, and when severe, laryngospasm and seizures. This condition is associated with unstable depolarization of axonal membranes, primarily in the peripheral nervous system.

column5: Debilidad muscular de la eminencia tenar

Spanish Translation: Muscle hypertrophy affecting the thighs.
Atrophy of the tibialis muscle.
Muscle weakness affecting the tibialis anterior muscle.

Spanish Translation: Multiple small zones of sarcomeric disorganization and lack of oxidative activity (known as minicores) in type 1 and type 2 muscle fibers.
column5: Fibras musculares tipo 1 y tipo 2 con regiones minicore

Term textual definition: Type 1 fibers relatively smaller than type 2 fibers
Spanish Translation: The presence of abnormal muscle fiber size such that type 1 fibers are smaller than type 2 fibers.
column5: Fibras tipo 1 relativamente más pequeñas que las de tipo 2

Spanish Translation: Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
An abnormal predominance of type I muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 2 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
An abnormal predominance of type II muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).

`Rhabdomyolysis` (HP:0003201) induced by a viral infection.
An abnormality of Sharpey's fibers (bone fibers, or perforating fibers), which are a matrix of connective tissue consisting of bundles of strong collagenous fibres connecting periosteum to bone.
An abnormality of `adipose tissue` (FMA)20110), which is loose connective tissue composed of adipocytes.
Any abnormality of the soft tissues, including both connective tissue (tendons, ligaments, fascia, fibrous tissues, and fat).
An abnormality of `fascia` (FMA:30318).
Lack of `subcutaneous adipose tissue` (FMA:74315).

Term textual definition: Absence of subcutaneous fat over entire body except buttocks, hips, and thighs

Reduced amount of `adipose tissue` (FMA:20110) in the region of the neck.
column5: Disminución del tejido adiposo alrededor del cuello

Spanish Translation: `Inflammation` (MPATH:212) of `fascia` (FMA:30318).
Generalized degenerative changes of the fat tissue.

An increase in adipose tissue mass by hyperplastic growth (increase in the number of adipocytes) or by hypertrophic growth (increase in the size of adipocytes occurring primarily by lipid accumulation within the cell).
The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intraabdominal fat tissue.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intramuscular fat tissue.
The presence of an abnormally increased amount of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the trunk of the body.
column5: Aumento de tejido adiposo subcutáneo del tronco

Spanish Translation: Localized loss of fat tissue.
Degenerative changes of the fat tissue.

Term textual definition: Loss of gluteal subcutaneous adipose tissue
Spanish Translation: Loss (reduction of previously present) of `subcutaneous adipose tissue` (FMA:74315) in the `gluteal region` (FMA:25245).
column5: Pérdida de tejido adiposo subcutáneo glúteo

Term textual definition: Loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue in limbs
column5: Pérdida de tejido adiposo subcutáneo en las extremidades

column5: Pérdida de tejido adiposo subcutáneo del tronco

column5: Ausencia casi completa de tejido adiposo metabólicamente activo (subcutáneo, intrabdominal, intratorácico)

Spanish Translation: Inflammation of `adipose tissue` (FMA)20110).
The presence of an abnormally reduced amount of `subcutaneous adipose tissue` (FMA:74315).
An abnormality of the `breast` (FMA:9601).
An abnormality of the `nipple` (FMA:67771).
Absence or underdevelopment of the breasts.
The presence of `asymmetrical` (PATO:0000616) `breasts` (FMA:9601).
Underdevelopment of the `breast` (FMA:9601) on both sides.
The presence of a `carcinoma` (MPATH:549) of the `breast` (FMA:9601).
The presence of `hypertrophy` (MPATH:159) of the `breast` (FMA:9601).
Underdevelopment of the `breast` (FMA:9601).
The presence of a `fibroma` (MPATH:407) of the `breast` (FMA:9601).
Spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing.
Abnormal development of large mammary glands in males resulting in breast enlargement.
Underdevelopment of the `areola` (FMA:67796), the circular area of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.
Underdevelopment of the `nipple` (FMA:67771).
The presence of nipples that instead of pointing outward are retracted inwards.
Placement of the nipples at a lower than normal location.
Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal.
A `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) of the `breast` (FMA:9601).
Presence of more than two nipples.
Underdevelopment of the `breast` (FMA:9601) on one side only.
A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple.
Any abnormality of the voice.
An abnormally low-pitched voice.
The presence of a characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to the meowing of a kitten.
An abnormal increase in the pitch (frequency) of the voice.
column5: Voz aguda o de tono alto

Spanish Translation: Hoarseness refers to a change in the pitch or quality of the voice, with the voice sounding weak, very breathy, scratchy, or husky.
Hyponasal speech is when there is an abnormally reduced nasal airflow during speech often in a setting of nasal obstruction or congestion.
A type of speech characterized by the presence of an abnormally increased nasal airflow during speech, associated with incomplete or weak closure of the velum.
Impairment in the physical production of speech sounds.
Reduced intensity (volume) of speech.

A type of soft tissue sarcoma with a histological appearance reminiscent of alveoli because of  its reticulated fibrous stroma enclosing groups of sarcoma cells, which resemble epithelial cells and are enclosed in alveoli walled with connective tissue.
column5: Sarcoma de partes blandas de aspecto alveolar

Spanish Translation: Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels.
A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue, occurring more often in cylindrical bones.
A neoplasm of the face.

Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term "fibroblastic" or "fibromatous" is used to describe tumors of the fibrous connective tissue. When the term fibroma is used without modifier, it is usually considered benign, with the term fibrosarcoma reserved for malignant tumors.
A fibroblastic sarcoma is a malignant tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue and characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells.
A rare, benign soft tissue tumor that typically occurs within the first two years of life.
Any neoplasm composed of fibrous tissue.

A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin - eg, exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes - eg, neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma.
A neoplasm containing histiocytes.
A smooth muscle connective tissue tumor, which is rare type of cancer that is a malignant neoplasm of smooth muscle. When such a neoplasm is benign, it is called a leiomyoma.
Benign neoplasia derived from lipoblasts or lipocytes of white or brown fat. May be angiomatous or hibernomatous.
Malignant neoplasms which probably originate in primitive mesenchymal stem cell populations differentiating down a lipomatous pathway.

Malignant mesothelioma is a form of cancer that originates from the cells of the mesothelium, a thin tissue layer surrounding the body's internal organs. Malignant mesothelioma is almost exclusively caused by asbestos exposure, pleural mesothelioma beeing the most common form, affecting the lining of the lungs called the pleura. Other forms such as perioneal-, percardial- or testicular- mesothelioma are much rarer.
The presence of a `melanoma` (MPATH:359), a malignant cancer originating from pigment producing melanocytes. Melanoma can originate from the skin or the pigmented layers of the eye (the uvea).
A neoplasm of the mouth.
The presence of multiple lipomas (a type of benign tissue made of fatty tissue).
A liposarcoma that contains myxomatous tissue.
An organ or organ-system abnormality that consists of uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation which can occur in any part of the body as a benign or malignant `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) (tumour).
Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm.
Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality.
A benign or malignant `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) (tumour) of adipose tissue.
A neoplasm of the head and neck region with origin in the lip, oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, and larynx.
A benign or malignant `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle.
A benign or malignant `neoplasm` (MPATH:218) (tumour) originating in the respiratory system.
A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma.
A benign tumor of striated muscle.
Presence of a lipoma in the region of the sacrum.
The presence of a `sarcoma` (MPATH:551).
A type of mesenchymal tissue cell tumor that exhibits epithelial differentiation, which most frequently arises in the extremities.
A neoplasm of the trachea.
